PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1993 which is before the House this morning represents yet another failure in the government's assets sales program. The government has come to privatisation in the first place in an altogether tawdry way. We have had promises over the years that the government would not be selling off this, that or the other. We have had Labor members running around the country assuring vested interest groups that these public bodies would be well and truly kept in public ownership throughout the term of the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: Yet, over the years, we have seen the government back down little bit by little bit, privatisation by privatisation, until it has come to what the opposition was saying all along, and that is that there are commercial assets that are held by government, and operated by government, that need not be owned by government. Indeed, some of those commercial operations, if privatised, can be operated much more effectively, much more efficiently, with better services and with lower costs than they can if they are kept in public ownership.

When the government came to privatisation, it came not for the right reasons, but for altogether the wrong ones. This was not a government that sat down and said, `Here we are operating commercial services. Here we are with something in public ownership that could be just as well run by the private sector—indeed, better run by the private sector'. It was not a government that sat down and said, as we did, that ordinary Australians should be offered an income stake in some of these commercial enterprises; that they should be given a share in the income generation and the capital appreciation; that they should be given a stake in the ownership of these national assets.

The government has come to privatisation for altogether the wrong reasons. It is a simple accounting exercise that has led the government into privatisation—basically an attempt to try to get money; an attempt to sell off silver to get money to put into recurrent revenue to make sure that the government can mask the real financial problems that it has with its budget.

Who can forget the opposition to the coalition's program on the Commonwealth Bank privatisation during the 1990 election? I can well remember going to a rally addressed by the then Leader of the Opposition at National Mutual Square where officers from the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association turned up with great placards saying, `Vote for Labor. Make sure the Commonwealth Bank is never privatised'. We can probably all remember that the former member for Hindmarsh, John Scott, had a wonderful sign in his window saying, `Which bank should never be sold for 30 pieces of silver?'. We can all remember the campaign promises that were being made back then. Of course, after the election the government found a tawdry excuse for floating 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. It was supposed to be done because of the inefficiency and the financial incompetence of the Kirner government. It was a case of getting rid of the State Bank of Victoria and shelving it into the Commonwealth Bank. We were given assurances even then that that 30 per cent would be the only part of the Commonwealth Bank that was privatised. Now we find that we have another 19 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank coming on stream.

I do not know why the government does this on a piecemeal basis. If it has come to the conclusion that the Commonwealth Bank is operating a commercial service in full competition with other banks, why can it not operate on the same basis? Why do we have to go through this death of a thousand cuts as the government reverses its position and, bit by bit, comes to what is economically necessary and inevitable—and, what is more, practically right? The government is now looking carefully at Telecom; it will be given the same sort of treatment. A reason will be thought of why there should be part privatisation of Telecom. A reason will be found why there should be a bit more. People in the Labor leadership are looking longingly at Telecom, thinking that Telecom could be the next golden nest egg to try to right their financial troubles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will they get away with it?

—Will they? We have said that Telecom should be privatised—not for the wrong reasons, but for the right ones. Irrespective of the financial mismanagement and the dreadful position the government has got the budget into, Telecom is now a commercial service operating in competition with Optus. There is no reason why the government should own one and not the other and no reason why average Australians should not have the opportunity to take a stake in Telecom.

PARA.TAB: The Labor leadership, which is looking lovingly at privatising Telecom, has to soften up its caucus and national council before it can do so. But I make a prediction that that, unquestionably, will come onto the list. All the Telecom unions that have been campaigning so hard for the government, on the basis that Telecom would not be privatised, will be placed in exactly the same position as the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association that campaigned so hard for the government's re-election on the basis that it would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank. But it did—and it will do so again.

The same thing happened with Australian Airlines and Qantas. Although the government had said that there was no justification for the privatisation of Australian Airlines or Qantas, after an election was out of the way, the political points were over and caucus and the national council had been softened up, we suddenly found that all the arguments had changed. The coalition had been right; it was better to have commercial airlines operating on a proper commercial footing in the private sector in full competition with other private sector airlines. In June 1992 the government announced that Qantas would purchase 100 per cent of Australian Airlines and the merged airline would be fully privatised. In November 1992 the government introduced the Qantas Sale Bill in both houses to give effect to the decision to privatise Qantas.

The bill received the support of the coalition. After all, it was our policy. It was assented to on 21 December 1992. There was a very interesting clause in that Qantas Sale Bill. It said that those parts of the act that had not come into effect would lapse on 31 December 1993. Do honourable members know why? It was there so that the government could hold itself to a timetable to get the Qantas float onto the market completed by 31 December 1993. It even put a legislative check on itself to make sure that that sale went through. The reason we have this amending bill today is that yet again the government has failed. The government had said it would be all over by 31 December 1993; the act would lapse on that day if the process had not been completed. But now, in September 1993, we have been asked to extend it until 30 June 1995. This is yet another failure by a government which was dragged kicking and screaming into the process in the first place. This is another failure that the parliament has to correct.

The act provided for the full sale of Qantas in the 1993-94 financial year. The sale was planned in two parts, a trade sale of 25 per cent and a public float of the remaining 75 per cent. The trade sale was completed on 10 March 1993, with British Airways purchasing the 25 per cent holding for $665 million. On 2 July 1993, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) announced that the government had decided to reschedule the float which, according to the statute, had to be completed by December 1993 and that, instead, the government would bring forward the Commonwealth Bank sale. Honourable members should remember that the Commonwealth Bank was never going to be sold either. That measure has been brought forward to try to raise $1.6 billion for the deficit hole. It is selling off the family silver to try to cover current expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The parliamentary secretary is next on the speaker's list. He will save his ammunition until then.

—It is just as well that the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) is not the Earl of Dartmouth or some British aristocrat. He would sell off the family castle to try to cover gambling debts. This is the policy that the government has been following; sell off the family silver, put it into recurrent assets and watch the money dissipate. At the end of the day, rather than retiring debt or treating a capital sale as a capital repayment, the government grabs the money, puts it into recurrent expenditure and Australia is worse off. At the end of the day we have lost a capital asset; we have not reduced our capital liabilities. All we have done is spent it—and every Australian is poorer.

PARA.TAB: Then we go on to other spending commitments; that is why we go on to another asset privatisation. By the time the government has finished this process, we will have lost capital assets and we will not have reduced our debt or our capital account—all we will have seen is the money effectively burned up in financial recklessness.

We had this Friday afternoon special from the Minister for Finance. He really specialises in the Friday afternoon press release, generally after the network television deadlines have closed. He had another Friday afternoon special to say that the long vaunted, long awaited, much publicised, greatly heralded Qantas sale, which was to be completed by December 1993—surprise, surprise—was not going to happen and was to be deferred until the 1994-95 financial year. This immediately created the problem that we hear about today. The legislation had provided that the sale had to be over by December. So we come back to the parliament with another failure under our belt, another failure in an assets sale, back here to amend a piece of legislation that the government could not even hold for about two years. We are back here trying to amend it all again and trying to pretend that the government's assets sales program is on track. I tell the government: if it is on track, it is on a road between Gundagai and Holbrook—somewhere out in a place where it was never expected.

I suppose an investor seeing the government assets sales program would sit back looking bemusedly at all of this. I do not think investors would be working overtime to make sure that they were ready and prepared for a government assets sale, because they are bound to be disappointed. The international investors and the broking houses must have walked down the aisle to consummate with the government on asset sales so many times that they have been utterly frustrated and disappointed. They are going to find it hard to walk down that aisle with all seriousness again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the consummation.
—They never get to the consummation; it is probably lucky for them. In order to preserve these provisions until the offering is made, the bill proposes to extend the cut-off date until 30 June 1995.

PARA.TAB: The government's incompetent bungling over this sale is indicative of the utter failure of its assets sales program generally. The government's assets sales program has never met a single target in any financial year. Three strikes and the government is out. The 1990-91 budget forecast that the government would receive $1 billion for assets sales. Do honourable members know what it received? It received $161 million—about one-tenth of the return on its planned assets sales. In the 1991-92 budget forecast, the government said that it would receive $625 million from assets sales. Do honourable members know what it got? The government paid out $300 million. It did not get anything; it actually paid out in that year. After saying that it was going to get $625 million, it actually shovelled out $300 million on these wonderfully planned assets sales.

I suppose the government's forecasts are getting better. In last year's budget, the government said that it might get $1.6 billion and it got $800 million. That is not bad. It nearly got 50 per cent of what it forecasted in last year's budget. Can the government tell me who will believe that it will get its $2.4 billion this year? Who is going to believe it? Three strikes and the government is out. The government has not met one target in the last three years. All the government does is pull out these numbers. It probably gets them from some computer deep in the bowels of the Department of Finance, which is probably driven not by any practicalities of what the government thinks it will get, but by what it needs to make the budget's bottom line look better. We get this figure of $2.4 billion.

The major part of that will come from the Commonwealth Bank, which the government was not going to extend the privatisation of in any case. That is why we sit back and say that Telecom is going to come. There is nothing surer. When we do not make this $2.4 billion, we will be back here next year saying that the government has suddenly seen a ray of light. Telecom will be back on. There will be a huge figure and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) will be able to say, `Look how well I am doing. I am getting the budget deficit under control'.

The worst aspect of this asset sales failure is that it is being used to mask and cover another of the government's financial disasters—the budget deficit. Every year the government treats planned asset sales as negative outlays. It announces a planned asset sale and says, `There you go, that is revenue in next year's budget'. The government says that this year we will have $2.4 billion of asset sales and that we can then put that into our account and show that as $2.4 billion of revenue. Look how much better that makes the government's budgetary deficit. This is nothing more than an elaborate ploy to mask the real financial failure.

We have made some inquiries of the Department of Finance to try to find out what world best practice is and whether other governments are selling off the silver and treating this as negative outlays or revenue, as income for the current year. The Department of Finance has not been able to tell us yet.

We have some questions on notice to try to find out how this is being treated. If a private company were selling off an asset, that would be shown on the balance sheet. Assets at the start of the financial year and at the end of the financial year would be shown on the balance sheet. The sale of a capital asset would be shown as an item on the balance sheet. A private company would not show an asset sale going into profit and loss with no corresponding entry. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe) must remember double entry accounting from his accounting days: if something is put on one side of the ledger, it is brought to the other side of the ledger; something by the window, something by the door.

The government takes out a capital asset and shows it as revenue but there is no corresponding entry to show that it has run down its assets or capital stock. That is because the government does not create a balance sheet. The way in which this government accounts for asset sales is all one way. The wonderful thing about it is that the government then takes that into account and says, `This is really going to help our budget deficit'. If the government is really going to look at the underlying budget deficit, it should not take the capital items into account. When the government says, `We have only got a $16 billion deficit', under normal accounting procedures it cannot claim $2.4 billion of planned asset sales off that. The real budget deficit starts at about $18.4 billion.

The government is saying in relation to its budget deficit, `This year, as part of our deficit reducing program, we are going to increase the deficit'. That is the old trick of saying, `We are going to reduce the deficit by increasing it; we are going to go from Sydney to Melbourne by going to Brisbane'. The government already has the deficit at $16 billion, but these planned asset sales have to be added back on, which will take the deficit to about $18 billion. This blows the government budget deficit as a proportion of GDP over the four per cent, back to the levels of the Whitlam government deficit.

The government has planned a few other funny tricks in relation to its budget deficit. It has Reserve Bank abnormal profits in there and increased dividends from government business enterprises. If they are taken out, as the private sector financial forecasters are saying, this budget deficit could be, in real underlying terms, as high as $23 billion, which will put the government's budget deficit at a level worse than that of the Whitlam government.

If the government wants to compare this budget deficit with the Whitlam government deficit asset sales cannot be taken into account. Even Gough was not flogging off the family silver to make his budget deficit better. He did not have that program; he did not have those items in his budget deficit. This government has taken something that has never been treated before, whacked it in and then tried to compare itself historically. The government has to compare itself historically and take out those abnormal one-off items. It proves that this government is back to the levels of financial profligacy, mismanagement and incompetence of Whitlam. `Dawkins greater than Whitlam' will probably appear on his tombstone.

At least it could be said that Whitlam had the decency to sack Cairns over his incompetence. But what can be said about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)? The Prime Minister has the indecency to fail to take any action in relation to financial mismanagement which is as bad, if not worse.

In cumulative terms, the effect of all of these budget deficits is that the government is running up debt. It is running up debt every year that it increases these budget deficits. If we add them up, we get a deterioration in the finances of the Commonwealth. The cumulative deficit over the past three years is in the order of $40 billion. It has deteriorated by $57 billion since 1989-90. Even if the government meets its targets, whatever those targets may now be, and I will come back to that in a moment—

TALK.START.PARA: —One per cent of GDP over four years.
—One per cent, is it? The government is still talking about a further cumulative deficit of about $25 billion to come before it gets to—
—I let you know because you had forgotten.

—Let me come to the government's targets. During the election campaign its target was for a surplus by 1995-96—remember that? Then it became one per cent by 1996-97. Then, when the budget came down, it became 1.1 per cent by 1996-97. Then, when the sales taxes and the wine taxes looked as though they were in deep trouble, it became 1.2 per cent by 1996-97. We have never seen such a moving target in all our lives. If this were an archery competition, those opposite would be thrown out for cheating. Every time the government has set a target so it can actually be measured, it is moved. It is like one of those chickens that people try to shoot at the show. This is a moveable budget deficit feast.

PARA.TAB: The reason why the government put the target out to 1996-97 is that it knows that that will be after the next election and government members will not be held accountable in this parliament. That is a lovely trick. They have made sure they are offering a target that they will never actually be responsible for bringing in. They have done that because they have no confidence—the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have no confidence—that that target will ever be met.

If we look very carefully at the budget forecast we see that it is the same old trick; it is not even a new trick. The growth figures are inflated down the years so the government can say that the economy will boom and it will all come in. Have we not heard this before? We heard exactly the same story in relation to the One Nation statement. We were going to have four per cent growth by 1992-93; the place was going to go gangbusters and the budget was going to self-repair. Have we not heard all this before? Honourable members know, the financial markets know and, in their better moments, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer know—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they have better moments?

—They do have better moments—very rare indeed. But in their better moments, in the dead of night when they are in their cars going home, they know the confidence trick they are pulling. They know that this is a budget deficit feast which is absolutely moveable. First of all, they pad out the asset sales as revenue, they then pad out a budget deficit forecast, add into the mix an inflated growth forecast and say, `Aren't we doing well?'.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the Treasurer is making the claim that the Australian economy is booming, but the proof comes in the budget figures. If the Australian economy is booming and if we are now in a period of sustained economic growth, why is our budget deficit going to be worse this current financial year than it was last year? If the Australian economy were recovering, the budget deficit, through the automatic stabilisers, would be coming back and there would be no need to pump prime. The government deficit would be reducing in this year if we were really out of recession and there would be no need to run historical deficits in the order of the 1981-82 or 1974-75 recessions.

The absolute truth comes when we look at the financial figures and see that these are inflated claims. We are supposed to be two years out of recession and going along well. The only trouble is that the budget deficit gets worse, and it gets less worse only because the government does this fiddle in relation to asset sales.

When a private company sells off assets and puts the receipts into recurrent expenditure to mask its operating or trading position it is generally an infallible sign that receivership is on the way. That is exactly the point at which the receivers say, `We are not seeing any operating profit here but we are watching assets start to disappear'. That is the point at which receivers move in to protect their assets. The government is doing exactly the same sorts of things.

Not only is the government doing this in relation to the trading account but it is also being done in relation to the budget figures, which is even worse. If a private company makes profit or trading projections in the financial markets which happen to be wrong, it can be sued for false and misleading advertising in its prospectus. A private company carries out huge due diligence checks to make sure that it always conservatively understates what its trading and financial position will be.

If a private company put out a prospectus which stated that it was going to receive $1 billion when it got $161 million, that it was going to receive $625 million when it paid $300 million, that it was going to get $1.6 billion when it made $801 million, the ASC would be down into that company faster than we could say Henry Bosch. Three years in a row! The government, which is supposed to be enforcing this law and leading by example, is in exactly the same position.

The government does not take the responsibility for these budget figures that is expected of private companies operating in financial markets in Australia. The government's mismanagement and the reporting of that mismanagement should deservedly make it stand condemned. The government should put itself on an even footing with the standards that are expected by law, convention and morality in corporate Australia. This government stands absolutely condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they were company directors they would be off to gaol.

—If they were company directors they would either be off to gaol or heading for the sun in Spain by this stage. Perhaps the Treasurer, when he takes that next flight from Fremantle, might think about a flight going in the opposite direction, across to the Mediterranean.

PARA.TAB: Despite all of that failure in reporting, that failure in policy, that failure in the method of privatisation, that failure in relation to statutory controls, that failure in the whole way that it has been planned, the fact is that we actually support the privatisation of Qantas and Australian. We regret the fact that it has failed and failed so badly, but in the circumstances all we can say is that the investing public should not have to suffer because of the government's incompetence.

Neither the investing public nor the passengers should be let down because of the government's incompetence. They deserve a good service from a privatised company that is able to inject capital and to compete with the best in the world. So, in the circumstances, the legislation is necessary. But it is necessary only because of a regrettable failure in relation to the asset sales program, a regrettable failure in the accounting methods that are used to portray it, a regrettable failure in financial management, a regrettable failure in relation to the way it is treated in the books of accounts. But, despite all those regrettable failures, for the sake of the travelling public and the investing public, this bill becomes necessary.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). It has been a salutary lesson this morning in understanding those who come from the bar. Having been given a case to mount, irrespective of the facts, the honourable member's duty was to purvey a view of it. He has done that admirably. It does require a bit of straightening out. I am glad that the opposition is supporting the legislation and that we have consensus on the need for the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill to go through.

PARA.TAB: It is true that, when the government set forth the process for the Qantas float, it aimed for a date of 31 December this year. But the government said at the time that the float would depend upon the state of the financial markets, and the honourable member for Higgins knows that very well. The government said that, if there was a need to defer the float, it would defer it. So this legislation sets a later date. The legislation is also necessary to protect the position of employees in the organisation, their rights and entitlements and the ongoing operations of Qantas as an almost wholly publicly owned enterprise during the next two years.

I turn now to the reasons why the government is deferring the float. First, it was always evident that the float would be dependent upon the state of the stock market at the time and the demand on capital in the stock market. I will come to the reasons why the government decided on the float because the honourable member for Higgins did not touch on those reasons. The government's prime responsibility is to maximise the return, not to plug a hole in the deficit. It is to enable a capitalisation of the airline which has been acknowledged as necessary by everybody for the last 10 years. I will turn to that matter in a minute.

There have been three major changes in aviation policy in this country in the last five years. Let us look at decisions taken by this federal Labor government, a number of which could have been taken at any time in the previous 20 years by the conservatives when they were in power. The first and uppermost decision was to deregulate the domestic airline industry in Australia to bring about genuine competition between Ansett and Australian Airlines, or Qantas Australian as it is now known, and to open up options for other airlines to enter the fray.As a result of that single decision we have seen substantial investment by the airlines in new infrastructure. Regrettably, we have seen the coming and going of Compass but the introduction of competition produced substantial reductions in air fares and a remarkable variety in timetables and options for consumers that were not available before. Flowing from that we have now seen a further restructuring.

The first decision that we took and the one that set this whole process in motion was the decision to bring about competition in domestic aviation in Australia. The second decision that was taken was the decision to merge Qantas with Australian Airlines. For the first time a government said that it has never made any sense for two wholly owned government airlines not to have a working partnership with each other. Most people would say that the decision to enable Qantas to buy Australian Airlines and, by that process, merge was long overdue commonsense, and I would agree with that; it should have happened much earlier. But that merger has provided a dramatic strength for both government airlines in the lead-up to the public float of Qantas, which I will come to in a minute. It has given Australian Airlines an international partner to deal with.

The other change in aviation policy was to enable Ansett to take an international partner as well. Ansett is in the process of forming a partnership with a number of airlines. This is necessary for the health of our domestic airlines. It should be remembered that 80 per cent of air travel in Australia is by people flying on domestic airlines. It is necessary for them to have strategic relationships with the international airlines serving Australia. It made eminent sense for Qantas and Australian Airlines to merge.

Having done that, we come to the question: why are we floating Qantas? Why has the privatisation of Qantas been set in motion? It is not, as the honourable member for Higgins said, simply to raise money to plug a hole in the budget. It was done because the government's advice from the boards and the management of all of our airlines was that international aviation had changed. It has changed in the sense that each of the major carriers has now formed strategic alliances with various companies as part of global networks. To leave Qantas sitting out there by itself and not allowing it to take a substantial partner would have been grossly irresponsible because it would have simply shrunk; it would have been rolled over the top.

It was necessary to find Qantas a partner; and boy, did we find Qantas a partner. We found British Airways as the principal bidder prepared to take—not to buy Qantas, as some people have thought—a 25 per cent strategic exchange. That has given British Airways and Qantas, very interestingly, a complete global network. If we wander around to the Qantas travel agency in Parliament House and look at the latest product called `Global Explorer', we will see a brand new ticket option available through Qantas and British Airways which enables a person to go one way around the world for $2,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you tried it?

—I will be trying it; do not worry about that. It is a ripper of a set-up. It has come about completely because of the options that the merged airlines now have in their global network. Most interestingly, all that people can get at the moment from the Qantas travel agency is a photocopy of the new product, because people around Australia have grabbed every one of the brochures and Qantas is now photocopying them to get them out to people.
—I have a carton of them in the office.

—The honourable member should take them around to the agency and help them out. Of course, that was sensible. Why has the decision been taken to float? There are two key reasons. It was not taken because of some inane, Thatcherite privatisation policy because the private sector can do better, in order to flog the government assets and take the dough. In fact, the privatisation of Qantas was worked through the ALP national conference for two principal reasons: first, to enable the taking of the strategic partner, and that is what has happened with British Airways; secondly, there was a recognition that the airline could not continue to operate on borrowed funds.

PARA.TAB: Qantas's capital structure at the moment is such that its aircraft are paid for by borrowings. Many of its assets in airports around the world have been paid for by borrowings. It was necessary to inject capital into Qantas. The way to inject capital is either for the government to supply it, as the shareholder, or to float the airline and raise the capital on the stock markets from the people of Australia.

That is the key point. The key point behind the float was not to sell the airline to some multimillionaire who wants to own an airline or to half a dozen of them who want to form a consortium, but to run a float so that thousands of ordinary Australians can buy small shareholdings, as they did in the Commonwealth Bank float. That guarantees Qantas a dramatic market presence.

It is the same success formula used by British Airways in Britain and by Singapore Airlines in Singapore—to float to the citizens of the country of which the airline is the national carrier, to raise the capital, to reduce the debt, so that, instead of paying back interest, Qantas is investing in modern generation aircraft, new service facilities, improving its profit and improving the dividend to the shareholder. Those are the reasons. It is not, as was presented by Mr silver-tongued lawyer, the honourable member for Higgins, some kind of desperate grab by the government to raise some money to plug a budget hole; in fact it was done to capitalise the airline and give it the opportunity to expand, in the global network in its partnership with British Airways, as part of the world's premier aviation structure. The government is proud to have set this in place.

Why not float now? The simple reason is that there are a number of major floats going on in the Australian stock market. Woolworths recently completed a float. That was an interesting case and a highly successful one. The Commonwealth Bank at the moment is running another major float. It, too, will be an interesting and successful one.

Why would anybody in his or her right mind put a couple of billion dollars worth of Qantas shares into a market that is absorbing those shares when the government's prime responsibility is to achieve the highest possible return? We will wait until we believe the market is ready for the Qantas float. We will guarantee the owners of Qantas, the people of Australia, the best possible result from the capitalisation of Qantas. The honourable member for Higgins made a fair bit of the accounting of these matters. I agree with him on the surface. That is how lawyers like to present things—on the surface.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you a lawyer?

—I never have been, and I am proud to say that I never was one. Thank goodness! There are too many of them in here. Some hold the view that in normal accounting practice an asset is not sold and counted as revenue. Of course that is not done in normal company practice. But in government enterprises and in government budgets, not only in Australia but all around the world, capital expenditure appears as an outlay and as a revenue item. When we announced in the One Nation statement in January last year that there were $2.4 billion worth of capital works around Australia, nobody in the parliament said that investment in assets could not be counted as an outlay. Of course it is an outlay. When a government commits itself to capital works programs, it is counted in the outlays each year. When a government sells assets and draws the revenue in, it is counted in the revenue. Honourable members opposite know that; our lawyer friend may not understand it. Perhaps the opposition can talk to him about that issue later on and make sure that he understands it. It is a slick point, but it does not show much understanding of the government's budgetary process.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, this legislation represents a deferral of the float of Qantas. It is obvious that the government will wear some criticism of that, because it is true that the economy has not recovered as quickly as we had anticipated, and the market is not yet ready for the float in the form that we had anticipated. But in terms of the comments made by the honourable member for Higgins about the budgetary process and his nitpicking about whether the deficit represents 1.1 or 1.2 per cent of GDP in four years time, in my view that is pretty irrelevant. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has publicly demonstrated, without drawing any criticism to what he has had to say—and he has been to a number of significant international meetings and conferences with heads of state—that, by world scale, Australia is in probably the most favourable position as a country at which an investor would look.

Inflation is down in the very low single digit figures—not where those lot opposite left it, at over 10 per cent, double digit inflation. Interest rates are at the lowest levels for 30 years. They are back at the levels we were borrowing at when we were starting with our first homes, just as our kids are probably starting now. They are at very low levels by historical standards. This government has shown in its last cycle a commitment to investing in infrastructure projects to ensure that the value adding benefits are coming through the Australian economy now. The companies winning export markets will have the transport systems to deliver their products, the waterfront has been cleaned up, and airport structures have been invested in and fixed up. The airlines are servicing Australia in a way that has not been seen before. The tourist industry is focusing on Australia—and I have not even bothered to mention the potential of what is going to happen in the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Mabo.

—I will sidetrack to the Mabo issue for a minute. This country is taking the lead in the issue of the rights of indigenous people. Yesterday, I had visitors from Canada—a country widely renowned as a leader in this matter—and they were staggered by the efforts of the Australian government in taking the lead in the way that we have. The only thing holding us up is that lot on the other side with their fellow conservatives in Western Australia and Jeff Kennett in Victoria—God love him and save him.

PARA.TAB: The government is taking the lead on so many fronts—infrastructure, investment principles and inflation. We have a budget deficit of one, 1.1 or 1.2 per cent of GDP. The US budget deficit projected for four years time is three per cent of GDP. The Swedish budget deficit projected for four years time is five per cent of GDP. OECD economists are saying that Australia has got it right, with one exception.

That exception is at the heart of the thinking on this side of the parliament—unemployment. By world standards, our unemployment level is in about the middle of the range. A lot of countries are far worse off; nevertheless, we are not prepared to accept the current level. We have committed ourselves to getting the whole trifecta—low interest rates, low inflation, and low unemployment. They are the goals, and the goals by which we should be judged.

The opposition has come in here and totally misrepresented the float of Qantas, the budget strategy and the achievements of this country—achievements recognised and reflected internationally. The International Olympic Committee would not have given us the year 2000 games unless it thought the country could deliver. With all the presentations, analysis and investigation that goes into such a decision, no-one could possibly imagine that we would have been given the games if the IOC did not think we could deliver. Of course the IOC knows that we can deliver the games, just as we have delivered this major reform process—and, I have to say, it has all happened on this side of the House.

I hope my comments have given the parliament and the people of Australia a different and more rational perspective on the reasons for this proposed legislation. I hope I have put in perspective the reasons for the restructuring of Qantas and Australian Airlines, the positioning of the merged airline in the global network and its partnership with British Airways so that when the float does come the people of Australia will respond positively and will want a stake in their airline. I know that they will, and I support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Qantas Sale Amendment Bill is living proof of the old adage: if you want something stuffed up, get the government involved. Despite the words we have just heard from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe), the reality is that the whole process of the sale of Qantas has been a sad and sorry story from day one.

PARA.TAB: The real tragedy of the Qantas sale is simply that we are about five years behind the times now and blowing out to seven years. If the parliamentary secretary really looked at the situation, he would see that the optimum time to have floated Qantas was undoubtedly in 1988-89 when the airline was in a very difficult situation, the economy was bubbling along and there was money to be had in a boom time. The fact that we have had deferral after deferral means that we have missed the boat for optimising the effect that Qantas could have in a world sense.

I do not say that lightly because presently most airlines are in deep recession, there are no yields and, while passenger numbers are up, nobody is making any money. We have a situation where there are attempts to form global alliances and where the biggest aviation nation in the world, the United States, is looking at ways of saving a crippled industry. In this country, we have an airline grossly disadvantaged by the government's failure to go ahead with the privatisation.

The parliamentary secretary is quite right: one of the great tragedies was that Qantas was undercapitalised for years. It was the fault of people on both sides of this House that Qantas was never really given that chance. For years Qantas has been begging for privatisation so that it can get out in the market and build itself up into a real global force. While the opposition is not opposing this bill, and while I think there is probably a realisation now that this is not the time to float, the real tragedy is that we have fallen behind the times.

I would like to make a couple of comments about the world situation on aviation at the moment because it is really quite interesting. President Clinton's commission on the whole of the aviation industry causes me some concern, because I think we are going to look toward a retraction of the American attitude towards international rights, and we will see a more protectionist attitude from the United States. A similar thing is happening with European airlines now. At the moment, discussions are being held on the possibility of the formation of a major European aviation bloc. What happens if we go off the whole area of bilateral negotiations for aviation rights and we move into a multilateral situation, and we have these blocs banging their heads against each other?

In our part of the world, the Asia-Pacific region—which is going to be the largest growing aviation sector—a couple of things could well happen. I think the Japanese, for example, will probably be strong enough to stand up on their own and take the blocs on. The ASEAN countries could well form their own bloc. If we have not got our act together, we are going to be stuck as the tail at the end of the world, with not very much say in how things go on at all. I say that notwithstanding the fact that we now have this alliance, or part-ownership, with British Airways. In Australia we have to make some very quick and tough decisions as to how we are going to play that future aviation policy.

The advent of the British Airways acquisition of 25 per cent of Qantas stock has helped, and there have been some advantages in getting that alliance into place. But that is not the be all and end all. We have to be very careful that we are not squeezed out into being part of the end of the line of world aviation and miss some of the opportunities that are going to be available for some of these big conglomerates.

There was one thing that the parliamentary secretary did not mention in terms of the so-called achievements of government aviation policy, and that is what is going on at the moment with the deregulation of the trans-Tasman area. That is supposed to be in place now. The advent of that common market over the Tasman has some enormous advantages. It has even more enormous advantages if we can spread it out a bit and look towards a south-west Pacific bloc, or group, being formed. That has advantages for us, and it has some real advantages for the small Pacific island states. We should be looking at this area.

We have to be fully cognisant of the fact that we now do have some international competition in terms of the international aviation services. The IASC's awarding of international rights to Ansett is ultimately going to have advantages. But, even that has been a bit late. It has come at a time when Ansett has had its own financial problems. Ansett is going through a period of recapitalisation so that it can service some of the routes that it has been granted.

There is a real worry in some sectors of the aviation industry that Qantas may be disadvantaged. I do not believe that is necessarily so. With the growth that we are going to see in aviation in the Asia-Pacific region over the next decade, there are going to be quite a few opportunities if we get our act together and go in there and plough that market. There will be opportunities for both Ansett and the Qantas group to do particularly well. We are really heartened by some of the projections on the growth of tourism in the Asia-Pacific region. The world tourism organisation is talking about 140 million Asian people travelling offshore on annual leave by the year 2000. If Australia can get one per cent of that business, the international airlines operating in and out of Australia are going to have to triple their capacity. We must look very seriously at the future direction of our aviation policy over the next decade.

I mentioned that I believe the physical privatisation of Qantas should have happened five years ago. Qantas would have been in a much better position now if that had been the case. While there are some very great advantages in bringing Qantas and Australian Airlines together as one entity, that in itself has probably put even longer delays in the privatisation process reaching its optimum.

When the British Overseas Airways Corporation and British European Airways decided to amalgamate in the early 1970s, it took about seven or eight years before the two airlines really came together. At the moment there are difficulties in bringing Qantas and Australian Airlines together. Much has been achieved so far, but it is still not all a bed of roses. It is going to take quite a bit of settling down. I am a little concerned for the worth of the Qantas-Australian group if we cannot really get that together.

The parliamentary secretary referred to Mrs Thatcher just flogging off the airline, but the story of British Airways was quite an amazing one. It was a moribund monster that very few people seemed to want to fly with. I think the general attitude in Australia was that BOAC stood for `better on a camel', rather than an airline, and people tried to avoid it. The year before privatisation BOAC had losses of about #276 million. Within 12 to 18 months of privatisation it was turned around to a highly profitable airline, and one of the most successful in the world.

The pure reasons for privatisation were present there, but one of the great successes of British Airways privatisation was that optimum staff share ownership was ensured. The airline was opened up and the staff were brought in and involved. Almost overnight, when the staff became shareholders, there was a complete change of attitude. The staff knew that the service that they were providing was going to determine whether they were going to get a decent return on their shares for that particular year. Somebody from British Airways—who will remain nameless—told me that one of the difficulties was that it could never get its staff to retire; they were shareholders, it was their business and they were going to stay there.

I hope that, when Qantas is 100 per cent privatised, we make maximum staff ownership an essential of the Australian operation, because that is one of the secrets of it. We have some lessons to learn from the trans-Tasman business. One of the great successes in our part of the world has been the privatisation of Air New Zealand. Air New Zealand is not a big company in world aviation terms at all, but the difference in that operation after privatisation was really quite outstanding. Whilst airlines around the world are announcing vastly reduced profits, or huge losses, in its last year of operation Air New Zealand came out with a profit in excess of $NZ100 million. Many of the silly work practices were improved under privatisation, the airline was capitalised properly, and innovative management came in.

The Air New Zealand operation now is quite outstanding in some of the things it has done. We do not have to be frightened of this—it should be encouraged because it is very much to Australia's advantage—but there is an argument about whether Australia gave New Zealand too much in allowing it to pick up passengers in Australia and fly beyond. This was part of the deal made when trying to get the aviation market into place. The reality is that a privatised, innovative and entrepreneurial Air New Zealand took that with both hands and is doing extremely well with it. Examples are its traffic from Taipei into Brisbane and on to Auckland and the fact that it has already identified the Korean and Thailand markets as areas to plough. It has been very smart.

I just hope that once Qantas is fully privatised the same entrepreneurial spirit will develop. Qantas has some tremendous advantages over a small airline such as Air New Zealand and could do quite well. One of Qantas's real difficulties is that, until it can be 100 per cent privatised, it will have its old culture. That must change if the airline is to optimise its opportunities.

Another reason privatisation should have happened five years ago lies in what has happened to Qantas in the interim. Partly because of the policies of this government, particularly with salary caps, wage freezes and deals done through union agreements with the accord—it is a real tragedy—there was a decision not to allow any increases in salaries for technical staff. We had the amazing situation a few years ago of Qantas having to take its maintenance offshore and have companies such as United Airlines, Aer Lingus and Japan Airlines do a lot of its servicing, because we lost a lot of our great technical expertise.

When wages were frozen it was quite easy for aircraft maintenance people to get Qantas engineers and technical staff to work in such places as Hong Kong for huge amounts of money. Qantas then employed Chinese maintenance people from Hong Kong to work here. It was a very sad period of Australian aviation history when that was allowed to happen. Qantas assured me that if it had been a private company at the time that would not have happened. In fact, Ansett was able to keep its staff; but Qantas had to abide by government provisions.

Over the last few years government caps have curtailed the amount of money that could be paid to people appointed as chief executive officers to Qantas. There are classic tales of Qantas CEOs being offered sums of $135,000 to $150,000 a year when the chief executive officers of some American airlines were being paid $2 million a year—and $800,000 a year was not an odd figure around the Asia-Pacific rim. Despite all the disadvantages that Qantas has had over the years of being a government owned instrumentality, in many respects it has done a lot better than many would have thought possible.

I hope the government is right, in terms of maximising the value of that airline, in deferring the sale process for an additional two years. The two years will give an opportunity for the amalgamation of Australian Airlines and Qantas to settle down. One would hope the world situation will improve so that yields on the international scene will allow some profitability. I repeat the hope that when we finally see Qantas sold off and a fully privatised Qantas emerge there will be an optimum availability of shares for staff to make sure Qantas can best meet its potential. The tragedy is that this did not happen five years ago and that we have missed out on some of the great advantages that privatisation could have given Qantas. We hope that the decision that we all make here today—we are not opposing this legislation—will allow Qantas to achieve optimum value as soon as possible and allow Qantas to rule its own life and maintain its position as one of the great airlines of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1993. I heard some of the comments of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) earlier. He was ranting and raving in his criticism of the delay in the public sale of Qantas, with a constant reference to the failure to float Qantas. Anybody with any knowledge of the international aviation industry would understand what the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who has just resumed his seat, has said: the state of the international aviation industry is such that it is not a good time to publicly float an airline.
—That is why you should have done it five years ago.

—The honourable member for Bradfield said that it should have been done five years ago. I have listened to the words of the honourable member for Fadden and the honourable member for Bradfield over the years about Qantas. In making these comments now, they are shedding crocodile tears. Over the years their attitude and expressions consistently have been anti an Australian international airline industry. They would have flogged off anything and everything they could, had they been in government. Hearing them evincing concern about Qantas is a new experience for me. It is the first time we have heard that. Their comments are crocodile tears. It would be irresponsible to be pushing to float Qantas in the current international aviation climate.

PARA.TAB: Earlier speakers, and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) in his second reading speech, made the point that the government's decision to reschedule the float of Qantas to 1994-95 was made on the basis of advice from financial consultants and the department. The international airline industry is depressed. There is a responsibility to taxpayers—to all Australians—to ensure that there is a maximum return to Australians as a whole, and to government, from the float of Qantas. The other need for the legislation is to ensure that we protect the rights of Qantas employees, given that the existing act provided for that during the transitional period.

I take the opportunity to pay tribute to the former chief executive of Qantas, John Ward. He led that organisation through trying and difficult times. He steered it through the challenging task of restructuring the organisation and through the amalgamation with Australian Airlines. He has to be given credit for the considerable productivity growth over recent years from that restructuring.

He had the extremely difficult task of amalgamating a major domestic airline with Qantas, which is oriented internationally. Both airlines fly aeroplanes and have pilots, but the equipment was different, their sales markets were different and their maintenance equipment was different. Whilst considerable benefits can be gained from having one large organisation, the task of going through the process of amalgamation is difficult. Qantas is a multibillion dollar business. In that business, John Ward carried out the hands-on task of the amalgamation.

Qantas carried on over many years the hands-on task of promoting Australia when it was not fashionable to do so. In effect, for many years the only promotion of Australia outside Australia was carried on by Qantas advertising and promoting its services and Australia as a destination. I share the view of the honourable member for Fadden that this multibillion dollar business has been undercapitalised for years by successive governments. That has always been a problem and it comes from the Sir Humphreys in this place and their own policy that there ought not to be a role for public sector enterprises. They achieved that result over the years of denying capital or providing advice that results in those kinds of decisions, despite the best efforts of ministers, whoever they may have been.

That is something that that organisation has had to struggle with. It resulted in the organisation having to carry a debt servicing burden that, in normal commercial circumstances, would not have been there to be serviced. So I wish Mr Ward well in whatever career he adopts in the years ahead. He has made a major contribution to the development of Qantas and to Australia's international airline services.

I also have a concern that the participation of British Airways in Qantas must result in a significant improvement and a significant benefit to Australia and to Qantas. The acquisition of the 25 per cent shareholding by BA in Qantas should not result in the tail wagging the dog. BA's reputation for brashness and for pushiness is well known around the world. If we look at some of the media companies, we find that a 15 per cent shareholding can be seen as having a controlling interest or a major influential interest.

In this case, there is a 25 per cent shareholding in Australia's flag carrier. The management of Qantas, its board, this government and future governments will have to be vigilant and firm to ensure that that shareholding by BA—welcome as it is—proves to be of benefit to Australia and to Qantas, and that the tail does not start to wag the dog so that Qantas then becomes simply a subsidiary of British Airways in management terms. The subsequent sale of the remainder of Qantas, together with BA's 25 per cent shareholding, should give Qantas the financial capacity to combat the growing consolidation of international airlines and the intense competition that exists and that lies ahead.

We are looking at an international airline market into this country in which the top 10 carriers in the year to May 1993 carried 83 per cent of the passengers. So, in that kind of market, it is likely to further consolidate to fewer major players. It is a tough market, and in that market we have to make sure that Qantas is operating as an organisation in the best interests of Australia and not of foreign shareholders.

When we look at the market we see that, in the year ended May 1993, almost 10 million international passengers came into Australia. The top 10 carriers I referred to carried 83 per cent of that total passenger market. This is down a little on the previous year ending May 1992 of 83.6 per cent, but within those figures we see considerable improvements in traffic into Australia. Overall, 9.67 million passengers came into or went out.

The growth on the routes, such as the Los Angeles-Sydney route, is to be qualified a little because there is some doubt about the accuracy of the figures. But it is reasonable enough to say that it was in the order of a 22 per cent increase in the year ended May 1992. The Honolulu-Sydney route had an increase of 31.1 per cent, partly because of the withdrawal of American carriers. Again, those figures are subject to later confirmation but they would be pretty much the order of the day. If we look at the figures for air traffic, with the exception of the Tokyo-Sydney and Auckland-Melbourne routes, we can see growth and improvement in all those figures and overall an increase of some 7.1 per cent.

I want to go back to the appropriateness of the time of floating Qantas. We are in a period of intensive international airline competition. It is tough times in the industry, and we look at national reports of what is happening in the international airline industry. We look to Europe. `Crisis for European airlines' is one headline I am looking at. Another headline in the Economist is `Losing their way'. It states:

Like vapour trails across the sky, the tangle that airlines have got themselves into seems never-ending. There may be a way to unravel their problems. But because airlines are battered and weary from the industry's worst-ever decline, there is a danger that the opportunity will be missed.

SPEECH.PARA: That statement is referring essentially to the European airlines but, with their connections into the market we are operating, it has significance for us. We need also to remember that the major international airline travel market—particularly into Europe—still has not recovered from the Gulf War and it is being succeeded by the world recession. So trade is extremely difficult.

PARA.TAB: Then, if we look across to the Asian scene, we see that the Asian airlines are going to have to look to how efficiently they operate their businesses and the fact that yield in those airlines is going down, not going up. In relation to Asian airline routes, the former chief of Taiwan's China Airlines used to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Intercontinental—
meaning intercontinental airline services—
is for show, regional is for making dough.

That goes to the point that many national flag carriers operate for reasons quite unrelated to commercial success or to commercial profit. An international flag carrier is a national show piece. It is their shop window, and they have to have an international airline. But the comment `intercontinental is for show, regional is for making dough'—regional being Asia—succinctly describes the practice and the situation within the industry.

PARA.TAB: If we turn to what is happening in the case of Cathay Pacific, we see that it is particularly concerned about the declining yields in international air services. The Managing Director said:

SPEECH.PARA: Unless yields improve, the industry is just not viable. If the decline in yields goes into 1994, some regional carriers—
Asian carriers—
will move into the red.

We see in the figures for the year ended 31 March last, Japan Airlines—JAL—had a pre-tax loss of some $US496 million. So Asian airlines overall—our growing market, our growing area of activity and a growing focus for Qantas—are finding it increasingly difficult. Yields are dropping, the number of passengers is increasing but the demand that is burgeoning for airline seats is almost all for heavily discounted, economy class seats, and the business and first-class travel have not picked up appreciably since the Gulf War of early 1991.

PARA.TAB: I suppose we could say that it is a bit like carrying more passengers for less profit or for profitless prosperity. There is another way of describing it, and that is to refer to it as carrying passengers for practice. They carry more passengers but are making less money out of it. If we look at the performance of Qantas—I have tried to describe something of the market and the way the market is operating, the depressed state that it is in, that profitless prosperity—and look at the top 10 profit-making airlines of the world in 1992, at the top of that list was Cathay Pacific with $US391 million; British Airways with $US309.8 million; China Airways, with $US143.3 million; Thai Airways with $US120.4 million; and Qantas is ranked fifth with $US106.6 million. These are the 1992 figures.

Five of the top profit-making airlines were Asian airlines but, if we turn to the top 10 loss makers, five of them were United States airlines, and I will come to the United States in a few minutes. Five of the top 10 loss makers in the world were US airlines, headed by Delta Air Lines with a loss of $US564.8 million; American Airlines, $US475 million; United Airlines, $US417 million; Northwest Airlines, $US405.1 million; and the US Air Group, $US404.1 million. Down the bottom of the chart is Japan Airlines with an after tax loss of $US349.3 million.

That leads me to the situation with regard to the US airlines. We see from those figures that five of the top 10 loss makers in the international airline business are US airlines. US airlines and the US government have been putting enormous pressure upon Australia to lay down and allow US airlines to intrude in Australian routes, the Australia-Japan route particularly. In my view, that approval should never have been given to Northwest Airlines, but that is the personal opinion of one member of this House.

Now the US airlines have the device, through chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, to run up their debt and then seek virtually a moratorium from all of that debt. Under chapter 11 bankruptcy they can step aside from that debt, go back into the market with a much lower cost structure and further set about eroding the market. In that process, they then take on the very bullyboy kind of approach we saw in the recent negotiations between Australia and the US in respect of the Northwest route from Sydney to Osaka and then to the United States.

That behaviour by the US is not new. At the end of World War II the United States and the United Kingdom virtually carved up the world airline market between them. The US has been negotiating on and off with the Japanese government over many years trying to address what the Japanese see as the unequal US-Japan air service agreement, an agreement drawn up at the time of General MacArthur which heavily favoured the United States. I find it quite repulsive that the United States government is talking about friends and economies working together when in the context of the airline market it is really looking to prop up the cash flow of ailing US airlines.

There is a very nice caption that describes the US airline industry: `Lean, mean, and frequently bankrupt'. I think that is the best description we can give it. Through chapter 11, whereby the airlines are able to set aside the debts that they have incurred, walk away from them, and come back in again with a much lower debt burden to handle, they can get away with this sort of intrusion onto the market.

It is clear that Asian airlines—when I say Asian airlines, that means Qantas—and this government have to be alert to ensure that we are not subject to the piracy of the US government and the US airlines trying to prop up bad commercial decisions, bad management in the case of those US airlines, and trying to protect their interests. When we look to the negotiations that are yet to come forward in respect of Australia, Osaka and the United States we will need to ensure that Australia's interests are fully protected because, as we look to an increasing and improving international airline climate, the return from the public float of Qantas will be greater.

As I said, this legislation is based on two things: one is to float off the rest of Qantas in a much more favourable airlines climate and the other is to protect the rights of Qantas employees because the sale has not proceeded according to the original timetable. I fully support the legislation. The objective here is to protect the interests of Australia, Australian taxpayers and Australian citizens and to get the maximum return for the airline. It is not good enough to say, `You should have done this years ago'. I said in my opening remarks that the opposition was crying crocodile tears this morning. I want to see Australia's interests protected, that we maximise the return and, most importantly, that British Airways does not become the tail wagging the dog in respect of Australia's national flag carrier.

I want to mention one last matter and that is my disappointment in seeing Qantas involved in the row over the Burmese, or Myanmar, seafarers from the vessel Angelic Faith, which was tied up in Dalrymple Bay in Queensland last month. Those seafarers had been underpaid some $200,000. Negotiations resulted in those seafarers being paid their money. But on their way to Bangkok the seafarers were taken off a flight, obviously with the agreement of Qantas, and sent back to Rangoon rather than to Bangkok.

Those of us who were involved in the ship safety inquiry and the Ships of shame report know only too well that Burmese seafarers are exploited, impoverished, intimidated and forced into signing contracts that no-one for a moment would possibly contemplate in this country. They were taken off a Qantas flight at Singapore on its way to Bangkok where they were to start a new life. The company involved in that was the Star Corporation Shipping Company, and that company ought to be standing up very clearly and accepting responsibility for the infamy that has occurred in respect of those seafarers.

I mention that in passing. It is not a matter germane to the nature of the bill, but I take the opportunity to mention that and to concern the company involved—the Star Corporation Shipping Company—which I understand is a Greek shipping company. That is the sort of intimidation and exploitation that is taking place in respect of seafarers on some ships operating into this country. I support the bill and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very useful debate on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill. I have listened with great interest to the comments by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris), both of whom know a considerable amount about transport. What they have both had to say in this debate I think adds to the knowledge of the House.

PARA.TAB: I was, therefore, rather concerned and surprised that the honourable member for Shortland should take such great exception to my suggestion that, had this debate taken place five years ago, leading to the privatisation of Qantas some five years earlier than is expected, many of the problems facing that company and the government in terms of its privatisation schedule, the funding and the support to the budget which it is meant to achieve would obviously have been significantly less. The honourable member for Shortland seems to forget that he has been a member of a government that has been in power now for nearly 11 years. The government has had plenty of time to develop a worthwhile and constructive privatisation program which should have included Qantas, which should have been sold at a time when the international civil aviation environment was significantly better than it is today.

The honourable member for Shortland is perfectly correct to make the point that internationally, and by extension nationally, civil aviation is going through a period of intense competition and a fierce price-cutting war around the globe. We do not know at this stage what the outcome of that will be but, as he rightly says, one thing is clear: most international carriers are running at a loss. Most American international carriers are broke but, because of the strange nature of their bankruptcy law, they are able to set aside their debts and continue to compete on international markets despite their lack of fundamental financial viability. When we consider this in the context of Qantas and its privatisation some very important questions need to be asked and answered. What are Qantas's prospects of making a profit? I am reliably informed that this calendar year it is anticipated there will be a small profit. It is also anticipated that the Australian Airlines component will do better next year than it has done this year or last year. That is well and good.

However, when we see Qantas in the context of its international profile, the situation is both complicated and difficult. Internationally, there is massive overcapacity of all airlines right around the globe. All European carriers, except British Airways, are losing enormous sums of money. All US carriers are also in a loss situation. In Asia, in the Asia-Pacific region in particular, even Japan Airlines is losing money, and it has the added problem of having high yen based costs.

Cathay Pacific and Singapore Airlines are at this stage still operating at a profit. Thai Airways International is breaking even. We do not know the circumstances facing Garuda Indonesia Airlines. We know that Philippine Airlines is losing money. We do not know the circumstances relating to China Airways. Malaysian Airlines is still profitable, although it has purchased a significant number of new aircraft which must be paid for and will add to the problem of overcapacity. Finally, Air New Zealand, in which Qantas has a significant shareholding, is also profitable, as was mentioned by both the previous speakers, the honourable members for Fadden and Shortland. In fact, last year it made a profit in excess of $100 million.

Consequently, the whole question of the privatisation of Qantas must be seen in the context of an aggressive timetable. The timetable must involve the linkage of Qantas and Australian Airlines, which, as I said, is proceeding despite all the difficulties associated with such a linkage between an international carrier on the one hand and a domestic carrier on the other, including the need to relate the fleets of the two airlines, some of the aircraft of which are not necessarily compatible. Of course, the Australian Airlines component will see the sale of a number of its aircraft over the next year or so, again depending on the capacity of the international market to absorb those aircraft.

What about the forward sale? What exactly does it mean now in the context of this legislation where we see the government yet again having to go back on its earlier decisions and reschedule the sale of the remaining 75 per cent of Qantas? Politically, of course, one obviously takes the opportunity in a circumstance such as this to say that this is yet another backflip on the privatisation of the airline, a privatisation which was originally guaranteed by the government in 1990. Here we are in 1993 and we are changing the arrangements yet again.

It is worth noting that last May the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) told parliament that the sale would go ahead in October-November this year or in April-May next year. But now we are being told, in the context of this legislation, that the Qantas sale will be deferred until 1994-95. This latest delay does follow, despite everything that the honourable member for Shortland has said, a long list of postponements, muddles, date changes and rule changes which have plagued the sale ever since it was originally conceived back in September 1990.

Consequently, I stand by every word I have uttered. This whole program should have been brought to the parliament five years ago when the economic environment, both domestically and internationally, was substantially more beneficial for the sale of an Australian asset, estimated now at some $2 billion, the sale of which under those circumstances would undoubtedly have been much easier than is presently the case.

The whole question of the sale of Qantas in 1994-95 is totally underpinned by a hope. In all frankness, at this stage that it is all it is, a hope. The government is pinning its hopes on an upturn in international aviation markets by that time. But, if it is wrong, what will happen? Will we come back here yet again for another change of legislation, another set of amendments, or will the government put Qantas on the block and sell it at bargain basement prices? I sincerely hope that no-one in this House would suggest that that would be an adequate answer. But much must be done in the meantime.

The point was made by both previous speakers, the honourable member for Shortland and honourable member for Fadden, that Qantas for a long time has been severely undercapitalised. In fact, even now, despite recent changes, the deficit-equity ratio is still at some 70:30. I must admit that is an improvement on the 80:20 ratio of debt which we had only 12 months ago, but I think that it does demonstrate the tightness of the financial environment in which Qantas is trying to operate. What are the timings looking to the future? As I said, clearly November 1994 is possible, April 1995 is likely, but obviously anything before that under current circumstances appears to be unviable.

Qantas bought Australian Airlines and paid $400 million to the Commonwealth. British Airways bought a 25 per cent interest in Qantas and paid $625 million to the Commonwealth. The outcome of this was that the Commonwealth took a $1.3 billion debt off Qantas, which is equivalent to putting cash in. Honourable members should not forget what I said: we are dealing with an organisation which has been severely undercapitalised for far too long.

All the debt Qantas still has is government guaranteed. That is an important factor in the context of privatisation. Qantas initiated a $1.3 billion government assured debt which is mainly short-term commercial. It involves 90-day rollovers, but it has a credit rating based on this government guarantee. But that debt must be repaid before the Qantas float; in other words, before the end of 1994-95. That again will depend on the capacity of Qantas to be able to compete in the current economic environment and in a very tight internationally competitive situation.

Qantas has a new credit policy. It has $550 million in US denominations, which have been issued. It has 850 million MTNs, also in US denominations, again to be issued up to $200 million. It is expected that this will be largely commercial paper with a bank facility behind it. All of that must be in place, and I understand it will be, by the end of October 1993, although the original timetable was somewhat earlier. There is also a further bond issue of $300 million which has been completed. So the refinancing of Qantas in a relatively short period will be critically important to the methodology of the privatisation program and the impact that will have on the debt ratios and the price which the market will perceive as being appropriate for Qantas shares.

The MTNs which I referred to are over a fairly long period, some 12 to 13 years, but commercial paper, which has some 90 days effectively, with a three-year bank facility can be interpreted as long-term debt. I mentioned earlier the sale of aircraft from the Australian Airlines fleet. There are four Airbuses to be sold late in 1994. Again we do not know what the international market will be for second-hand aircraft at that time.

The point was also made by my colleague the honourable member for Fadden about engineering skills. It is quite true that Qantas has built up considerable engineering skills in recent years, despite the fact that this government only a few years ago allowed Qantas to effectively export its engineering requirements and, to a large degree, close down its skills base in this country, again because it argued—with some justification—that the costs of employing staff in Australia to do that work were not competitive with overseas cost structures.
