Nevertheless, it is now doing maintenance work for Chinese, Malaysian and South Pacific airlines.

It must not be forgotten that Air New Zealand, in which Qantas has a share, also has engineering capacity. Our current labour rates and our award arrangements, even in the context of Air New Zealand, make Qantas uncompetitive internationally. Therefore, in the context of international competitiveness the question of Australia's labour rates and our industrial relations policy overall is of fundamental importance to determine whether by 1995 Qantas will be on a sound base to not only privatise itself but on a basis which will make it worth while.

We have to see a creditable financial improvement during 1993-94, and it is generally believed in the money markets that that level of profit must be in the range of at least $150 million. Hopefully, the outcome will be better by 1994-95 when it will need to be in the range of $400 million to make it a creditable proposition in the context of its assets base and the total Qantas package which it offers the market.

In addition, it is worth noting that Qantas has some $300 million-plus in tax credits which must also be used up before Qantas shareholders can be offered franked dividends. The biggest difficulty is the market where the mums and dads of Australia are actually interested in the prospects of buying shares in Woolworths and other companies, including the Commonwealth Bank which has been on the market with another share tranche coming up very soon. The question arises as to what extent Qantas will be seen as a good growth stock. I emphasise the word `growth'.

With all the will in the world, in the foreseeable future Qantas is not likely to be marketed as a major dividend earner in the short to medium term. People will be buying it because it is Australia's flag carrier; people will be buying it because they want to have a piece of international civil aviation action; people will be buying it because they think to some degree it is the right thing to do as an Australian. But I think it is important to remember that while it will have potential for growth, all else being equal, it is not likely to be a major dividend earner in the foreseeable future.

There are a few comments in relation to this legislation which I want to make. The bill before the House today is essential for the sale of Qantas because it amends the Qantas Sale Act to take account of the deferral of the Qantas sale, the details of which I have already noted. As I said, it is really five years too late.

It is interesting to note that when the Minister for Finance told parliament the sale would proceed it took him seven weeks to issue a press release saying that it would be deferred until 1994-95. Subsequently, there have been media reports and recriminations by the asset sales task force, which has claimed that Qantas misled it over the airline's budget projections. Qantas has defended its profit projections, claiming that it has always said they were volatile. From my discussions with Qantas and from the evidence contained in my presentation to the House today, I think its case is self-evident.

The Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1993 postpones the date on which provisions of the sale act of 1992 are automatically repealed from December this year to 30 June 1995. Do not forget that we are talking about a lot of money. We are talking about the sale of a major Australian asset at an anticipated value of some $2 billion.

On the assumption that the Qantas float would take place in 1993, the original act provided for unproclaimed sections to be automatically repealed if not enacted by 31 December of this year. Consequently, the government's deferral of the Qantas float until 1994-95 means that any provisions of the original act not commenced by the end of 1993 will be repealed automatically and not extended by this amendment bill. Without the bill, the deferral of the Qantas public share offering would mean the automatic repeal on 31 December this year of the 50 per cent and the 100 per cent sale day provisions in the principal act. The government claims that these provisions relate to Qantas employees—in fact, this was the point made in the second reading speech—and said how retaining accrued benefits and being removed from the ambit of legislation governing Commonwealth employees post-sale was significant in the terms of this amending legislation.

This raises the question which was raised by my colleague the honourable member for Fadden—namely, that of the maximum staff share ownership. I totally endorse what my colleague said. International evidence, and domestic evidence in other cases, shows quite clearly that where the shareholding can be maximised in the hands of those who work for a corporation, automatically they have a commitment to its success which usually results in a better bottom line than is achieved in a situation where there are simply paid employees with no emotional connection with their employer. Therefore, in the final formula of the sale contract the opposition would like to see the employees of Qantas and Australian Airlines—which then of course will be one corporation—given every opportunity to maximise their ownership in this extremely important Australian asset.

In his second reading speech, the Minister for Finance claimed that the government's major concern in introducing this amendment was the preservation of Qantas employee entitlements. But this is only part of the story. In fact, without the amendment bill many other provisions relating to the progressive transfer of Qantas from the government to the private sector would also lapse and therefore, for technical reasons, there was no choice but to go ahead with this amending legislation. However, as I said initially, it is yet another instance in the long list of postponements, muddles, date changes and rule changes which have plagued the Qantas sale since it was finally decided on way back in 1990.

In regard to the government's overall asset sales, I seek the permission of the House to incorporate in Hansard a media release which shows that over the last five years Labor's asset sales program has failed to live up to its expectations. In fact, Labor's cumulative projections on asset sales total $5 billion. It has delivered less than $3 billion, leaving a $2.25 billion credibility gap with the obvious impact on the budget.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: "The fact is that Labor's track record on privatisation has been abysmal. The sales of Qantas, a substantial part of ANL Ltd and the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation were all expected to be completed in 1992-93, but have not been. In fact the bulk of the Government's 1992-93 asset sales program simply did not happen.
"The following table shows how for the last 5 years Labor's asset sales program hasn't lived up to expectations.

"Labor's cumulative projections on asset sales totalled $5b. It has delivered less than $3b—leaving a $2.25b credibility gap. No doubt in this year's Budget Labor will continue to reannounce asset sales it was meant to have completed in previous years.
SYDNEY 4 August 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt, as we have seen in this year's budget, Labor will continue to reannounce asset sales. The government will continue to put forward items which it intends to sell. But the shortfall in achieving its objectives over the period 1988 right through to 1992-93 gives the House very little room for optimism that they will be achieved in this financial year, and leaves considerable room for scepticism that the government really knows what it is trying to do in terms of its privatisation program. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a healthy sign that the government is now inserting sunset clauses in legislation. In Australia, as in many other parts of the world, we tend to drown in a sea of legislation. Quite often a lot of this legislation has existed on the statute books for a very long period of time and, for all intents and purposes, is a dead letter.

PARA.TAB: But in this case, when the government originally brought in the Qantas Sales Act 1992 it did seek to bring a discipline upon itself to force it to complete the intentions of the legislation within certain finite time periods. Perhaps it was also intended to be used as a whip against the Labor Party factions to make sure that they did not intrude to frustrate the laudable, though belated, aims of the bill which sought to return Qantas to private ownership. The principal amendment is to subsection 2(6) of the act which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If a provision of this Act has not commenced before 31 December 1993, the provision is taken to have been repealed on that day.

That was the discipline which the government now seeks to ask the parliament to extend. For various reasons, some of which have been outlined by previous speakers, parts of the principal act have not come into effect and unless this bill is carried here, and indeed in another place, the privatisation will not proceed completely. The government has therefore sought to ask our assistance to bail it out of a hole.

PARA.TAB: On this side of the House, we know government is a necessary evil. We ought always to ensure that government is kept to the absolute minimum degree possible. Our philosophy in the Liberal and National parties is to support free enterprise and, as a general rule, we consider that government ought not to be running enterprises in competition with the private sector.

One has only to look at the very long list of financial disasters which have resulted from various government activities—particularly state Labor government activities—and from their very many largely failed attempts to be entrepreneurial in the marketplace. I think it is a truism that governments cannot be as efficient as the private sector and thus we support the privatisation of Qantas, which really ought to be seen as returning to the Australian people the right to own some shares in a very important national enterprise.

In the past, the government, with its slavish adherence to its former socialist philosophy, used to consider that privatisation was, in effect, depriving the Australian people of important assets. The reverse is of course the case. If we were gullible in looking at the legislation which was brought in in 1992, we could consider initially that the government had been converted to our philosophy. Perhaps some people might have suggested that the government had become a latter-day St Paul on the road to Damascus. But the reality is that the proposed sale of Qantas does the right thing for the wrong reason.

Since the 13 March election, we have read and heard about the absolute financial hole into which the Labor Party has put Australia over more than 10 years in office. We know how absolutely desperate it is for funds. We know what a disaster the Australian economy is. Therefore, we ought to see the Qantas sale legislation for what it really is—an attempt to obtain money, a money grab to reduce the budget deficit.

Clearly, when one sells off assets that money ought to be used to reduce debt. It is totally wrong for that money to be used for the purposes of recurrent expenditure, as the government intends. I repeat: asset sales should be used to reduce debt. The government's actions now are akin to a farmer flogging off the family farm, failing to discharge his debts to the bank and then blowing the proceeds on a holiday. The net result of the government's actions is the debt remains and it has to be paid by our children and our grandchildren. That is one of the great crosses that this generation and this government will have to bear.

In his contribution the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) pointed out that, once the proceeds from the sale of Qantas disappear into the bottomless pit of the government's deficit, the government will look around for other public enterprises to privatise. Of course, we on this side of the House strongly support privatisation; but, once again, the government will seek to rob Peter to pay Paul. As the honourable member for Higgins said, Telecom will undoubtedly be one of the first cabs off the rank. Although the Telecom employees strongly supported the Labor government prior to the 13 March election, it will be interesting to see how they react to a proposed imminent sale by Labor of Telecom.

Qantas is a great company. All Australians should take pride in what Qantas has achieved. However, it should also be appreciated that, because Qantas has been a government airline, it has been forced to be responsive to government policy which has prevented it from competing properly in the marketplace. For example, in the area of foreign policy, this government has used Qantas as a tool. It forced Qantas to open direct air links with Zimbabwe. While I am certainly not opposed to air links with that country, most people at the time would not have considered that as a profitable route. Qantas, therefore, was compelled to make losses as part of the government's political agenda.

Also, Qantas opened services with the People's Republic of China. Again, I would support services to that place, but the result was, I understand, that initially losses were made again. It is unfair to expect Qantas to be entirely efficient when the government is telling the airline where it ought to fly for the government's own purposes.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that Qantas was prohibited from travelling on the most profitable air route in the world—that between Australia and South Africa. Labor said that, because of Australia's opposition to certain South African policies, the government owned South African Airways was to have a monoply on this sector. Also, Qantas has been prohibited from flying to Taiwan. We ought to recognise that one of the great benefits of the sale of Qantas is that Qantas will be able to spread its wings, literally and financially, and compete fairly in the marketplace.

The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) pointed out that the government has missed the boat as far as the public float of shares in Qantas is concerned. While it is recognised that the share market is not presently ideal for share floats, five years ago the situation was different. Indeed, had the government taken this action then, we would have seen a resurgent Qantas which would have had a much greater share of the marketplace.

It has also been stated that it is important, indeed vital, for Qantas staff to be given the opportunity to acquire shares in the airline. The best form of service will emanate from people who have a vested interest in the airline's success. I certainly hope that the government will do whatever it can to encourage Qantas staff to take up shares.

As indicated by earlier speakers, the opposition does not oppose this bill. But the opposition is concerned at the long list of postponements and muddles that we have seen in the selling of Qantas shares. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) is seeking in this bill to extend the time limit for outstanding matters from 31 December 1993 to 30 June 1995. I hope that some time down the track the government will not march back into this place to ask us to indulge in further extensions.

It is important that the sale proceed within the extended time limit. It is important that Qantas be given the opportunity to compete properly, openly and freely. After all, Qantas is a great airline—it is a good representative of this country—and we need to allow it to compete properly on fair terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in the debate on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill really to go back over some of the privatisation approaches that the coalition has had for some years now. I particularly refer to a paper that I produced in April 1989 entitled Privatisation—the Australian way. Those in the coalition will recall that paper. The policy has not changed much. The only thing that seems to have changed over time is that others have taken my name off the paper and put theirs on it.

PARA.TAB: The most important things to draw to mind in this paper are the reasons for privatisation: the lack of managerial autonomy; inflexibility in the capacity to raise capital; the requirement to perceive political priorities; the rigid and entrenched labour practices; the lack of exposure to competition of deregulated markets, which fosters commercial complacency and hence inefficiency. Those are the basic tenets under which privatisation was approached by the coalition back in the 1980s. Nothing has considerably changed from that at all.

The bill today is purely a deferring matter—a matter which reflects on the management of the privatisation progress and process more than it does on Qantas. I have to draw the attention of the House to the areas, the nominated companies, in this booklet at which the coalition was aiming back in those days: Aussat, Australian Airlines, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, Australian National Line, the Commonwealth Bank, domestic and international air terminals, Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, Medibank Private, OTC, Pipeline Authority, Qantas and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. When that list was released Mr Hawke—well remembered as a former Prime Minister; these days one wishes he was back—was horrified at the prospect of having these sales take place: `The great sell-off: the opposition sells the world', Labor cried.

As a consequence, half of those companies have already been privatised and the other half have had added to them some additional government enterprises which will be sold in the near future. As a consequence of this, we are able to encourage various state governments to approach their state instrumentalities with a view to privatisation, because by far the biggest area for privatisation of government assets is in the state government sphere. Certainly, looking at the operations of some of the marketing boards, some of the large assets that are held in electricity, water, ports and railroads, a vast quantity of assets exist all requiring updating and all requiring government dollars. At the present moment, the public would far rather see those authorities in private hands where the dollars are more readily raised than through the taxation system of governments.

Those matters are all raised in Privatisation—the Australian way. As one goes through the booklet, one will see two other things which are most important. One is that all moneys raised by privatisation in our plan were devoted to debt retirement. The government's process to date has been singularly marked by the application of what funds it has raised—something short of $3 billion—to current expenditures. If this is to continue, then quite clearly the debt of the nation will never be addressed, because the only way it will be faced in the future will be through higher taxation. At the present moment, that is politically untenable.

The second important thing about this booklet is that it sets out the ways in which sales should take place. From what I have seen to date, in particular regarding the Qantas debacle, when the first approaches were made to the market, with the help of an underwriting adviser, expressions of interest were called both for Australian Airlines and for Qantas—the ones that were not for sale at any price. Eventually, when both airline corporations decided that they wanted to take over each other, the government intervened to ensure that Qantas took over Australian Airlines for some $400 million. We are still waiting to see the outcome of that because management structures are being adjusted. There has been substantial labour loss. We are yet to see the full working efficiencies of that merger.

Apart from that, Qantas has been subject to a number of changes—firstly, the trade sell-off of 25 per cent to British Airways. When Qantas was put up for a trade tender of 25 per cent, the successful bidder was British Airways. The price set and paid by that corporation—some $600-odd million—was certainly very high. Whether the government can possibly achieve a comparable price for the two united airlines of Australian and Qantas has yet to be seen. To take it to the market in an inappropriate and unprepared state would almost certainly end in disaster.

I reflect also on two other areas. With regard to the Commonwealth Bank, the first tranche was offered on a fixed price, first in, best dressed basis. I notice that the offering currently in the marketplace is based on a floating price, following the success of the Woolworths float. I hope that the underwriters and the government can get a sufficient distribution of shares, not only to the current shareholders but also to wider areas of Australia. A most important part of Privatisation—the Australian way was ensuring that the maximum number of Australians could get into shares. By doing that, we encourage savings, participation and interest in what is going on in the commercial areas.

I especially want to emphasise the tremendous need for employee shares. If we can encourage all employees to hold shares, even on most generous terms, then the benefit to that corporation, and ultimately to the total economy, is almost assured. I hope that any future privatisations will ensure those things; it was certainly carried out in the Commonwealth Bank float. I hope that, when we come to Qantas and the other floats that will inevitably come down the track, that aspect is very securely written into it.

I do not wish to continue for long in the debate, but I wish to draw people's attention to the history of privatisation and the paper the coalition produced. What we advocated is now being followed by the government. There are aspects of that program which I still commend to everybody. I hope that, when they see the benefits of privatisation in another five years time, they might reflect that it was a pity that the government did not do it earlier.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Sciacca) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION LIMITED SALE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation was formed in 1970 to consolidate the engineering expertise accumulated

SPEECH.PARA: during the construction of the Snowy Mountains scheme. I am sure all Australians agree that that was a period of enormous significance for the engineering skills of this nation. SMEC, as the corporation is called, is based in Cooma and specialises in engineering services, road construction and overseas aid projects. By and large, it has created a very good standard of performance internationally and has a very worthwhile reputation.

PARA.TAB: In 1990-91, SMEC made a small profit of $309,000 on assets of over $9 million during a period when, for international economic reasons of which we are all aware, there was not only considerable international competition for projects, but a dearth of projects available on the market. In 1991-92, SMEC made a consolidated after-tax profit of $314,000; and it is expected to announce a $1 million profit for the year to June 1993. In other words, it has hopefully gone through its low period and is rising out of it.

The company has been consistently rated in the top 200 international design firms and has successfully completed over 1,500 separate projects in Australia and in some 53 countries overseas, mainly in the Third World. It has performed this work for aid agencies, government organisations and various private sector clients.

SMEC's expertise includes civil, electrical and mechanical engineering, aspects of water resources development, power generation and transmission, irrigation and land development, road engineering and transportation, procurement and project management. As well as its many overseas successes, SMEC has been active in pursuing privatised infrastructure projects within Australia. SMEC supervised the $100 million bypass around the city of Goulburn on the Hume Highway, which is well known to all honourable members, especially those from New South Wales who take the road to Canberra. SMEC has also been involved with the clean waterways program for the Sydney Water Board, providing staff in several disciplines, including construction, estimating, tunnelling and other infrastructure development areas.

The opposition was the first to advocate the privatisation of SMEC in about 1988. The government announced SMEC's 100 per cent sale in its 1992 budget. At last, we have reached a common point. A pre-sale scoping study was undertaken for the asset sales task force of the Department of Finance by Arthur Andersen and Co., which is now acting as consultants on the sale.

Prior to the 1993 election, the government indicated a preference for an employee buyout, subject to a fair price being negotiated, the company being viable and the sale taking place within a reasonable time scale. A staff buyout has come forward in the name of Tinbury. As I understand it, Tinbury, in terms of share ownership, is held by about 100 of the 240 staff—mainly the technical and professional staff. It is offering a staff buyout for the company.

Negotiations between the government and Tinbury have been protracted for some six months or so and are still unresolved. The government approved the staff buyout of SMEC in March of this year. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) wrote to Tinbury requesting that a proposal be submitted by the end of May. It is now September and, as I said, apparently no agreement has yet been reached.

The government has foreshadowed that there is a point when negotiations with Tinbury must come to an end. It may have to look at other methods of selling SMEC, including considering the possibilities of the industry being involved. From the opposition's point of view it is essential that in the final analysis the government maximises the value of SMEC in whatever sale price is finally achieved. We are moving an amendment to that effect.

The difficulties in this sale, however, which otherwise would have been a fairly clear-cut affair, concern a claim against SMEC, known as the Dartmouth Dam claim, for work undertaken in a project. In 1990 there was an incident at the Dartmouth Dam power station which has made an accurate valuation of SMEC very difficult. On 2 May 1990, two 80-kilogram girders from a gatehouse at the top of the Dartmouth Dam collapsed and were swept into the heart of a generator, causing a massive explosion. The Dartmouth Dam power station, one of Victoria's largest hydro-electric power stations, has only recently recommenced operations. In the meantime, Victoria had to purchase additional power from New South Wales. Even though the cost of rebuilding the damaged generator and power station was kept to around $29 million—significantly below the $80-odd million originally believed to be the cost—the claim initiated as a result of this incident, and for consequential damages and lost power generation, has not been settled.

The State Electricity Commission of Victoria is suing the Rural Water Resources Commission of Victoria and SMEC for $89m in alleged damages. The Rural Water Resources Commission also has a cross-claim against SMEC for a further $1.65 million. SMEC has legal representation. It is contesting the claims but it is unable to estimate its liability, if any. If litigation proceeds—and that is not by any means certain; there is considerable doubt about that—SMEC's liability could be much larger than its insurance cover and the value of its assets. As I said earlier, its assets are valued at around $9 million. If SMEC has to pay substantial damages, it will, in effect, be liquidated. One of the problems hampering negotiations has been placing a value on this risk. In recognition of this contingent liability, the government is offering Tinbury—it is not contained in this bill—a limited money back guarantee. This means that if SMEC is liquidated, Tinbury's up-front payment for SMEC will be refunded.

Let us look at the legislation in some detail. The legislation will effectively divorce SMEC from Commonwealth legislation and jurisdiction. It is important to remember that the Commonwealth's liability under SMEC, as it currently stands, is that it is the sole shareholder of a limited liability company. In terms of the Dartmouth Dam case, whether the Commonwealth continues to own SMEC or SMEC is sold on to another owner, the limited liability provision will still stand. That, again, is a factor which no doubt the other parties to the claim will have to take into account.

This legislation contains the changes required to enable SMEC's sale, while allowing for a range of outcomes—including a trade sale—in the event that the government cannot strike an acceptable agreement with Tinbury. The Minister for Finance stated that as a condition of sale, Tinbury must maintain operations in Cooma and not on-sell SMEC for five years. The third and an important criterion for sale is that the company must remain primarily Australian and that the staff must be given every opportunity to purchase the available equity in the company. But, as I said, the months go by and no settlement has yet been effectively achieved; no contract has been signed. The Minister for Finance has previously stated that as well as maintaining operations in Cooma, any other buyer must incorporate concessional employee shareholding and preserve Australian ownership and control. The opposition supports these conditions.

In order to reduce the initial cost of Tinbury purchasing SMEC, this legislation contains a provision for extinguishing SMEC's accumulated tax losses. The effect of that is that profits from the financial year in which the sale occurs onwards will be fully taxable as if no past tax losses had been made. The effect of that is that the actual purchase price of SMEC could be lower than previously anticipated, but it would not carry with it any additional benefit to the purchaser who would be required to pay full tax on profits for the period under consideration. It is not intended to proclaim this provision unless the removal of tax losses is part of a sales agreement approved by the government. One could ask the question: why put it in the bill if it is up for negotiation? It is quite unusual to put things in legislation and then state that they are subject to negotiation when, after all, an act is meant to be an absolute. In effect, this provision reduces the up-front purchase price of SMEC by an amount the government expects to recoup if and when SMEC makes future profits.

Given the contingent liability hanging over SMEC, this provision is not regarded as being unreasonable—and it is likely that even a trade buyer would want similar terms. But that touches upon the point I made: having put up the flag and offering this as the basis of negotiation, it probably would have been better to have emphasised it as an absolute rather than as something which is open to negotiation. Furthermore, in the event that SMEC prospers, the effect of the provision—theoretically, at least—will be revenue neutral.

I want to make it quite clear to the House that the opposition wholeheartedly supports the privatisation of SMEC. In the totality of the privatisation program of the government, SMEC is a relatively small and incidental item. In the context of the town of Cooma, however, SMEC is of some relevance. It has a staff of some 240 people. There are hundreds of people living in the town who are dependent upon SMEC. It has a very long history with Cooma, the southern highlands, the Snowy Mountains scheme and so forth. Naturally, people would like to see that continue. That is why the opposition has supported the view that any future buyer, including Tinbury, should be required as part of the purchase agreement to guarantee that it would remain in Cooma and not on-sell for at least five years. That, as we see it, is a fair deal.

The opposition is particularly concerned that in any case where the government is negotiating with only one bidder, as it is in the case of Tinbury, any contract resulting from such negotiations must not be seen to undervalue SMEC or to be susceptible to the charge that it undervalues the company or its assets. We believe that it would be both prudent and appropriate for the government to seek the opposition's concurrence with any contract that the government may negotiate as a result of a non-competitive sale process. The opposition is thus moving an amendment to the effect that any sale must maximise the value of SMEC. Ideally, any contract negotiated for the sale of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation as a result of a non-competitive process should receive the approval of the opposition before being signed.

I understand that one of my colleagues will be moving a further amendment to express the hope that SMEC will continue to be involved in major developmental projects, such as the turning inland of rivers in North Queensland and elsewhere. It must be understood that once SMEC is privatised the projects with which it becomes involved will be the absolute responsibility of its board and not of government, because the government will no longer have a shareholding of any nature in the company. Nevertheless, my colleague's view would be shared by any honourable member wishing Australian engineering corporations, such as SMEC and its various competitors across the land, to be seen as being of world standard, as we know they are, and therefore well and truly capable of being involved in Australia's major national development projects.

The outcome of the sale of SMEC, as I said, is not something of enormous financial benefit to the Commonwealth—it might be worth $1 million; it might be worth a little more. Nevertheless, I have gone to some lengths in my address to point out the difficulty of trying to assess the actual value of the company in the context of the Dartmouth claim. That claim, in the event that it proceeds, would be a claim against a limited liability company and limited to the level of that liability. In one way or the other, any claim in excess of the insurance cover, the actual assets backing of the company and the debts carried by the shareholders in the company, under many circumstances, would result in liquidation.

In view of its association with the Snowy Mountains scheme, it would be a pity if SMEC fell upon evil days, but those are the realities of the commercial market. Tinbury, and the personnel involved in it, are well aware of the implications of that situation. It is in that context that the sale of SMEC is probably quite different from the sale of any other government assets. Many of them, such as Qantas—the sale of which we debated in this House only a few minutes ago—have their difficulties.

The important thing about the Tinbury bid is that it emphasises one of the principles which the opposition believes is important in privatisation projects: that is, wherever possible, employed staff should be given the maximum opportunity to become shareholders in the enterprise of which they form such a vital part. In industries such as engineering and in a company such as SMEC, it goes without saying that the major asset of the corporation is the intellectual property of its personnel. Apart from its old buildings, which were built in Cooma in the 1950s, it has very little else except the intellectual capacity of its employees and the goodwill they have created over the decades through the quality of the projects with which they have been associated both in Australia and overseas.

However, this does complicate to some extent how one values a corporation of this type. How does one put a monetary figure on intellectual property, which depends not just on the past but also on the future viability of the corporation, and which in turn depends on the flow of projects to it from both government and the private sector in Australia and overseas?When one visits the headquarters of SMEC in Cooma, one cannot but be impressed by the photographs on the wall in the foyer which set out in some detail the substantial projects it has carried through in recent years—in Malaysia, Thailand and elsewhere. I do not have the slightest doubt that Australia, being on the edge of the Asia-Pacific region, will in the years ahead have an outstanding opportunity to increase the entry of our experts into world markets, especially into regional markets, and even more especially into the markets of our neighbour countries which have seen such substantial, if not phenomenal, economic growth over recent years.

In China the growth rate has been 10 per cent. In most of the ASEAN countries it has been six per cent or more. That puts Australia's two per cent or less into stark relief. Those countries will be looking for investment, for know-how and for expertise. In fields such as engineering, in the areas where SMEC has established a very worthy reputation over recent years, I have no doubt that its personnel will be able to play a very significant role in getting out into world markets, tendering for projects and winning its fair share.

I make the point in the amendment which I have advised the House that I intend to move that it is very important that the asset values, once determined, be progressed as best we can. SMEC is a Commonwealth asset; it belongs to the Australian people. In a sense, there are two balancing acts here. On both sides of the House there is agreement that the first priority for sale should be the provision of a staff buy-out. I have also made the point that some six months have passed and, to the best of my knowledge, no deals have been achieved. One therefore has to question whether, in the desire to achieve a staff buy-out, we are giving adequate consideration to ensuring that the Australian taxpayers' interest in SMEC is also being adequately protected.

Ultimately that is an executive decision to be made by the government. But it is the role of the opposition to put on record the fact that we are watching and are concerned. It is our responsibility to ensure that the final contract is in the interest of the Australian people and maximises the value of the asset. SMEC will be sold. We must ensure that in the method of its sale we are adding to Australia's intellectual capacity in the engineering field and that what has been built up over some years is not lost. I move:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House is of the view that any sale of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation should not undervalue this Commonwealth asset".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I am very pleased to support the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited Sale Bill in this, my maiden post-ministerial speech. I am also particularly pleased to speak today because this task would have been undertaken by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), who is, unfortunately, overseas. I would like to record at the outset that he particularly wanted to be here when this bill was debated.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said when he was introducing this bill, the sale of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Ltd represents another important step in the government's micro-economic reform program. It is also a vital and logical step in the development of a company that under government ownership has established itself as Australia's foremost international engineering consultancy firm.

I have misgivings about some privatisations, particularly those engaged in at times by state governments, because there is a downside to privatisation. I do not regard privatisation as an ideological must. However, in this case we have an organisation that has established itself, and what the government is doing is very sensible.

SMEC has completed more than 1,700 major projects in 55 countries and more than 80 per cent of its current revenue is derived from international business. In this most competitive industry, SMEC has demonstrated that it can successfully tender for the most complex technological projects against the world's leading consultancy firms.

For example, one of its recent successes was the contract to supervise the construction of a 339-kilometre motorway linking Islamabad and Lahore in Pakistan, which was won against aggressive international competition. In addition to its traditional areas of expertise—the design and construction of major hydro-electric projects, highways and transportation, and water resources—SMEC has developed technological expertise in many disciplines which places it at the very forefront of the industry internationally. Its water resources branch, for example, which undertakes work in the fields of hydrology, hydraulics and systems simulation studies, is recognised as one of the most technologically advanced consultants in its field in the world.

SMEC is now positioned to maintain and increase its already substantial business in the vital South-East Asia-Pacific region, adding to its national importance as a significant earner of foreign currency, and a vital flag carrier for Australian industry. Last year, when I was privileged to be Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, SMEC was on several of the delegations that I led to South-East Asia. One delegation was to Vietnam, a country that has been fighting for some 50 years. Vietnam's infrastructure was wound right down. When international aid flows to that country, it is very important that attention be given to projects such as ports, roads, dams and electricity transmission. It is very important that international engineering assistance be given. I see SMEC well placed in that context.

The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has already mentioned that the company has proved itself in the highly competitive Australian market. After winning the contract to supervise the construction of the federally funded multimillion dollar bypass around the city of Goulburn on the Hume Highway—which it completed months ahead of schedule and well within budget—it also successfully bid for the Jugiong bypass further south on the Hume Highway, which is now under construction.

I guess it is still a matter of surprise to some people that such an important international company is located in Cooma, a small Monaro town in the foothills of the Snowy Mountains. As honourable members in this House know, historically this is the legacy of its parent, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. One of the principal reasons why Cooma was selected for the headquarters of the Snowy scheme in the 1940s was that it was the closest railhead. At that time Australia had to import much of its engineering expertise, while Australians were sent abroad for training in the investigation and design of hydraulic works.

When the Snowy scheme was nearing completion, the decision was taken in 1970 to establish an international consulting firm that would take advantage of the extraordinary talent that had been assembled, and keep these skills in Australia. Today, the wheel has come full circle and Australian expertise has developed to the point where we now export our technical excellence. SMEC has played a key role over the years in achieving this enviable situation, and engineers in many disciplines—and from many countries—now come to Australia, and frequently to Cooma, for their own training.

SMEC is a major employer in Cooma, and the government's announcement that the company would be sold to staff through its buyout vehicle, Tinbury Ltd, was widely applauded. The staff buyout offers stability and sustainability. A condition of the sale is that SMEC must remain in Cooma for at least five years, and it may not be sold during this period. The board of Tinbury has made it clear that it intends to stay in Cooma for far longer than five years. It is my understanding that Tinbury will meet the criteria set out by the minister in his speech, and that the negotiations were finalised and signed on 17 September. This is the matter that was raised by the honourable member for Bradfield.

For the local community, and particularly the business community of Cooma, this is good news, and the honourable member for Eden Monaro has worked tirelessly to secure this outcome for the staff and the region. I would like to pay due credit to him. Already more than half the staff are shareholders in the company, and the staff shareholding will be extended through a second prospectus to be issued prior to the settlement of the sale.

SMEC's principal resource and asset is its skilled staff. I was privileged to launch Brad Collins's book on the Snowy. For the first 33 years of my life I lived on a farm near the Hume Highway. Through the 1950s I saw the very large trucks grinding along the highway, carrying generators and various pieces of equipment down to the Snowy scheme. It was also a source of wonder to me, seeing all this moving past to some area that I did not even see until the late 1950s. What was really wonderful about the launching of the book was that, after having read it and seen some pictures of some of the people in the book, they were there at the launching.

Those people came from all over the world at that stage—many from war torn Europe—and by and large they settled down with what became a wonderful scheme. This bill is recognition of the fact that these people made the company what it is today, and that they are best placed to steer it to still greater success in the future. This in itself is the reason the government allowed the staff to have first option. We recognised the people, their skills and their intellectual property. We can now look forward to seeing SMEC beginning the next chapter in its long and very proud history.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited Sale Bill simply provides the broad legislative framework within which the sale of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation may proceed. The House should not assume that the current bill in any way, shape or form provides any details as to the terms under which the final sale of the corporation might take place. To that extent, it provides no detail as to the eventual transparency of that pending transaction. On this basis, the coalition reluctantly supports the passage of the bill as it is. It gives no guarantees as to its position on the circumstances which will eventually surround the sale of the corporation.

PARA.TAB: By way of background, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation—SMEC—was formed back in 1970. It was converted to a public company in 1989. The corporation was a spin-off of the engineering and construction consultancy expertise developed over the building project life of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electricity Authority.

In the late 1980s the government allowed SMEC to restructure itself in the form of a public corporation in which the Commonwealth became simply the predominant shareholder; that is to say, the government's interference in the day-to-day commercial activities of the former authority was withdrawn, and the corporation was allowed to proceed, to all intents and purposes, as any other private business. The pressure on SMEC to perform on its own was blindingly apparent, and attested to the weaknesses some governmental authorities have in meeting market conditions.

SMEC's history over the 1980s has not been one of the high points in the history of governmental business enterprises. I know that the staff and the board of directors have struggled mightily to keep the corporation afloat over the last seven or eight years, but we are still looking at a business concern which, by any reckoning, is still proppy on its feet. SMEC's revenue dropped dramatically after 1985, and the government, for all its touted opposition to privatisation, realised that the authority had no future under the public umbrella.

The evidence of SMEC's declining business performance was pretty stunning, to say the least. SMEC's 1985-86 annual report shows a 42 per cent decrease in revenue—effectively a loss of $3.7 million. As a result of this near crisis, a three-year corporate plan was implemented, staff cuts occurred and an external board of directors was instituted. In the first year of the plan, revenue dropped a further 25 per cent from the previous year; from $64 million down to $37 million. The loss for the year was $2.4 million. At this time, to maintain working capital, the government injected $6 million into SMEC.

By the third year of the plan, revenue was still dropping faster than expenditure. It was patently obvious that something needed to be done. As the SMEC reports indicate, the corporation had been hit on many fronts. SMEC had proved to be `ill-suited to meet market fluctuations' and there were `too many [government] constraints' on its activities in the early to mid-1980s. Furthermore, because the majority of SMEC's work was on overseas infrastructure projects, it suffered greatly when there was a worldwide pattern of reduced emphasis on infrastructure development.

SMEC also had to compete against private Australian based and foreign engineering firms which, in the early 1980s, it was ill-prepared to face. Since the authority has been corporatised, the ship has been steadied somewhat. Profit has remained relatively steady, with the corporation registering a bottom line operating profit of $274,000 in 1989. In 1990, SMEC returned an operating profit of $309,000. In 1991, SMEC's operating profit was $238,000 and in 1992 SMEC achieved an after tax profit of $290,000. That is not a great performance by any standard and one described by the chairman of SMEC as a not yet satisfactory result—something of an understatement.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) informs us that SMEC is now set to make a $1 million profit next year. This looks to be true on the basis of SMEC's revenue flows as indicated in its annual reports. Revenue has climbed during the years 1990 to 1992, growing by 13 per cent, 28 per cent and 17.8 per cent for 1990, 1991 and 1992 respectively. SMEC's domestic workload has strengthened. Despite the weaknesses in the international market, overseas consultancy operations are accounting for more and more of the corporation's revenue—81 per cent of revenue in 1992, which is a good early sign.

The corporation is involved in over 100 projects in six regions: the Pacific and Papua New Guinea; Indonesia and South-East Asia; China and Hong Kong; Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Sri Lanka; the Indian subcontinent and Middle East; and Africa. It has project contracts which include a $27 million contract to supervise the building of a $US1.5 billion motorway linking Islamabad and Lahore in Pakistan; a flood damage restoration project in Bangladesh; a hydro-electric project in Guangzhou in China; and roads projects in Indonesia, Malaysia, Tonga and Thailand.

As well as having engineering projects, SMEC is contracted to AIDAB as a procurement contractor to supply commodities to recipient governments, ranging from textbooks and tractors, to medicines, railway signals and equipment for clearing oil spills. Despite the evidence that SMEC—its staff and board of directors—has managed to pull itself back from the brink for the time being, the terms of the privatisation of the corporation are less than clear and rightly should be scrutinised by the parliament.

The public, over time, has contributed strongly to the operations of SMEC and its earlier business structures. Notwithstanding the contribution the body has made to the nation's engineering and construction expertise, its terms of sale must be above board. Taxpayers should expect their earlier investments and future liabilities to be protected. In this respect, I wish to make a number of points when the debate is resumed.

The point for the opposition here is a very clear one: before the Senate, following passage through this House last night—and indeed it was previously before the Senate in a different form—is a proposition which will extend to Australian taxpayers a benefit which they should receive before Christmas. Included amongst the propositions is one which would extend taxation relief to those people earning below $20,000 a year. PARA.TAB: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition probably does not understand that many of the people earning below $20,000 a year do not work for the whole year; and that cannot always be reflected by their PAYE benefits. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Do the ABS employment statistics for the retail sector display a regular seasonal pattern? Are there reasons for expecting that pattern to be different in 1993-94?

—It is a fact that the ABS figures on retail sales show that December is the peak month of the year for the retail sector. Turnover in December for the retail sector as a whole is typically well over one-third higher than for the average of the other 11 months of the year. Retail traders take on additional staff to handle that seasonal spike of customers in their shops. This creates many jobs, particularly for young people, for school leavers and for people who are on university vacation. It also provides many other temporary jobs for people who might otherwise have been out of work.

PARA.TAB: The ABS publications on labour force figures show that last December the retail sector appears to have created some 35,000 to 40,000 seasonal jobs; that is, jobs additional to the underlying pattern of employment. This December we should see an even bigger seasonal boost because the government has, through its fiscal policy, designed a stimulus to provide additional support to the economy at that time, whilst at the same time laying down a firm foundation for the reduction in the budget deficit over the years ahead.

The key ingredient to this additional stimulus is the personal income tax cuts which the government would like to give as from 15 November, providing an additional opportunity for people to spend more in the lead-up to, and at the time of, Christmas. But it would be fiscally irresponsible for the government to proceed with those cuts without having the rest of the package; in other words, providing the tax cuts while the opposition has the rest of the strategy held hostage in the Senate.

By stubbornly opposing these tax cuts and stubbornly opposing this package, the opposition is essentially threatening 40,000 jobs for Australians over Christmas as would be provided by this boost to the retail industry. Instead of there being more jobs this Christmas, instead of more people being taken on by the retail sector, we could, as a result of the Liberal Party's tactics, see fewer people taken on, therefore removing the opportunity for 40,000 seasonal jobs.

Not only do Liberal Party members want to deny tax cuts to ordinary working men and women in Australia, but also they want to deny part-time employment to their sons and daughters who otherwise might be able to go out and get a job during that particular period. We only have to remember that at this time last year, the Leader of the Opposition was still clinging to a policy which would have taxed Christmas to the hilt, would have taxed everything that went on the Christmas table, and would have taxed every present that was ever bought for any child throughout Australia.

What he wants to do on this occasion is not so much tax Christmas, but postpone it until next July. Last year the Leader of the Opposition saw the light and abandoned his policy. I suggest he does the same this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to the current logging of compartment 1402 in the south-east forests, listed in the national estate register as being of high conservation value. —I thank the honourable member for his question and his interest in this very important issue. The honourable member is right when he refers to the national forest policy statement, but I must remind him that that statement has two partners—the states and the Commonwealth. The states and the Commonwealth are signatories. The states, therefore, have got to abide by their commitment.

PARA.TAB: I have written to all the state governments—particularly the New South Wales government in this case—and I have said that as part of that policy statement these are the areas which I believe, on advice, are the areas of high conservation value. The area referred to by the honourable member was on that list set out in my letter. I am still awaiting a response. As the honourable member will appreciate, forestry, particularly the issue of logging, is a state responsibility. We may all not like that, but that is the bottom line. We must now look at whether the New South Wales government is serious about its commitment to this forestry statement. Minister Lee and I will be discussing what action we can take if it is proven that the states are not committed to that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister advise the House of progress being made by the government in tackling Australia's unemployment problem.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Speaker—
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Maranoa.

—I said during the election campaign that the government would not leave the unemployed to fall behind and become an underclass, that we would keep the unemployed as part of the mainstream labour market and that the government's policies would focus on growth in employment—an inclusive policy to include all Australians in that activity. On the basis of our performance in the 1980s in terms of employment growth and our devotion of economic policy to growth, the government will, of course, as it is now, with low inflation and low interest rates, and a budget to bring the deficit down, set up a situation where growth in the economy can proceed. The profit share is already rising to its late 1980s high level, which is reflected by a very high level of the all ordinaries index, as companies regain their profitability, repair their balance sheets and get ready to invest in a larger way which would secure higher aggregate levels of employment for us.

PARA.TAB: We understand that growth alone will not repair the problem of the long-term unemployed. In fact, at a meeting in the last week or so, the G7 ministers agreed that growth alone will not deal with the problem of unemployment, particularly the long-term unemployed. That is, in the case of some European countries—Britain comes to mind as one with a high level of unemployment—it has had no impact whatsoever on wages or wages growth, because these people are now no longer regarded as part of the labour market. They have been sidelined. They have become an underclass. They have no attachment to the labour market and, therefore, they are not an economic variable in terms of wages, productivity, growth or anything else.

That means two things. One is that it is imperative to get back to higher rates of growth because higher rates of growth will provide aggregate jobs to reduce unemployment. That is reducing the stock of long-term unemployed people, but it will not necessarily deal with the long-term unemployed. That is one of the issues that is the focus of the committee on employment opportunities which I met with this morning to discuss progress in preparing the discussion paper on employment. Having talked to the prime ministers of Britain and Ireland and the President of the United States on this last visit about the problem, I am convinced that Australia can be at the forefront of tackling the challenge and finding ways to address the problem of unemployment and particularly long-term unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've been in for 10 years.
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders!
—The committee is addressing these problems at the right time. The committee recognises the central and dominant role of sustained economic growth in reducing unemployment.
—They would be grateful for your advice.
—I warn the honourable member for Flinders.

—But it also acknowledges the need to maximise the employment outcomes from economic growth. It is one thing to have the growth—we need the growth basically to see the turning in employment—but we must have the efficiency of having the longer term unemployed involved in the opportunities of that growth. Therefore, special assistance needs to be given to long-term unemployed, as we know that growth alone will not be enough to get them back in employment.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the discussion paper will need to cover many areas to give a comprehensive assessment of the options facing us, including flexible industrial relations arrangements; income support provisions that are more responsive to part-time and casual work opportunities; more active labour market assistance which recognises the needs of different job seekers in different regions with different employers; a stronger vocational training system, which the government got to work on in 1992; and the removal of barriers to employment. We on this side of the House believe that equity demands that the unemployed be the focus of government assistance, but it is critical—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wind it up, for goodness sake.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell is not in his correct place and, in any case, interjections are disorderly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen comments by the British Chancellor of the Exchequer about the priority being given in Europe to employment policies? Does the minister agree with these comments, and what are the government's intentions in this matter?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the comments of the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr Kenneth Clarke. They are sobering comments indeed. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The persistence of high levels of structural unemployment right across the continent of Europe is, in my opinion, the most serious economic problem facing our governments today.
In Europe there is no longer a belief that the resumption of growth is the sole remedy for all economic ills.

He went on to say that he was extremely concerned that there is no guarantee that unemployment will fall significantly as the recovery progresses. He has good reason to be sober, coming as he does from Britain where during the 1980s some three million jobs were added to its supply but where during the recession about 1.5 million jobs were lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 146, which says that a question fully answered cannot be renewed. The minister is repeating words that the Prime Minister gave us just minutes ago. Can he tell us something else?

—There is no point of order. I was going to make another comment and that was in reference to the number of points of order that are taken in this place, often under the guise of some degree of relevance. Might I suggest to honourable members that they approach that issue with some caution. I have been listening to the minister's answer on this particular issue, and I would invite him to get to the substance of it.

—Mr Clarke confronts a situation where half of the three million jobs created in the 1980s have been lost in the course of the recession. In the same period of time, 1.6 million jobs were created in this country. To get an appropriate equivalent, one multiplies the Australian figure by four. That would put us in a position of being the equivalent of about 6.5 million jobs in the United Kingdom. In the course of the recession we have lost some 200,000 to 300,000 of those jobs in contrast to the British position of losing about half.

PARA.TAB: Mr Clarke realises that, for the British and the Europeans to be able to deal with a situation that they will find increasingly serious over the next 24 months, they will require active measures of their governments in order to keep the work force, which is out of work, competitive, to retrain those who have been structurally adjusted out of the work force to be able to get back into the work force and to provide growth which is absolutely the underpinning of any improvement in employment at all. That is very much the position that this government would accept as the appropriate approach to dealing with the problems that are confronting the Europeans and, to a lesser but nevertheless serious extent, confront us here.

There are a variety of views in the community as to what the government ought to do in defining its intentions on these matters. A recent comment, for example, from Professor Sloan—if the headlines are to be believed—said that labour market programs do not create work. She is quite wrong about that; they do. The government's new enterprise incentive scheme creates new small businesses which employ additional people. The jobskills program and LEAP are fully additional to work force numbers; they are not simply a process whereby unemployed people are selected to get the job.

Wage subsidies offered through jobstart programs bring forward employment opportunities. Whilst there is some displacement in this area, in particular, from the work force—some unemployed people get jobs that others would have got were those subsidies not offered—the displacement rate is not 100 per cent. So there is additional employment through those processes. That part of Professor Sloan's comments was quite erroneous. I would agree wholeheartedly with other parts of what she has said. She also said that labour market programs ought to be pursued in the work force for equity and efficiency reasons. It is essential, in terms of equity and efficiency, to provide everybody with an opportunity to work because, without a competitive labour market, with each recession unemployment plateaus at higher and higher levels.

Those issues of employment and unemployment are serious matters of debate and there are serious problems involved in arriving at the correct solutions. There is a debate, not only in this country but elsewhere, of a remarkably similar character. One of the problems is that among no group of conservatives anywhere, except here, is a government not required to undertake active measures in the labour market to encourage people back into work and provide opportunities for them. Alone among all the conservative parties in this country is the opposition's position of savagely slashing labour market programs on which, in comparison with those in Europe, as a percentage of GDP, we do not spend as much.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991, the ESOS Act, to strengthen the protection afforded to international students' pre-paid fees. The need for this was highlighted by the closure of the Australian Business College in Perth in February 1993. This closure and the absence of money from the special account meant that about 350 overseas students in Australia and up to 100 still off-shore lost moneys totalling up to $2.2 million. Because of the special circumstances of the closure, this loss was made good by a special Commonwealth appropriation. The Commonwealth should not be placed in this situation again. The industry must look after its own. Legislation is also required in the current sittings to address the act's 1 January 1994 sunset clause. There is now little medium term prospect of industry self-regulation or of state and territory regulation replacing Commonwealth regulation. Industry supports continuation of the act.

PARA.TAB: The bill will strengthen the ESOS Act by requiring private education providers to maintain trust accounts, not just special accounts, for students' pre-paid funds; to adhere to limits on draw downs from those trust accounts to ensure that if they default there is enough for refunds; to adhere to more prescriptive refund provisions if they fail to provide the course, or if a student withdraws from the course; and to be in an industry-run tuition assurance scheme to guarantee that international students receive the courses paid for if a provider defaults.

Details of the tuition assurance scheme are being developed by a government-industry working group. They will be prescribed in the regulations under the act later this year. The scheme will be run and funded by the industry, although $3.1 million was appropriated in the 1993 budget to provide Commonwealth financial assistance in its establishment.

Another major amendment will introduce prison penalties for current monetary penalties for certain breaches of the act. This follows from advice from authorities investigating the closure of the Australian Business College in Perth that penalties needed to be stiffened. Increasing the penalties to imprisonment allows the court to impose a monetary penalty in addition to, or instead of, the term of imprisonment in accordance with the formula provided in the Crimes Act 1914.

Additional amendments include allowing more flexibility in rolling back the financial regulation sections of the act in favour of equivalent state and territory arrangements; providing a sanction when a suspended provider ignores the act's requirement that it not recruit new overseas students; changing the definition of an overseas student so that it clearly excludes those studying on a visitor's visa.

The bill is the product of extensive consultation with the international education industry, including seminars in major capital cities and discussions with the National Consultative Committee on International Education and Training Services. It has also been shaped by the attentions of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, especially the committee's December 1992 report on its inquiry into the operation of the ESOS Act. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill proposes to amend the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to initiatives announced in the context of the 1993-94 budget. This bill proposes to establish a pilot program for transition support for students with disabilities for an initial period 1994 to 1996 at a cost of $5.1 million.

PARA.TAB: Additionally, $3.6 million developmental funding is to be provided over three years from 1994 to 1996 to support existing and developing hostels for rural school students. The students at risk program, which was due to cease at the end of 1994, will be extended for a further two years, with funding of $13.5 million.

This bill also finalises the full implementation of the national equity program for schools for 1994, including the broadbanding provisions endorsed by the Australian Education Council which provide financial assistance under four elements focused on access, equity, national priorities and incentives. Following agreement with school authorities, these new provisions will replace the interim arrangements that existed in 1993. The bill provides for a number of other changes: strengthening the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools; and limiting eligibility for Commonwealth general recurrent funding to those students enrolled at non-government schools and attending those schools on a regular basis.

Finally, this bill will provide funding schedules for programs under the national equity program for schools and joint programs to support primary and secondary education for the remainder of the 1993 to 1996 funding period. I believe this will provide state and non-government school authorities with greater certainty in their future funding and facilitate a better planning basis over the medium term.

The bill sets grant levels for schools in the 1994 program year which are estimated to be $2.901 billion. Funds appropriated by this bill for the 1994 program year are estimated to be some $2.286 billion for general recurrent grants to government and non-government schools, $303.7 million for capital grants to government and non-government schools, $286 million for national equity programs, $18 million for the school language program and $6.5 million for other joint programs. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
