DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Sciacca, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 focuses on implementing some 1993 federal election initiatives and initiatives announced in the 1993 budget. The bill also provides for some minor policy changes and technical amendments to further improve the effectiveness and efficiency of social security administration.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the 1993 federal election, the government announced that it would introduce new payment arrangements for long-term unemployed clients aged 60 and over, but below pension age. The commitment was made in recognition of the difficulties faced by older unemployed people in the current labour market.

From 20 March 1994, any person aged 60 and over who has not reached pension age, is unemployed, has been registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service for the last 12 months and has been receiving income support payments for the last 12 months will be able to claim a mature age allowance. The person will have to be in Australia and satisfy the age pension residency requirement of 10 years qualifying Australian residence. The person's partner might also be qualified to receive a mature age partner allowance.

Transfer to the new allowance will be voluntary. Unlike the conditions that apply to newstart allowance, a person being paid the mature age allowance will not have to satisfy an activity test or stay registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service. However, a person might wish to remain registered so as to use any assistance the Commonwealth Employment Service provides.

Mature age allowance will be paid at age pension rates and be subject to the pension income and assets tests. Some of the other main features of the new allowance are that allowees will have access to the pensioner earnings credit scheme, and pensioner tax rebates will also apply.

The government recognises that the need for the mature age allowance could diminish when the economy recovers. To that end, legislation providing for the allowance will be subject to a sunset clause of 30 June 1996, after which time no new claims may be lodged. Existing recipients will not be affected. Continuation of the arrangements will be reviewed in 1994-95 in the light of prevailing labour market conditions.

This bill also gives effect to an election commitment announced by the Prime Minister in Investing in the nation to provide an incentive for social security allowance recipients and their partners to earn moderate casual or part-time income without automatically affecting their income support payments.

Jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowance clients being paid at the maximum rate will be able to build up credit of up to $500 that can be offset against income from employment. Couples will be able to build up a maximum credit of $500 each. For a single person, credit will accrue at the rate of $90 a fortnight. Credit for each member of a couple will accrue at $80 a fortnight. The credits will not be transferable between partners.

Credits may be used provided the person's earnings from employment and other income fall below the income test cut-out point for that person for the fortnight in question. For those earning above the cut-out points in a given fortnight, credits may not be accessed but will be `preserved' for up to 13 weeks and can be accessed at a later time.

Newstart allowance was introduced in July 1991 with the objective of assisting the unemployed, particularly the long-term unemployed and those with labour market disadvantages, to return to paid employment and so reduce their dependency on income support.

A requirement of newstart's implementation was that an interim evaluation report be presented in the 1993-94 budget context. The report indicated that newstart has produced some impressive results, including 1.7 million job referrals, over 430,000 placements on labour market programs and 320,000 job placements. As part of the interim evaluation, a post-implementation review was conducted. In general, the review found that both staff and clients see newstart as an improvement on the old arrangements, but officers of the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service felt that the positive aspects could be better used.

The measures, to be implemented progressively from September 1993 to September 1994, will reinforce the key objective of the newstart strategy: namely, to help those on social security payments to maintain their job search efforts and move into jobs. In summary, those measures will:

SPEECH.PARA: improve the selection processes for client contacts to ensure the early identification and assessment of clients with labour market disadvantages;
provide more effective case management for all newstart clients, particularly those with a labour market disadvantage;
enhance compliance and review activity to reinforce client obligations to make genuine efforts to find work, undertake training and generally improve job prospects;
improve client assistance and service delivery; and
improve liaison between the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service.
The implementation of some of these measures requires legislation and the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 provides the first step in doing this.

PARA.TAB: The Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 provides for the introduction from 1 January 1994 of a $200 education entry payment for newstart allowance clients and jobsearch allowance clients under 18 who have been registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service as unemployed for at least 12 months and who enrol in a full-time course of education that is an approved course under the Austudy or Abstudy schemes. The payment will assist with the up-front costs of taking up study, such as enrolment fees, purchasing books, student union fees and course fees.

Some people, such as those who have lived or worked overseas, may be entitled to income support from another country. Presently, it is not a general requirement for the grant or continued payment of an Australian pension that people claim or pursue their entitlement from another country, even from countries with which Australia has social security agreements based on shared responsibility. From 20 March 1994, if the Secretary to the Department of Social Security thinks a person or that person's partner would be entitled to a payment from a specified country, it will be necessary for the person or that partner to take reasonable steps to obtain the maximum payment from that country. The overall result will be a reduced dependence on Australian social security pensions when payments are also available from specified countries.

The government is concerned to ensure that the debt recovery provisions set out in the Social Security Act 1991 operate not only efficiently and effectively but with fairness. With those objectives in mind, the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 will amend the Social Security Act 1991 from 1 January 1994 to implement a number of initiatives announced in the 1993 budget relating to debt recovery.

Currently, jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance and sickness allowance clients are paid according to the number of days for which they are entitled to payment. If a client does not tell the department he or she has started work or received income, any calculation of overpayment begins from the day after this `notifiable event' occurred. Amendments will provide for the calculation of the overpayment to start on the day the notifiable event occurs, rather than the day after and will bring the treatment of overpayments into line with the payment of arrears.

Dual payments, for example, where a client obtains a replacement cheque—on the basis that the original cheque has not been received—but subsequently obtains value for not only the replacement cheque but also the original, will be recoverable in the same way as many other debts, for example, from continuing payments or by garnishee. The recovery of debts arising from fraudulent negotiation of cheques by a third party will be streamlined by allowing recovery using existing powers under the Social Security Act 1991. This will avoid the need for costly civil action.

The Social Security Act 1991 generally excludes dual entitlement to social security income support and other government income support payments such as compensation and service pension. However, unless a client commits a breach of a provision of the act or misrepresents his or her situation, a debt arises only where there are dual social security payments or concurrent payments of a social security payment and a service pension. Amendments will extend the debt recovery provisions to allow recovery of all payments covered by multiple entitlement exclusion provisions, such as Austudy and war widows pensions.

At present, fraudulently obtained payments can only be recovered from the Department of Social Security client who actually received them unless another departmental client agrees to recovery from his or her own payment. The Department of Social Security has been criticised by the courts in a number of cases—specifically, for not taking action against partners who were knowingly involved in payments being fraudulently obtained by Department of Social Security clients.

Amendments will allow a debt to be recovered from another person, usually a partner, where that person has benefited from and been knowingly involved in the fraudulent obtaining of moneys by the Department of Social Security client, provided that the involvement of the other person has first been established through criminal proceedings.

The bill provides for a number of measures concerning the treatment of compensation payments for social security purposes. They are intended, generally, to preserve the integrity and effectiveness of the existing provisions. One of the more significant measures will be to bring within the provisions lump sum compensation payments whether or not they contain an economic loss component. A great majority of lump sum compensation payments contain economic loss amounts. Those payments are, and will continue to be, covered by the compensation provisions. The so-called 50 per cent rule will remain whereby half the total lump sum will continue to be disregarded for social security entitlement purposes. It is clear, however, that compensation settlements are being entered into such that they avoid, or attempt to avoid, the compensation provisions. The government has acted and will continue to act to ensure that people who receive compensation payments use them for their support, at least for a reasonable period of time, before calling on the taxpayer funded social security system.

Another important change is to use a new divisor within the statutory formula that deals with the treatment of lump sums. The employees—all persons—average weekly earnings figure is to replace the `all male' figure. The all persons figure is more likely to reflect the level of ordinary wages in the occupational classifications most likely to sustain work related injuries and recognises the fact of women's participation in the work force and the incidence of motor vehicle accidents across the general population.

Another change will limit the exemption from the provisions dealing with personal sickness and accident insurance policies. Some of these policies pay policy holders an amount less an amount of income support received from the Department of Social Security in the period covered by the policy. It is not acceptable that insurance companies should be able to shift part of their costs in this way onto the taxpayer. The bill also, among other things, standardises the treatment of wife pensioners in compensation cases, clarifies the `event' that might give rise to the entitlement to compensation and tackles certain cost-shifting type provisions in state and territory legislation.

Rent assistance waiting periods were abolished from March 1992 for nearly all eligible clients. However, at present, young people under 18 who have lodged a claim and are qualified for the homeless or independent rates of jobsearch allowance and sickness allowance must serve a waiting period of 18 weeks before rent assistance is payable. This bill gives effect to the government's decision to abolish the 18-week waiting period for this latter group from 20 March 1994. This measure will make it easier for these young people to access secure accommodation.

The government has decided that from 1 January 1994 all secondary school students born after 31 December 1977, apart from those students who attract Austudy paid at the independent or away from home rate, or who are homeless, will instead remain within the social security system until they turn 17. Most students will become eligible to attract family payment at the new rate that will apply from 1 January 1994 of $123.90 a fortnight for their caregiver. Those secondary school students who are homeless will be eligible for special benefit. On their 17th birthday, secondary school students will be able to claim Austudy. This bill gives effect to that decision.

The Department of Social Security issues millions of statutory notices each year to various groups of clients. Most of the notices require clients to notify certain relevant changes to their circumstances and an overpayment results if a client fails to do so. The Social Security Appeals Tribunal—the SSAT—has indicated what it regards as potential technical deficiencies in the department's notices with the result that the SSAT has found against the department in many overpayment cases on the grounds that the notices are deficient. Given that the cost implications for the Commonwealth are significant, probably in excess of $50 million per year, it is proposed that prompt legislative action be taken to resolve this problem.

Amendments contained in the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 make it clear that a notice will not be invalid merely because it may fail to specify the manner in which a person must comply with it or because it does not describe itself as a `recipient notification notice' or `recipient statement notice'. In addition to protecting the revenue, these amendments are important as a matter of equity. Many people responded to these notices and gave the department information that brought about a reduction in their social security payments. Others ignored the notices and failed to notify the department of named events or changes in circumstances. It would be unfair to those who did comply with the notices to relieve others from the consequences of their failure to notify.

Since 1991 the powers of the Secretary to the Department of Social Security to waive a debt have been guided by ministerial direction in two successive disallowable instruments tabled in and allowed by the parliament. Only very recently the Federal Court decided in Riddell v Secretary to the Department of Social Security to set aside the 1991 ministerial direction on the grounds that it was invalid and indicated that it would do the same to the 1992 direction if it came before the court. This has left decision makers and tribunals with no guidelines on how to decide if a debt may be waived and, potentially, it has significant cost implications for the Commonwealth.

The bill addresses these problems by amending the Social Security Act 1991 to include the grounds for waiver in the act itself. One of the grounds in the act will be more generous than it was previously. Waiver of a debt will occur where the debt arises solely because of administrative error of the Commonwealth and the money was received in good faith. Previously, it was also necessary that recovery would cause financial hardship before waiver could occur. On the other hand, there will now be no general power to waive because of special circumstances. The circumstances listed in the bill provide a code for making waiver decisions.

The Data Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 provides for data matching between specified agencies so as to detect where two inconsistent payments are made to a person by the same or more than one agency; to detect where inconsistent income data is held about one person by two or more agencies; and to detect possible tax evasion.

Ideas for changes or improvements to the act are constantly being made as a result of the unusually large number of agencies with a direct interest in the act and the level of scrutiny given by parliamentarians and others. As a result, the act has been amended on several occasions since its enactment in 1990. The Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 makes further changes to the act to improve the efficiency and accuracy of data matching by, among other things, permitting tax file numbers to be used by assistance agencies in discussions with the Australian Taxation Office when following up discrepancies; better clarifying certain definitions and the source of authority for payments of Commonwealth assistance; and correcting some minor oversights. However, the most significant change will be to repeal the sunset provision in the act so as to permit the data matching program to continue beyond 22 January 1994. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Sciacca, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill gives effect to four amendments to veterans' entitlements. The first deals with the government's budget announcement concerning eligibility for benefits under the veterans' children education scheme. Children of veterans who receive extreme disablement adjustment will now be eligible for assistance under the scheme. This measure will align the benefits available to children of extreme disablement adjustment pensioners with those available to children of totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners.

PARA.TAB: The three remaining measures are non-budget amendments. It is proposed to extend the sunset clause which governs the operation of advance pharmaceutical allowance. These provisions allow a lump sum payment of pharmaceutical allowance of up to seven payments to be made to chronically ill pensioners who have a high prescription drug use. Without this extension the sunset clause would repeal advance pharmaceutical allowance from 1 January 1994. The proposed amendment will extend the operation of the advance payments for a further 12 months. This will enable a review to take place on the pharmaceutical requirements of chronically ill persons who access these payments.

The second of the non-budget amendments deals with the assessment of allocated pensions and annuities. These types of investments are similar in structure to a managed investment and can be drawn upon by the purchaser at a rate and amount desired, until the balance of the account is exhausted. An allocated pension or annuity gives the purchaser some control over the amount of return and when it is received.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act does not expressly provide the rules under which this form of investment is assessed. The proposed amendment will align the assessment of allocated pensions and annuities with managed investments. This amendment will ensure consistency in the method of assessing allocated pensions and annuities with similar provisions in the Social Security Act. The last of the three non-budget amendments will change the definition of shares and listed securities. This definition was inserted into the act to provide that the income and assets value of shares was assessed in accordance with the managed investment rules. It defined shares as only those listed on a stock exchange in Australia. Concerns have been raised that, by limiting the application of the definition in this manner, it may be seen as an incentive for pensioners to divest themselves of their Australian shares.

This initiative proposes an amendment to the definition of shares and listed securities to ensure that it applies to both Australian and foreign sourced shares. It will align the treatment of shares and listed securities with similar provisions in the Social Security Act. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to implement the EC-Australia wine agreement. On 6 December 1992, I jointly announced with our wine industry that Australian and European Commission officials had negotiated the text of a bilateral wine agreement aimed at improving our bilateral wine trade. This announcement attracted wide media attention, and rightly so, as the European Community is Australia's largest export market for wine.

PARA.TAB: During 1992-93, Australian winemakers exported 44 million litres worth $144 million to the EC, or almost half of our total exports of $293 million. This agreement will guarantee our continued access to the EC market which will remain the key market as our wine industry strives to lift exports to $1 billion by the year 2000.

This agreement is a vital part of the strategy to further lift exports. As I have said, the target is $1 billion by the year 2000. It should not be forgotten that we have increased exports fourteenfold since 1985-86 from $21 million to the $293 million to which I previously referred.

This legislation enables the agreement to enter into force and our winemakers to enjoy its benefits. The agreement provides for the mutual recognition of each party's winemaking practices and standards; it affords mutual protection to each party's geographical indications—that is, the names of our wine regions such as Coonawarra and Hunter Valley; it reduces the number of analyses the EC requires of Australian wines from eight to three; it allows Australian winemakers to market wines in the EC labelled with multi-varietal and multi-regional blends; and it allows the export of Australian sweet wines, such as the justly famous De Bortoli `Noble One', to the European Community, which was previously not permitted. Importantly, it prevents either party from introducing additional certification requirements on imports of each other's wines.

The agreement recognises the importance of European geographical indications to the European Community. It also recognises the widespread use of EC names on Australian wines. The agreement provides for the gradual phase-out of our use of EC geographical indications according to their commercial importance.

There are four tranches of EC names to be protected. A list of thousands of EC geographical names which are of no commercial significance to us will be protected immediately the agreement enters into force. The second tranche is of little used names, such as `Frascati' and `White Bordeaux', which will be phased out on 31 December this year. A further group of names of some importance to us, such as `Chianti' and `Madeira' must be phased out by 31 December 1997.

The last tranche includes names which are widely used by our winemakers, names like `Claret', `Chablis' `Burgundy' and `Champagne'. Phase-out periods for these names have yet to be determined but the agreement provides that negotiations on phase-out dates for these names must be concluded by 31 December 1997.

We have used European geographical names to denote a style of wine for more than a hundred years. Migrants often brought these names to Australia and used them to describe a familiar style of wine; the names have become generic. Names like `champagne' have been used to describe a dry sparkling wine. Once protection commences, both European and Australian geographical indications will only be used to indicate the true place of origin of the wine. Thus the name `champagne' will only be used to describe wine made in the Champagne region of France.

The agreement provides for additional phase-out periods to clear stock from wholesalers and retailers. Australian wine made prior to the phase-out period for production labelled with the protected EC names may be marketed by wholesalers for up to three years and by retailers until stocks are exhausted. Australian winemakers have already begun using varietal and brand names to replace European geographical indications.

The bill also provides for the protection of traditional wine expressions. Words such as `brut' or `reserve' are frequently used to indicate a certain quality or style of wine. Under the bill, traditional expressions may only be used to describe wine which originates in the country in which the expression has been traditionally and consistently used. The lists of both Australian and EC traditional expressions are still under negotiation by the two parties to the agreement. The bill provides for protection to commence when the traditional expressions are entered in a register. This will occur after negotiations on protection of traditional names are concluded.

The agreement has the strong support of the peak wine industry body, the Winemakers Federation of Australia. Wine industry representatives were fully involved in the negotiations on the agreement from the outset. The agreement has strong support throughout the European Community.

The bill establishes a Geographical Indications Committee to determine the boundaries of Australian geographical indications. EC regulations require that where wine exported to the EC is labelled with a geographical indication, the boundaries of that region must be defined precisely.

Where does Coonawarra end and Riverland start? This question is just as relevant for Australian wine consumers as it is for the EC requirements. By defining the boundaries of our geographical indications, this bill will give greater certainty to enforcement of the label integrity program provisions of the act, which require winemakers to keep records to substantiate label claims of the vintage, variety or geographical indication of wine. The bill will give consumers the guarantee that when wine is labelled `Coonawarra', the grapes from which the wine was made came from within the defined boundaries of the Coonawarra region.

The Geographical Indications Committee will comprise a Winemakers Federation of Australia nominee, a nominee of the Wine Grape Growers Council of Australia and an Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, AWBC, nominee. The committee will publish proposed determinations and seek submissions from winemakers and grape growers and their organisations on the boundaries of Australian wine regions. There will be appeal rights to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court.

The bill establishes a registrar of geographical indications and traditional expressions who will be an employee of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The registrar will list all geographical indications determined by the committee, list the protected EC names and inform other countries of Australia's protected names.

The Winemakers Federation of Australia has applied to the National Food Authority to have the Australian food standards code covering wine modernised and brought more closely into line with EC standards. The NFA application, even if accepted in its entirety, will not authorise all EC winemaking practices. There are some EC standards which the Australian wine industry does not want to adopt for wine made in Australia. The bill authorises the import of wine from the EC which conforms with the compositional requirements set down in the agreement and allows these standards to be varied from time to time by agreement as EC winemaking practices change. The EC practices differ in minor ways and in ways which do not affect health, from the standards set by the National Food Authority for sale of Australian and imported wine. EC wine will still have to comply in all other respects with Australian standards, for example with regard to labelling with alcoholic content.

The EC-Australia wine agreement is the first of several agreements on wine we intend to conclude with our major wine trading partners. Work is already under way on developing a wine agreement with New Zealand. The bill therefore amends the objects of the act to include implementing the EC-Australia wine agreement; enabling Australia to implement further international agreements relating to trade in wine; and defining Australian geographical indications for wine. It extends the powers and functions of the AWBC to cover administration of the EC-Australia wine agreement and the definition of Australian geographical indications.

The bill creates several new offences. The offences include the false or misleading use of geographical indications and traditional expressions for wine. However, winemakers will continue to be able to use their individual name and the individual name of their predecessor in business, in the course of trade, even where that name is the same as the name of a protected geographical indication.

The bill also amends the act to allow regulations to be made concerning blending rules for wine and the composition of export wine. These regulations will not be activated until there has been further consultation with the wine industry, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and the National Food Authority. The bill also allows the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to prescribe the grape varieties which may be used in making wine. This will prevent the use of hybrid grape varieties in export wine, which is a concern in some export markets. The bill will have no financial impact.

This bill and the agreement it seeks to implement present challenges for our wine industry, including the opportunity to consolidate our position in the world market. It represents a landmark commitment by our industry and a true sign that our industry has come of age internationally. It removes technical trade barriers to our wines on EC markets. More importantly, it provides the important basis for continued future access to this market. I commend the bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

Bill presented by Mr Johns, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The sale of CSL Ltd is an important part of the government's micro-economic reform program. The decision to sell CSL by way of an initial public offering of shares is consistent with this government's desire for Australia's pharmaceutical manufacturing base to grow stronger, with linkages to international markets. For CSL to compete effectively in the international marketplace and to achieve its full growth potential, it requires greater financial and management flexibility to secure capital and pursue its internationalisation goals. The public float of CSL will enable it to achieve this potential and will release the Commonwealth from its incongruous position of being owner, as well as customer and regulator of the company.

PARA.TAB: CSL was established by the Australian government in 1916 to help meet the pharmaceutical needs of an isolated nation then at war. Following the implementation in 1989 of a reform package which corporatised its operations, CSL is now an unlisted government owned public company with assets of $238 million and sales for last year exceeding $160 million.

CSL is an independent developer, manufacturer and marketer of ethical health care products. Its core expertise is in human and veterinary pharmaceutical and diagnostic products of biological origin, notably vaccines and blood plasma products. CSL's principal products include influenza and infant triple antigen vaccines, antivenoms and a variety of plasma derived products.

Significant levels of resources have been directed to research, development and commercialisation of core products. More than $18 million has been invested by CSL in research and development during the past year. The company is as export oriented as it is research based. It is actively internationalising its pharmaceutical, veterinary, diagnostic and plasma products business. Presently, 10 per cent of its revenues come from export sales and there are plans for further expansion in the future.

Based at its 12-hectare site at Parkville, Victoria, CSL employs 1,200 people and has sales and distribution branches in each mainland state. In addition, the construction of a highly advanced blood plasma fractionation plant is currently nearing completion at Broadmeadows in Victoria.

The government took a decision as part of the 1992-93 federal budget to sell all of its shares in CSL. After a detailed scoping study of the various sale options open to it, the government announced in November 1992 that the sale would proceed on the basis of an initial public offering of the whole of the government's 100 per cent shareholding. The flotation will occur in the second half of this financial year, depending upon market conditions and sale preparations.

The decision to float CSL was predicated on the company remaining independent, under Australian control and continuing its key role in providing blood products to the Australian community. The bill addresses these key issues by:
limiting the voting rights of significant foreign shareholders in regard to appointment, replacement and removal of company directors;
requiring that CSL's head office and principal fractionation activities be located in Australia; and
requiring that CSL remain incorporated in Australia and CSL's chairman and two-thirds of the board be Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: These arrangements will be complemented by an allocation of shares in CSL at point of sale as follows:

PARA.TAB: a limit of five per cent on all individual shareholdings, domestic or foreign;
an aggregate limit of 15 to 20 per cent on foreign shareholdings; and
preference for individuals and institutions over corporate shareholders.

SPEECH.PARA: This share allocation strategy aims to achieve a broad spread of shareholdings at the time of the float which, combined with market based incentives, should ensure an independent CSL into the future.

PARA.TAB: Continued supply of plasma products post-sale will be covered by a long-term contract between CSL and the Commonwealth. Supply of these products is a key national interest issue. Accordingly, provisions have been included in the sale bill to enable the Commonwealth, through the Minister for Health, to have direct access to the Federal Court in the event of a breach of the contract, and for the court to make orders to ensure continued performance.

There is also a prohibition on CSL disposing of, encumbering or granting any interest in the plasma products facility at Broadmeadows without the Commonwealth's consent. The plasma products supply contract will also restrict CSL's ability to dispose of plant and equipment, which is necessary to enable it to fulfil its contractual obligations. These provisions represent the best available protection of the national interest, consistent with the sale of CSL.

The bill now before the House contains the legislative changes that need to be made to enable the float of CSL to be finalised. Much of the bill is concerned with the removal of CSL from the ambit of Commonwealth legislation so that, post-sale, CSL will be the same as any other Australian pharmaceutical or health care company.

The government is committed to the protection of all CSL employees' rights which accrue during the period of government ownership, especially in cases where these rights accrue as a result of Commonwealth legislation. To this end, the bill provides for a number of savings provisions in respect of a variety of acts, such as the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976 and the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. These provisions will ensure, in particular, that employees of CSL do not lose the benefits that they will have accrued prior to sale.

Rights under the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act will apply for 12 months post-sale. In general, other rights not conferred by Commonwealth legislation will not be affected by the sale as the government is selling its shares in CSL and the CSL award will continue post sale.

The legislation contains transitional arrangements to provide certainty that CSL is freed from all legislative constraints which apply generally to Commonwealth business enterprises and to clarify the position in relation to rights and obligations which arise prior to the sale day.

The sale of CSL could leave the purchasers of CSL shares liable for certain state and territory taxes and fees. To avoid this liability, to reduce potential sale process complications and to increase the return to taxpayers, the sale is to be exempted from state and territory taxes and fees.

This bill puts in place a sound legislative framework to enable the public offering of the Commonwealth's shareholding in CSL to proceed. It provides the Commonwealth with security over CSL's role in fractionation while freeing CSL from obligations to the Commonwealth other than those of any publicly listed company. I commend the bill to the House, and I present the explanatory memorandum for the bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr O'Keefe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988, the ALTD Act, to extend the operation of the Australian land transport development trust fund. The Commonwealth government is allocating some $2.46 billion to fund roadworks on national highways over the three calendar years from 1 January 1994. This amendment will allow this to be funded from the current ALTD Act until new legislation is in force governing the new roads program.

PARA.TAB: This amendment will not alter the government's commitment to develop a new national highway act during 1994 to replace the ALTD Act 1988. The national highway act will create a more efficient road management system, with potentially great benefits to the taxpayer and road users. As part of this government's commitment to creating an appropriate roads administration program, a full consultative process is under way, involving state governments and major industry bodies.

Also, in developing the national highway bill the government will be taking into account reports from the Australian National Audit Office and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, both due to report to parliament later this year. As a result, the national highway bill for the post-1993 roads program will probably be introduced near the end of the current period of sittings, or early in the following period, with consideration and passage in 1994. Hence it is necessary to amend the ALTD Act to extend its operation and ensure that the federal roads program can continue to be delivered.

The introduction of this amendment will not alter the government's intention to fund the national highway system only from 1 January 1994. This commitment arose from the July 1991 Premiers Conference where it was agreed that road funding responsibility for each level of government should be more clearly defined and that each tier of government should concentrate on funding, planning and building roads that were clearly within their responsibility.
To provide the government with the ability to extend the current ALTD Act, three sunset clauses within the act require amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: .subsection 12(1) provides that road user revenue payments into the trust fund may only be made before 1 January 1994;
.subsection 12(2) provides that a proportion of refunds applicable to road user charges payable before 1 January 1994 be offset against road user charges payable into the trust fund; and
.section 25 provides that the trust fund shall be closed at the end of 30 June 1994.

The provisions of this amendment remove each of these final dates and give effect to a continuation of current ALTD trust fund arrangements. The proposed new national highway act would contain provisions for the closure of the ALTD trust fund.

PARA.TAB: Turning to details of the bill, clauses 1 and 2 contain the usual citation and commencement provisions. Clause 3(a) of the bill provides for the continuation of road user charge revenue payments into the trust fund beyond the date of 1 January 1994 which would otherwise apply. Clause 3(b) of the bill likewise provides for the continuation of the provision contained in subsection 12(2) of the act such that the proportion of refunds applicable to road user charges payable after 31 December 1993 be offset against road user charges payable into the trust fund.

Clause 4 of the bill provides for the continuation of the ALTD trust fund for an indefinite period or until it is repealed by the inclusion of an appropriate clause in a new act for administration of the federal roads program. The trust fund would otherwise close at the end of 30 June 1994. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

Bill presented by Dr Theophanous, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Childcare Rebate Bill 1993 will provide for the payment of rebates for expenses incurred for work related child care as announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 9 February 1993. This bill realises a key election promise to the families of Australia. It is another promise made and kept. The cash rebate is a major plank in this government's commitment to increase the number of child-care places, to make child care more affordable and to increase the choices for Australian families. It is an investment in our future.

PARA.TAB: This government recognises that women are unable to participate actively in the work force unless they have access to affordable child care. The skills of women with work force experience are extremely valuable in an economy dependent on the training and flexibility of the work force. The cash rebate will substantially increase the ability of women to work and to undertake further study and training. In short, it will allow them to contribute the full wealth of their talents and abilities to national growth and prosperity.

Child care is no longer a welfare issue. It is now an integral part of the government's approach to building a highly skilled and adaptable work force. The child-care rebate is part of the Labor government's comprehensive child-care policy. It recognises that most parents need quality child care at some stage of their working lives and that they need help with the cost of child care. The rebate will significantly improve the affordability of child care for working parents. It builds on this government's outstanding record of assisting families with dependent children through its support for child care.

When the Labor government was elected in 1983 there were just 46,000 operational child-care places. There are now more than 208,000 child-care places in Australia. Budget funding for an additional 29,000 places will lift the number to approximately 237,000 by the end of this financial year. This government has also promised to meet all demand for work related child care by the year 2001. This will mean an increase in places to more than 300,000 by 1996-97.

And we have put money where our mouth is. Commonwealth outlays have grown from $65 million in 1982-83 to over $550 million this financial year. As the places have grown, we have ensured that ordinary Australian families can afford to use the child-care facilities. This year alone, an estimated 170,000 low and middle income families will benefit from long day care child-care assistance of up to $108.50 a week. As well, the government has extended the more generous long day care child-care assistance to directly Commonwealth funded occasional care centres from 1 July 1993. This has benefited a further 20,000 low and middle income families.
In February 1993 the Prime Minister announced further initiatives to build on Labor's child-care commitment to families. These included:

SPEECH.PARA: the establishment of a care for sick children program. This will help employers establish sick care facilities and provide for suitable separate sick care facilities in child-care centres and family day care schemes.

To keep child care affordable, the fringe benefits tax exemption was also extended to approved employer sponsored family day care, outside school hours care and vacation care services on 1 July 1993. The 1993 budget legislation includes sales tax exemptions for goods used by child-care services.

To ensure quality care for Australian children, the new accreditation and quality assurance system will be implemented in child-care centres from 1 January 1994. This fulfils yet another election commitment. The 1993 budget provides funding to implement these initiatives.

The Childcare Rebate Bill 1993 is another important step to ensure that child care is affordable for all working families. Many families do not currently receive any government financial assistance for child care because their joint family income exceeds the threshold for child-care assistance or because they use informal care. From 1 July 1994, parents using child care while in employment, training, studying or looking for work will be able to claim a rebate for part of their child-care expenses. An estimated 230,000 families with 358,000 children will benefit from the scheme.

PARA.TAB: As the Prime Minister said in Investing in the Nation, the child-care rebate recognises that the cost of child care is a legitimate expense for parents earning an income. Just like other concessions for expenses incurred in earning an income, it will not be means tested. Tax deductions of $4.9 billion each year are provided for work related expenses, such as subscriptions for professional associations and trade unions, car expenses and professional libraries.

The introduction of the child-care rebate is a long overdue recognition of the costs of child care borne by parents, and particularly mothers, in earning an income. This bill recognises that all working families are entitled to some recompense against the cost of work related child care. And to ensure that the benefits flow on to low income families, the government took the more equitable decision to provide this assistance as a cash rebate. This will assist low income women and families because the rebate will be able to be claimed as the expense is incurred.

A deduction would have forced many families to carry these costs for more than a year before they could claim any benefit. It would also have provided greatest benefits to higher income earners. People below the tax threshold would not have benefited at all. Instead, the use of a rebate ties the level of the benefit to the cost of child care incurred by the parent and not to the level of taxable income.

The rebate will be payable fortnightly through Medicare offices of the Health Insurance Commission. Eligible families will pay the first $16 of weekly child-care costs and then be able to claim 30 per cent of their costs up to a fee ceiling of $110 per week for one child in care or $220 per week for two or more children in care. The maximum weekly rebate will be $28.20 per week for one child, or $1,466 per year, and $61.20 per week for two or more children, or $3,182 per year. The cash rebate is paid over and above child-care assistance.

The rebate will be paid for all work related child-care expenses for children aged up to 12 years of age. Child-care expenses incurred by working parents in long day care centres, preschools, family day care, outside school hours care, vacation care and private child-care arrangements will be eligible for the rebate. Child-care expenses incurred in care services not eligible for government assistance have also been included in recognition of the fact that almost two-thirds of working families use these care arrangements, either by choice or because formal care is not available.

Care can be provided in either the child's home or another person's home. Carers must be over 18 years old, and parents are excluded from claiming the cost of caring for their own children.Child-care providers, whether in formal child-care services or at home, will be required to register with the Health Insurance Commission through Medicare offices and provide proof of age, proof of compliance with relevant state licensing requirements and a declaration that they have a tax file number. Carers will be given a child-care provider number which must be quoted when issuing receipts for child-care payments.

To address the privacy concerns of parents and care providers, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has been consulting with the Privacy Commissioner. Let me stress that at no time will parents or providers be required to give details of their actual tax file number to the HIC. All they have to do is state whether they have a tax file number. The registration form for care providers will require a declaration that the care provider has a tax file number. If a carer provides a tax file number, the Health Insurance Commission must not record the information. Carers who advise that they have a tax file number will be given a care provider number which they must quote when issuing receipts for child-care expenses.

Families will be required to substantiate their work force status and the birth dates of their children. Families will have the option of allowing the Health Insurance Commission to use Medicare enrolment details to verify birth dates of children. Families will register with the Health Insurance Commission and be issued with a family registration number. Families will be able to claim the rebate by mail or in person at any one of 240 Medicare offices around Australia, in a similar fashion to the Medicare rebate. This will mean they will be able to get the rebate immediately across the counter. This arrangement will not only be familiar to many families but also reduce the need to establish a separate service.

To enable the Health Insurance Commission to begin preparations for the child-care rebate, the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Act 1993 was passed during the autumn sittings earlier this year. This government is committed to enabling parents to fulfil both their work and family responsibilities by ensuring that quality child care is affordable and accessible. The child-care rebate is a central part of that commitment. I have great pleasure in commending this historic bill to the House, and I present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION LIMITED SALE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, given that you were in the chair earlier today prior to the interruption of debate on the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited Sale Bill, I had sketched some of the background and current financial status of the corporation. Moreover, I foreshadowed some initial reservations and concerns that the coalition opposition had in regard to the bill before the House. More specifically, I would like now to outline in some detail why the opposition believes there is a whole range of unanswered questions and a number of potential difficulties in regard to the sale of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, otherwise known as SMEC.

PARA.TAB: The starting point for the coalition in privatising any government business is simply that, when a commercial sale takes place, it has to be that—commercially based and commercially presented. But what do we have in this bill? We have a staff buyout of the corporation, which the coalition has long supported, which raises more questions and issues than it answers. It is no wonder, in view of this, that negotiations over the sale of SMEC have been so drawn out for so long. All I can say is thank heavens SMEC was not a significant performing asset.

The staff buyout, which will be by way of Tinbury Ltd, a company formed by SMEC's employees, is to proceed on a basis which reduces the purchase price of the corporation as a going concern; that is, in order to lower the sale price the federal government is prepared to extinguish accumulated tax losses in exchange for recoupment through company tax at a later stage. There is nothing necessarily wrong about this process, but the bill tells us nothing about the extent of these tax losses, their likely impact on the Commonwealth's return from the sale, and the precedence for the Commonwealth acting in this way in the matter of the disposal of public business assets. Irrespective of SMEC's future, which is far from assured, is $1 million—SMEC's expected sale price—a decent return on a company about which we cannot even determine, for reasons I will explain shortly, the real value of its assets base? It is nothing more than a simple question which requires a simple answer.

The government knows the SMEC deal might fall through and the staff buyout might not be completed. The bill therefore provides for alternatives such as a trade sale. But, again, all of this is in the future, as are the terms on which eventual deals with whomever will eventually be struck. The bill now before the House has nothing to say about the details of these matters whatsoever. On this basis, I have no idea why the federal government is proceeding with legislation in anticipation of processes which are yet to unfold and about which the parliament knows nothing.

Look at one of the other issues raised in the legislation. The bill provides for the SMEC's sale to Tinbury—in the event that such a sale takes place—to be overturned and a money back guarantee provided should SMEC face liabilities arising from current legal proceedings.

Not all members may know, but in 1990 Victoria's Dartmouth Dam was forced to close after a serious construction related failure at the site which destroyed the hydro-electricity plant's generating facilities. In fact, only last week, by coincidence, after four years and some $94 million in costs, the dam was reopened.

The minister did mention this crucial matter briefly in his second reading speech and referred the House to SMEC's annual reports for further detail. Regrettably, as with most public bodies, the usefulness of SMEC's annual report in providing detail and objective and critical commentary on its own activities is paltry and the reference the minister cites is of no help whatsoever.

Notwithstanding this, as a result of the incident at Dartmouth Dam, the State Electricity Corporation of Victoria is suing several parties, including SMEC. Other parties have cross-claims targeting SMEC as well. The claims well exceed the corporation's own insurance cover and could lead to its liquidation. If this occurs, the Commonwealth—which has limited exposure to the legal claim, as I mentioned—intends through this bill to provide a money back guarantee to Tinbury, should it successfully buy out the corporation. Of course, with overhanging liabilities of this order, the actual value of SMEC's asset base—now at $9 million in net terms—is also questionable, a matter which further complicates the sale of the corporation.

We are now debating a sale bill which provides no detail whatsoever and which is simply envisaging a series of probable sale outcomes and other imponderables. On this basis, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) would have done well to have resisted calling the proposed sale of SMEC a key feature of the government's micro-economic reform agenda. The sale was forced on the government as the corporation fell over. The sale is nowhere close to being settled. Even the staff buyout proposal presented as the first option for the sale was adopted by the government only after the coalition promoted such a position. So this bill is not part of a systematic micro reform program; it is a hurried push to clear an asset off the books even before all the preparatory homework has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited Sale Bill today, we are dealing with an organisation which is unique in Australian history and has provided very great benefits for the states of Victoria and New South Wales. I think it has been responsible for achievements of which every single Australian is enormously proud.

PARA.TAB: It is with some degree of unpleasantness that I reflect upon the fact that, while our great athletes are lauded, great tributes are paid to them and they receive the general adulation of the greater Australian community, the people who have done so much over a protracted period of time to provide the substance and the backbone of the nation have been left as unsung heroes. When we move into committee I intend to move a small amendment because we are very worried that the results of this sale could result in the dismemberment of this corporation which has provided such an enormous benefit for Australia.

The shire councils in North Queensland have formed themselves into the North Australia Water Development Council to move along the development of a scheme often referred to as the Bradfield scheme. The scheme has been revised very dramatically from a report by a team of engineers—Gutteridge Haskins and Davey, Monro and Johnson, McIntyre and Associates and Cameron McNamara—to the Queensland government in 1984. That, plus the report done by the Office of Northern Development, indicated clearly, as much as anyone can project these things with very hard figures, that an outlay, a net capital cost, of $2.49 thousand million would produce an annual gross revenue—value of production, if you like—of $2.02 thousand million.

The revised Bradfield scheme was originally announced by the then Queensland government, and the then federal government under Malcolm Fraser put some $5 million into prefeasibility reports on the project. The whole of Australia welcomed the scheme with open arms and very great adulation. I might even use that very strong expression to describe the reaction of the Australian people. I and two other people—Dr Heidecker from Queensland University and Mr Roy Stainkey, a very prominent person in grazing circles in Queensland—received some 200 requests from the media to do interviews during the next week to two weeks, which showed similar massive universal reaction to the scheme as there was to the Snowy Mountains Authority project. For the first time, some hard figures exist on proposals that will work.

Former Senator Walsh was a great person for denigrating the scheme and referring to me and others as people who made water run uphill. So it probably bears comment that the major dam called Hell's Gates in the Burdekin River has a full supply level of 1,279 feet whereas the water is delivered onto the western plains below Hughenden at 1,079 feet. That is a sufficient head to give a flow of water from one point to the other, over 500 or 600 kilometres of canal. We are not trying to make water run uphill. In fact, we are facilitating the water to run downhill where it can be used away from areas where enormous damage can be done.

What I have said is relevant to the bill before the House because, if the talent and the accumulated wisdom are scattered to the four winds as a result of what is happening in the House today, we will not have the reservoir of knowledge and experience that is needed to undertake a scheme of this magnitude.

The computer program models that have to be put together to work out how much water will fall over at the point of exit and how much water can be taken out and delivered to a farm some 400 or 500 kilometres away are very complicated. We need to deal with people who know what they are doing and who are extremely experienced in this area. An engineering firm is extremely lucky if it gets to build a dam every two or three decades. It would be a very rare engineering firm that would have that honour. We have here a group of engineers who are doing this sort of work on a continuing basis not only in Australia but also overseas. The SMEC engineers—the engineering companies that undertook the project at the time—worked on the revised Bradfield proposals.

It is appalling that, once again, we find ourselves in the depths of a recession—in exactly the same position as we were in the 1930s—making exactly the same mistakes. It is deeply regrettable that the 223 people who represent Australia in this House and in the other place are not aware of the economic history of our nation. This stands in stark contrast with the performance of the United States government during the Depression when the Tennessee Valley Authority projects were undertaken and almost completed.

The Tennessee Valley Authority projects produced some 12,000 megawatts of electricity—not an awful lot less than we produce in the whole of Australia. The cost of that energy is nil because it is hydro-electric energy, the generation of which costs nothing. The building costs were also negligible. The workers at the time would have had to be paid unemployment benefits, so, in its wisdom, the United States government said that it was better to pay people to work rather than not work.

So the United States had this magnificent series of projects which delivered water to the farm gate throughout the Tennessee Valley Authority areas. These projects produced a huge amount of hydro-electricity and controlled the enormous flood damage that had occurred regularly throughout that area. In addition, the United States government built the biggest dam in the world, the Hoover Dam on the Colorado River, and planted some 2,000 square miles of trees to revitalise the mid-western plains area which had been damaged by land degradation in early United States history. All of those wonderful things were done during the Depression in the United States.

Instead of listening to Mr Theodore—who was the then federal Treasurer of Australia and who was disowned and thrown on the scrap heap by his own party, the ALP—in its wisdom, the government of the day listened to Dr Niemeyer from the Bank of England. He said that during this period the government must pull in its belt and spend nothing, which was about the most disastrous advice that could have possibly been given in a depression.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing over there? You should be over here.

—I cannot speak for the Liberal Party but, on the contrary, my own party has asserted these principles very strongly throughout its recent history. There was a change in attitude in Canberra at that time which Arthur Fadden had a lot to do with. I cannot help but mention the Spooner proposals in New South Wales which were eventually accepted by the rest of Australia. But that happened very late—the war was almost upon Australia before the government eventually started to do something. But in sharp contrast with the United States, our country achieved absolutely nothing in that period. One-third of our entire work force were paid to sit on their backsides and do nothing whilst almost starving to death.

PARA.TAB: We now find ourselves with an effective unemployment rate of 15 per cent or 20 per cent. If one takes out the increases in all the mickey mouse proposals called work training schemes facilitated by the ALP to hide its unemployment figures, we are talking about vast numbers of people lying idle, doing nothing, while some 20,000 pieces of heavy equipment lie rusting and rotting, doing absolutely nothing as well. Rather than pay a person to sit down and do nothing, the government should pay that person to climb up on the bulldozer, press the starter button and dig a channel from one point to another. This is really not a great deal more complicated than the other things I have outlined to the House.
It never ceases to amaze me how the ALP government insults the intelligence of the Australian nation by claiming that it was responsible for a wonderful recovery in 1983-84.

TALK.START.PARA: —It rained.

—That is exactly right. In 1983-84 it rained and that is what caused the turnaround in Australia, not the change in government. And because it did not rain in 1981-82 and 1982-83, in 1982-83 alone the estimated losses were $7.5 billion, and I have extracts of figures that I can produce for the House.

PARA.TAB: The 1965-66 drought was of such dimensions that its effects were documented. The direct losses were estimated to be $1.5 billion. That would indicate, with a multiplier effect of two, that we have here losses approaching $4.5 billion at 1965 value. To equate that with today's value, we would need to double that figure and probably double it again in order to demonstrate the vast panorama of human destruction that was occasioned by that drought.

The Snowy Mountains scheme enables us to drought-proof one-tenth—maybe as much as one-fifth—of the entire arable area of our nation, so that part of the continent which is not desert can be used productively. It is a disgrace to each and every Australian that almost one-fifth of the surface area of Queensland—this rich black soil varying in depth from 18 to 35 inches over this vast area of land—is presently producing virtually nothing of value.

Every single, solitary sugar mill in North Queensland has what is called a productivity council in the super wet belt between Townsville and Cairns—or between Ingham, Babinda and Gordonvale, if you like. The productivity council exists to try to come up with ways and means of dealing with the waterlogging and flooding problems in the super wet belt. Most of the towns in this area receive between 100 to 300 inches of rain every year and thus have an immense problem with flooding.

In fact, the problem in Ingham is so serious that if that area had a simultaneous flood in the upper Herbert and in the lower Herbert—and this most certainly will happen—the emergency services predict the loss of some 250 lives. As luck would have it, in the last 100 years flooding has occurred twice in the lower Herbert and three times in the upper Herbert but has never occurred simultaneously. But that most certainly occurred in black man's history, in the history of the first Australians, because the legend for the Ingham area is water from mountain to mountain when the whole coastal plain went under water. That is exactly what will happen with a simultaneous flood.

Like in the Tennessee Valley, there is a very good reason why the flooding needs to be controlled. Cameron McNamara in the report on the Herbert River said that the losses were $30 million a year. Admittedly, that was in a series of very bad flood years, but the losses were quoted in that report as being $30 million a year just for one town, Ingham. And there are half a dozen towns of that size in the super wet belt.

We do not want to see scattered to the four winds the enormous reservoir of knowledge, experience and intellectual wisdom called the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. We hope that when we move a small amendment later it will be considered favourably by the government. I am sure that no member of this House would like to see this magnificent corporation dismembered and that accumulated wisdom and knowledge—

TALK.START.PARA: —Lost forever.

—That is right. Without it, it would be extremely difficult for this country to proceed with the next giant step it must take—namely, the Bradfield proposals. The Clarence River diversion proposals in New South Wales most certainly should be the step that this country should take after that.

PARA.TAB: If we are to move forward, we can look at the Snowy Mountains and be very proud of what we achieved. We can achieve exactly the same things up there, as well as in northern New South Wales. But we cannot do so if we do not have a corps of people similar to the United States corps of engineers who achieved all of those wonderful things during the Great Depression in that country. At the present time, we are making exactly the same mistakes that were made during the Great Depression in exactly the same place; that is, the federal parliament of Australia. In fact, it was one of the state governments that eventually showed the way—which, of course, America had taken seven years prior to us. America hardly expected over 20 per cent unemployment. At one stage, we had over 33 per cent unemployment in this country. Unfortunately, that was for an extended period of time, whereas the period during which the United States had over 17 per cent unemployment was very brief.

Would anyone in this place seriously question the fact that we have 15 per cent unemployment at present? Can anyone seriously say to me that it is better to pay these people not to work instead of paying them to climb up on one of those 20,000 pieces of heavy equipment that are rusting and rotting away at the present moment and do something which is of such benefit to this nation that every year, $2,000 million extra in export earnings will flow into this nation?

I will conclude on this point. People say, `Where will you find the markets for this product?'. That is dealt with in the report by the Office of Northern Development. By the year 2009, in around 15 years time, there will be an extra 536 million mouths to feed in the countries with which we trade—the countries ringing the Pacific basin. One-third of those people are the wealthiest people on earth. They live in the United States, Canada and Japan. Another third of them are in the greatest growth nations in the world. China's annual GDP growth is 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. We have allowed a great deal of latitude to the honourable member for Kennedy, but the reality is that this has absolutely nothing to do with the bill.
