DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PROCTEXT.PARA: COGNATE BILL:

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Dr Theophanous:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 amends a number of acts. They are: the Disability Services Act 1986; the Health Insurance Act 1973; the Hearing Services Act 1991; the National Health Act 1953; the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992; the Nursing Homes and Hostels (Legislation Amendment) Act 1986; and the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.

PARA.TAB: Part 2 of this bill, namely clauses 3 to 5, deals with the Disability Services Act amendments; and part 8, namely clauses 28 to 52 inclusive, deals with amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act. I shall briefly address parts 3 to 7 inclusive first and then deal with parts 2 and 8 in turn.

Clauses 6 to 13 of the bill amend certain aspects of the Health Insurance Act which particularly affect pathology authorities. These amendments are designed to do a number of things. Firstly, they ensure that not more than one pathology authority controls a pathology laboratory so that there can be no Medicare benefit double-dipping. Secondly, they require pathology authorities, in circumstances where practitioners leave an authority, to obtain request forms for pathology services. Thirdly, they impose penalties on pathology authorities for providing authority request forms which are different from the approved forms. Fourthly, they provide that a pathology authority which is a partly or wholly owned state, territory or public authority is not an approved pathology authority. Fifthly, they allow the relevant Minister for Health to review after 12 months a determination allowing an approved pathology authority to operate additional collection centres, and one amendment also extends to an authority a right of review of the minister's decision. Sixthly, they make a minor change to the way in which licence fees are reimbursed to an authority if permission to operate a collection centre is cancelled. The coalition does not oppose these technical amendments.

Part 4 of the bill, clauses 14 to 17 inclusive, amends the Hearing Services Act to make it clear that war widows qualify for hearing services. It also gives protection to the official symbol of the Australian Hearing Services, and this symbol is covered by schedule 2 to the act. The coalition welcomes those amendments.

Part 5 of the bill, clauses 18 to 21 inclusive, amends the National Health Act to allow pharmacists who relocated before the 1990 restructuring arrangements to continue to supply pharmaceutical benefits, and also to allow the signatory, where approval is granted in these circumstances, to cancel approval for the earlier premises. I note that the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) states that the objective of this measure is `to prevent an injustice which might otherwise occur'. The amendment has the effect of deeming, as approved, new premises of those approved pharmacists who relocated without obtaining approval. The coalition supports those amendments.

Part 6 is a minor amendment to the provisions relating to positions on the Australian Health Ethics Committee. Apparently the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 contains a typographical error. This is not actually stated in the parliamentary secretary's second reading speech. However, when reading the amendment in the bill, we are apprised that the purpose of the amendment before us today is to ensure that such nominations as are received for the National Health and Medical Research Council come from learned `academies' and not `academics' as the act presently states. The coalition will not oppose that amendment.

Part 7, clauses 24 to 27 inclusive, amends the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1986 by repealing subsection 25(2) and section 38. These sections have not been proclaimed and relate to provisions no longer needed, and naturally the coalition will support them.

I now turn to part 2 of the bill, clauses 3 to 5 inclusive, which amends the Disability Services Act 1986. The coalition is very concerned about clause 4 of this part. The parliamentary secretary's second reading speech states that the amendments to part 2 were of a `minor nature'. With respect to clause 4, which amends section 14J of the principal act, the speech contains the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the amendment . . . will make it clear that the statements which the minister is permitted to make under the section, regarding funded organisations' breaches of prescribed standards under the act, will not become the subject of a defamation action nor will any person who fairly reports or summarises the statement be liable for defamation. This amendment restates the common law. The provision should save litigation costs.

I have been advised that statements by the minister as authorised by section 14J of the act presently enjoy qualified privilege under common law, because the statement is made in accordance with an established law. It would therefore seem unnecessary to restate the common law. This has not been deemed to be necessary at any time until now. The second reading speech gives no explanation as to why this restatement is now necessary. This is a quite unprecedented section.

PARA.TAB: The coalition wants to know whether the government wishes to claim any precedents for this clause. Our investigations have revealed none. Given that there are no precedents for this action, why does the government claim that it is now necessary in this case? What actions have been taken by the minister in the past against this clause?

As I indicated, the second reading speech refers to the fact that this amendment will `save litigation costs'. Of course, if people are barred from suing, litigation costs are saved. It has made us curious as to just how much litigation has been incurred by the minister when carrying out his duties, or attempting to carry out his duties, in relation to this area.

Finally, if it is not a case of what has happened in the past, is it a case of what the minister anticipates will happen in the future? Does the minister expect to deal differently with the relevant organisations in the future, or does he know something about the intentions of certain organisations towards him, and about legal action that might thus be precluded?

As I said, the second reading speech claims that an effect of this clause would be to save litigation costs. At least, it says it should save litigation costs. There is a difference between `is' and `should'. Litigation costs are saved if the action is won. Under the present law as it relates to defamation, if one is sued unsuccessfully by someone, then one can claim costs against that person. On the other hand, if the person suing is successful, then it is open to that person to apply for an order for costs.

I do not, therefore, see the justification of the argument for the need for this clause as being to save costs. Persons save costs if they are in the right. If the minister is acting properly under the act—and he is authorised to do a number of things under the act—then that should not be a problem. However, if this clause is intended to extend the ability of the minister to behave in certain ways which would otherwise lead to defamation actions, I fear that this could lead to a very substantial and serious reduction of rights that are available to Australian citizens now.

I will refer briefly to what the act presently allows. It sounds a bit technical at first, but that is only because we have to keep referring back to other clauses. In fact, eventually we come to the end of the trail of references to other clauses, and at that stage it is all pretty clear—if we have taken long enough to look up all of them. Section 14J at the moment says that if the minister has made a declaration under section 14G, the minister may make available to the public, in any way the minister thinks fit, any or all of the following information:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) the eligible organisation's name and address;
(d) the name and address of the service that is the subject of the declaration;
(e) the terms of the Minister's declaration under section 14G;
(f) details of the eligible organisation's failure to meet the applicable standards in respect of the provision of the service;
(g) the actions taken in respect of the eligible organisation's failure to meet the applicable standards.

To make that just a little more intelligible, the heading under which this section appears in the act is `Information about Minister's declaration may be made available to the public'. Section 14G, which is referred to in section 145, appears under the heading, `Failure to meet applicable standards in the provision of service'. So it has to do with the withdrawal of funding from those organisations that are not meeting the applicable standards. Section 14G allows the minister to make a declaration stating that the eligible organisation is not meeting the applicable standards in respect of the provision of the service, and consequently is in breach of the condition of the grant. That all seems quite reasonable, and we have not objected to that in the past.

PARA.TAB: Section 14G goes on, however, to say that the minister must provide a copy of the declaration to the eligible organisation concerned. Section 14H says that the minister must not make a declaration under section 14G unless a disability standards review panel has been established; that requirements of the orders have been complied with; that the minister has complied with guidelines in force under section 5 that relate to the making of such a declaration; that an eligible organisation has applied under the orders to the panel for a review; and that the minister, in making the declaration, has had regard to the recommendations made by the panel. That spells it out a little further and shows that the minister has a fair amount of latitude. Section 5, referred to in section 14H, says:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.(1) The Minister must formulate principles and objectives to be furthered and guidelines to be complied with in the administration of this Act.

In summary, therefore, the minister has a lot of power to decide just what he wants to have happen—which is right and proper. Governments ought to have that power. However, if the minister is of a mind to withdraw someone's grant, then that organisation also has some rights, and they relate to the disability standards review panel. The minister, however, must only take regard of the recommendations of the panel. He is not bound by them. He can still go ahead and decide not to extend the grant, or renew the grant, or whatever. He may also make public certain information.

PARA.TAB: In summary, all of that seems to me to be a fair enough balancing of the government's right of policy, a minister's power to make sure that policy is being carried out, and some protection against arbitrariness—or fears of arbitrariness—by government or a minister. There is a review process, the outcome of which is public. The minister does not have to follow its recommendations therefore it is all the more mystifying why the minister now seems to need this new protection.

As I said a few minutes ago, my information is that the Minister for Health has qualified privilege under common law. I am not a lawyer but I know a little about defamation actions—I have been down that path, but not against a minister. This privilege derives from the fact that he is empowered to do certain things under the act. However, this is qualified, to the extent it should be by common law. That common law protects the rights of the litigant.

Some honourable members seem to think that when words uttered in this chamber appear in a speech in a Hansard, they are totally protected from any defamation action. They are not. If any one of us—or somebody else—were to take an extract from Hansard and circulate or promulgate it maliciously, that protection would not apply. In publishing maliciously, the protection is not there. So there are limits on privilege in this place—rightly so. The protection of parliamentary privilege enables us to raise things that we need to put on the record and that otherwise may not be able to be raised. But malice is a different issue entirely.

I fear that we could obliterate rights, whether of people or organisations, that could lead to injustice through this proposed amendment of section 14J. Those rights are now available in the case of malice, for example, but presumably would disappear once we take away the right of action for defamation. The coalition would like the questions I posed earlier answered by the minister—and we want a good answer. I foreshadow that, if we do not get it, at the committee stages of the bill the coalition will vote against clause 4.

Finally, part 8, clauses 28 to 52, of the bill amends the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. The most significant changes are, firstly, to allow the Therapeutic Goods Administration—TGA—to evaluate goods which, under the transitional provisions of the 1989 act, were listed or registered without evaluation. Secondly, it gives effect to an international convention on the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, which allows for mutual exchange of manufacturing information, thus removing the need for overseas inspections by the importing country. Thirdly, it extends the definition in the Therapeutic Goods Act of authorised persons who could be called on to assist, to include members of the Australian Federal Police. Fourthly, it claims to facilitate the introduction of complementary state and territory therapeutic goods legislation.

It is this last change about which the coalition expresses a qualification here in the House of Representatives. We indicate that this matter may be pursued further when this bill is debated in the Senate. Whilst the last meeting of Commonwealth-state health ministers agreed that there was a need for complementary therapeutic goods legislation, none of the state ministers—as I understand it—was consulted by the Commonwealth government on the specific amendments now under debate. Even if one or more of the state ministers was consulted, several certainly were not. As the second reading speech states, it is necessary for complementary state and federal legislation to be introduced in support of the regulatory framework that the Commonwealth legislation establishes. Surely it would have been desirable for the draft of this proposed amendment to go to the state ministers to enable them to comment in advance whether this bill presents any difficulties which would make implementation in their respective states a problem, or even maybe to suggest a better way of going about it.

Whilst we will not take any action in relation to the passage of this part of the bill here in the House of Representatives, the coalition is seeking more information in relation to state ministers' views on the legislation, and reserves its right to take different action in the Senate. So far as the second bill that we are debating in this cognate debate is concerned, the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill, the coalition is not opposed to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) reflects the wide range of diverse health programs in Australia. As has been outlined by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), it covers quite a large range of services that are very much part of Australian society and part of the kinds of health services and programs we offer. In particular, it looks at the Disability Services Act and the dispersal of assets by organisations into which the Commonwealth government has had input. It provides the ability to garnishee some of those assets to see what we can gain. It also looks at the need for organisations to meet required standards, given that this is what they are funded for.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Moncrieff has expressed some concerns in relation to defamation laws. My concern is that organisations which are given taxpayers' money to provide particular services for people—we as taxpayers should demand them for people in our community who are least able, those with very special needs—should provide them in the very best way possible. The public should be informed of any fall in standards. We see it as a question of accountability. We, as a community, need to be assured that our money is being spent in the best possible way. In that disability area we have seen the implementation of the Disability Discrimination Act, which has brought developments in work, accommodation, leisure and independence of people with disabilities and special needs. The kinds of services which we offer and that people are demanding should be those we are funding people for.

We are saying that, while this may be a question of law, it is also a question of community standards. While this whole question of what is under privilege is debated, it is the right of the community at large to know and be assured that their money will provide the kinds of services which they believe the community should provide for people with disabilities and that this need is met in the right way. The public has a right to information on organisations' failures to meet applicable standards in the provision of services. We have heard great detail, recently, of accountability. We have seen a whole range of issues discussed in the Senate estimates committees. It is one of the great television shows in town at times.

I suggest that the kinds of provisions in this legislation are an insurance for all of us; that people with special needs in our community are having them addressed, and that the money we supply as taxpayers and a community is provided in an appropriate way. We have a right to know if things are not going well.

As we become better informed as a community, and as people with special needs and disabilities recognise their entitlements under the Disability Discrimination Act, our more informed community will demand the services it acknowledges to be a right and part of our democratic country. As part of the health services of this country, services to people with disabilities need to be questioned constantly, looked at and extended.

A number of other areas are covered. One concerns pathology services. As many of us who have been in parliament for some time will know, there has been a great debate about the level of pathology services, the pathology reforms which happened in 1991 and the demand of the community to have access to services at a reasonable cost.

Those reforms address the objective of cost efficiency through a planned reduction in the number of specimen collection centres through a licensing system. This amendment continues to address the number of licences; the whole question of discretion of the minister; and the question of hardship. At the core of this issue is the need for all of us as Australians to have access to pathology services at a reasonable cost. This bill implements measures that allow for the determination to grant licences in special cases. I think the community quite justifiably demands yet again an acknowledgment that pathology services are available to people in need; that they are at a reasonable cost; that we, as taxpayers, are assured that our money is being spent in the best possible way; that there is not double dipping; and that the kinds of pathology services that people need are the services to which they have access. But they are not overserviced and people should not be—to use the old word—double dipping. I see pathology services as very much a part of our daily health program. Australians have an entitlement under Medicare to access to general practitioners and to other specialist services. It is up to all of us to ensure that those services are developed and maintained at a cost efficiency level, but also that we continue to ensure that Australians generally have access to them.

As well as that, this bill covers the National Acoustics Laboratory, and it expands on the existing definition of `eligible persons' to include holders of a dependent treatment entitlement card. These people are departmental veterans' affairs beneficiaries. It also preserves the National Acoustics Laboratory's symbol. I think that is something of which we can justifiably be proud. Australians should be very proud of the work which the National Acoustics Laboratory does. It provides a whole range of services to people with hearing impairment, and it has been very highly praised. It has earned both national and international recognition in the way that it operates. To be able to expand this service, to define whom our beneficiaries are, and to maintain the symbol of something which is theirs is recognition yet again of the singular and very important work which they do. The nature of that work is highly prized, not just by the clients of the National Acoustics Laboratory but indeed by all Australians, because we all prize excellence. We all prize work which is done and which we seek acknowledgment for. Within the recognition and maintenance of that symbol, we see a treatment of it. There seems to be no area that is left untouched by this particular health services bill.

Another question of equity and justice lies in the area of pharmacy relocation. Some people relocated pharmacy premises before 18 December 1990, and they may not be technically entitled to the moneys for dispensing which they have been given. So this is a question of justice to ensure that people who have gone in good faith to these pharmacies and continue to be served by them are entitled to the money which has already been given. We all remember the kinds of difficulties which the pharmacy boards and the pharmaceutical associations and societies went through in terms of that whole relocation process—the lack of question of market forces, and the needs and demands of us as a community to have access to pharmacies without being extremely overserviced or pharmacists finding themselves doing everything to maintain their service rather than to dispense goods.

In that whole area of the relocation of pharmacies and the dispersion of various pharmacies, some people relocated without getting the necessary permission. We may find that difficulties could arise. So this bill addresses that matter. Yet again, this amendment focuses on the needs of people—people who need to be able to access dispensing pharmacies as part of our health program. So we, as a government, are ensuring that those needs can and will continue to be met. There is no question of that not happening.

Another area which is covered by this bill is nursing homes. As honourable members would know, this government has been committed, through its age care policy, to an expansion of nursing homes. It has also provided that nursing homes and specifications for government nursing homes will be covered by the National Health Act of 1988. That act endeavoured to do a whole range of things but in particular in relation to nursing homes it provided us with a whole series of specifications for the way in which government moneys could be spent. This bill repeals some parts of legislation which are made redundant by that particular act.

So it is quite important that we address those issues and ensure that the National Health Act, which deals with specifications for government nursing homes, is the prime act, and that people in nursing homes have, and continue to have, the support of the government in its whole range of services which it now offers to the aged. The whole role of nursing home proprietors and the government in the treatment of people in nursing homes and hostels has been covered by a whole range of rights and responsibilities in nursing homes. We have seen a focus of the community on people in nursing homes; demands of people in nursing homes; and a question of advocates. We see this as a client centred program. This yet again continues that kind of work which this government has done.

The other major area which this Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill covers is the Therapeutic Goods Act. As honourable members would be aware, early in 1993 the ministers for health in all states and territories reaffirmed an earlier agreement that a national uniform approach to the regulation of drugs was required. It would seem we are a very mobile country. Most people would know that 25 per cent of Australia's school children move interstate every year. So if we have a quarter of our school children moving interstate, a lot of other people are obviously moving interstate as well. A uniform system for controls of therapeutic drugs is important. We, as a national government, manage the national health program through Medicare, so it is important that therapeutic drugs are addressed in a national way. It would be seen to be necessary for this to happen. The state and territory ministers themselves have said that this is a very important proposal, and they support it.

The other provisions that this gives effect to are Australian's obligations under the convention for mutual recognition of inspections in respect of the manufacture of pharmaceutical products. Australia takes very seriously its international conventions. I think we would all recognise that there is a need for approval of overseas manufacturing sites for the supply of raw and finished materials to Australian therapeutic goods and manufacturers. We need to be assured, as an Australian community, that the kinds of standards which we maintain here in relation to the manufacture of goods is maintained overseas. None of us wants to see those standards diminish. We believe that it is vitally important to all of us as consumers that this is maintained. So this bill enables those overseas manufacturing sites to be inspected and to facilitate that.

This bill also looks at the Australian register of therapeutic goods and enables kits and other things designated as kits to be registered. There are a couple of important provisions in this bill in terms of breaches of the act in relation to the use of the Australian Federal Police. Perhaps one other important recommendation is that this bill enables the determinations of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee in its report to be made public. I think that is particularly important, because this recommendation was always intended for implementation in Professor Baume's report. This amendment enables that to happen.

Many of us are very concerned about the way in which drugs are evaluated in Australia. We like to pride ourselves on the quality of our drugs and services. This government has had a very large education program—indeed, some of our major service organisations have been part of that—to ensure that people do not keep drugs too long and do not overuse drugs, but use drugs in the right way. It is also important that the work and findings of the Drug Evaluation Committee become public. That is in line with Professor Baume's recommendations.

We are seeing more and more a need for the community to be given information, to know what is happening and to be part of its own health programs so that people can make informed decisions. As we become a more complex, sophisticated and better educated community, it is important that all information in relation to services, particularly health services, is available for us to read. I am delighted to see that those recommendations are there.

I think all of these amendments to this act reflect the Australian health system. Only recently President Clinton has come to power in the United States of America and Mrs Hillary Clinton has gained quite some acclaim for her work in trying to develop a national health service there. It makes us Australians realise how much we take for granted the access we have through Medicare to specialist services, hospitalisation and, of course, a whole range of other services. They are very much a part of the Australian community. The community sees access to those services as a right and entitlement so it is incumbent upon the government to ensure that those services are delivered in a fair and equitable way and that they are delivered in a cost-efficient way to ensure that taxpayers' money—which is, after all, the community's money—is spent in the very best way. We are assured that the community wants the accountability procedures in some of these amendments. It is important that we endorse the kinds of amendments that are in this legislation which focus on delivery of service to clients to ensure the very best for all Australians, irrespective of who they may be.

Indeed, some of the people who are covered by this legislation are people with very special needs, who are covered under the Disability Discrimination Act and the Disability Services Act. There are people who have particular needs in relation to hearing. There are people who need to access both pharmaceutical drugs and therapeutic goods. There are people who are in nursing homes, and people who are seeking the services of pathologists. So there is a wide range of Australians in our community who are covered by this legislation, and they are all people who are deserving of our special consideration. They are people who do not enjoy the kinds of privileges which many of us do, and they are certainly people who do not enjoy good health and access to services in the way that we take for granted.

It is incumbent upon us as a government to ensure that the services to those people in our community who are in need and deserving of our attention are delivered in the most just, fair and equitable way, that they are cost-efficient and that they are the kinds of services for which we are paying. It is important that we look at this whole range of measures in a context of client delivery and also in the context of Australia's own medical services. I recommend these amendments to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly on the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I wish to comment on a problem that has arisen continually in Kennedy. A number of the complaints have been concerned with beche-de-mer, but a number of other complaints are that the net being cast by the Therapeutic Goods Act is being thrown far wider than it needs to be thrown. Something like one in five people have severe sinus problems. They have to take regular medication and some of the capsules that they have to take are extremely expensive. I have been told by pharmacists—I do not know whether it is accurate information I am being given—that the costs of a lot of these items have been spectacularly increased because they come under the net cast by the Therapeutic Goods Act. It seems to me we could be facilitating an even wider casting of that net.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of health foods, a lot of people question the therapeutic or health value of a lot of things such as beche-de-mer, to cite an example. In this particular case it comes from a culture a lot older than ours. I bring it to the attention of the House that some of the claims made for fish over the years have been seen to be wildly exaggerated, but recent studies indicate quite clearly that the reason why countries where people do not eat meat have a very low rate of heart problems compared with those countries where people do eat meat is not the lack of meat but because of what is called the E. factor in fish oil. It is the consumption of fish that accounts for the low rate. I am not going to be presumptive and say that these things do not have the qualities that are attributed to them. But, whether they do or do not, to include fish as a therapeutic good seems to me to be casting the net exceptionally wide. These are the claims that have been made to me.

One of the reasons why this government does not enjoy the reputation of coming to grips with the problems of our country can be seen in the role of parliamentary secretaries. Today one of our parliamentary secretaries was asked to switch from being an engineering expert one minute to being an expert in therapeutic goods the next minute. Clearly no person, no matter what his skills and capacities are, can be an expert in these fields. In the state parliaments throughout Australia we have come to expect ministers to sit in the parliament. If things are happening in their portfolios that are not good, they are grilled, whether it is on legislation or appropriations. That has not occurred in this House today.

I pay a compliment, as I did earlier today, to some of the parliamentary secretaries who are being expected to switch from one moment defending positions which require certain skills, intellectual capacities and experience, to an entirely different field at another moment. The people who make the decisions are not sitting in this place and, until they do, there will still be a great gulf between what happens in this place and what are the thoughts, beliefs and aspirations of the wider Australian community.

Coming back on to the bill specifically, I would have liked to have got this point across to the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) himself but he is not in this chamber. I request that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous) bring to the attention of the minister concerned the fact that the net is being cast very wide. I do not have the skills or expertise to comment on the continual complaints being made that ordinary products—such as a fish product which has been eaten for hundreds, arguably thousands, of years—suddenly have to come under a therapeutic goods act. It seems to me to be quite ludicrous. If that is incorrect, I would like that pointed out to the House. I have my doubts as to whether we can have that done today. If that is the case, I would like to put the point very forcefully that this is very silly. It is costing people heaps of money.

In fact, the items that were brought to my attention have all been accepted in the United States, where there are very stringent drug controls. In that country it was considered to be quite ridiculous to have these items covered under the drug and health administration offices. Yet here these items are placed under this net and, for no good purpose whatsoever, subjected to the very stringent requirements which are very costly for those people who believe, be it a good thing or bad thing, that they need these products and want these products. That is the only point that I wish to make.

I also make the point that parliamentary secretaries are being asked to do tasks that are really quite above and beyond the resources of any human being, even outstanding human beings such as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, who is in the chamber at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on this Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The bill proposes amendments to several pieces of existing legislation. I will address my remarks to some of the amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986 and the Health Insurance Act 1973.

PARA.TAB: The Disabilities Services Act was one of the most significant and progressive pieces of social legislation passed for many years. The act was passed to replace previous legislation and to provide a new direction for the development of government programs for people with disabilities, with provisions that are more flexible and responsive to their needs.

The act aimed to enable people with disabilities to achieve positive outcomes such as increased independence, employment opportunities and integration in the community. The act set a new direction for the development of government programs for people with disabilities. The handicapped programs review recommended that the delivery of services be based on the principle of integration. People with disabilities were no longer to lead segregated lives. The government has pursued this agenda since 1984, aiming for a partnership with state and territory governments.

The act gave the government a strong legislative authority for the disability reform strategy. Breaking with the past, the Commonwealth put the focus on rights, on participation and on achieving independence. The next step was to link this new agenda to income support. In 1988 the Social Security Review published a paper on this which recommended that income security, employment support, rehabilitation and labour market programs be coordinated as a package for people with disabilities. The result was the establishment of a disability task force and, soon after, the disability reform package which effectively offered people on income support a fast track to open employment.

To encourage action at the state level, the federal government began negotiations with state and territory governments in 1991. These negotiations resulted in the Commonwealth-state disability agreements. All states and territories had signed an agreement by June of this year. These agreements gave the Commonwealth the responsibility for employment services for people with disabilities and the states the responsibility for accommodation services.

The Commonwealth's agenda in the employment area has focused on setting up a network of services across the country which place people with disabilities into open employment. The strategy is very much about providing alternatives to segregated employment. At the same time, the Commonwealth has encouraged transition in the segregated model. The development of national standards this year will add further weight to the transition strategy.

To assist the states to improve accommodation services, the Commonwealth offered quite significant financial incentives as part of the Commonwealth-state disability agreements. States and territories have also been required to enact complementary legislation to the Disability Services Act. They have all done this, which means that in Australia we effectively have national legislation in the disability area affirming the same social justice principles.

The Disability Discrimination Act which came into effect on 1 March this year added another level to the legislative reform program. A quick stroll through the past 10 years shows how we have laid the foundations for a new approach to disability services in this country.

Under section 14J of the Disability Services Act, where an organisation has not met prescribed standards of service the minister may make the following information available to the public: the organisation's name and address, the name and address of the service that is the subject of the declaration, the terms of the declaration under section 14J, details of the organisation's failure to meet the applicable standards in respect of the provision of the service and the actions taken in respect of that failure.

It has been suggested that statements under section 14J might lead to some organisations seeking to bring about a defamation action against the minister. The amendment, through the insertion of an additional paragraph, states that defamation laws do not lie against reasonable public statements such as those which would be made under section 14J. A similar provision exists in the National Health Act 1953. I understand these provisions would also relate to Commonwealth public servants in the event that they are required to make similar statements as delegates to the minister.

This brings me to the issue of situations where public servants are threatened with possible legal action in relation to the performance of their duties. In my previous role as a Public Sector Union delegate representing members who were officers of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, I recall a number of occasions where officers sought advice and assistance from the union relating to possible actions by community groups. This occurred on at least two occasions that I can remember in the disability services area. PSU members were concerned about suggestions of possible legal action foreshadowed by organisations which may have been the subject of an adverse report which they became aware of.

It is important that public servants, when properly exercising their duties, are protected against personal liability for statements made in the circumstances I have described here. While on this subject, it is not only community organisations that sometimes criticise public servants in the performance of their duty—and I refer to another matter raised with me in my former capacity.

On 6 June 1991 in this place, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) made an allegation in relation to a funded organisation in his electorate. He alleged that officers of the then Department of Community Services and Health had referred to a group of people with profound disabilities as `the residue'. The honourable member did not provide any evidence or explanation to support his allegation and did not name any of the officers he was referring to. I became aware of this allegation in my role as a union delegate.

PSU members who worked in the disability services area in New South Wales were outraged at the allegations, which they emphatically denied. I subsequently took up the matter on behalf of the union with senior departmental officials. The staff members concerned suffered considerable distress at these remarks. Although the honourable member for Mitchell did not identify any officers, it would have been readily assumed by people associated with the particular service that he was referring to one of a small number of departmental officers who dealt with that service.

I am aware from my personal contact with many of the staff in the disability services branch in New South Wales that they are people of the highest integrity and commitment to the disability services program. I am confident that such a remark as described by the honourable member for Mitchell would not have been made by any of the Commonwealth officers in this area.

My purpose in raising these issues is simply to highlight the need for protection for individual public servants who, in carrying out their duties in policy areas which may cause conflict in the community, may become subject to attacks of a personal nature from community organisations or, indeed, from politicians. In most cases the finance directions provide protection for public servants against legal action arising from the proper performance of their duties. However, the amendments contained in this bill will provide additional protection in cases where officers are making statements under delegated authority on behalf of a minister.

I now turn to the amendments to the Health Insurance Act in relation to pathology services. During the 1980s there was a massive increase in the use of pathology services. The advent of sophisticated new technology, the greater community awareness of pathology services and the issue of preventative medicine have contributed to this trend. Up until 1991 Medicare benefit payments for pathology services were increasing at a rate of about 14 per cent per annum. It could certainly be described as a growth industry.

Inevitably, pathology became one of the most significant areas of potential and actual abuse of Medicare services, and this added to the major cost increases. In 1985 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts published its report No. 236 resulting from its inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing. This report dealt specifically with pathology services and went into some detail. Since that time the government has acted on many of the recommendations contained in the Public Accounts Committee's report.

In 1991 the government introduced a number of measures to restructure payments of Medicare benefits for pathology services. This followed publication of the national health strategy background paper No. 6 on pathology. The 1991 reforms aimed to ensure that pathology services remained accessible to all Australians at a reasonable cost. There needs to be an appropriate balance between a patient's right of access to pathology testing and the absolute need to contain costs. In this respect the advent of new technology has facilitated some restructuring of the medical benefits schedule to reduce the schedule fees for pathology services which can now be carried out at less expense than was previously the case.

Clearly the measures have been effective as the growth in Medicare benefits for pathology services, previously around 14 per cent per annum, has flattened out considerably, and there has been almost nil real growth since that time in pathology services. However, these services still represent more than 12 per cent of total Medicare benefits, or more than $630 million, in the last financial year. So there still needs to be close monitoring of these services.

The amendments in this bill are a continuation of the government's measures to introduce more accountability and more efficient auditing of Medicare payments in relation to pathology. In particular, section 23DK of the act currently contains provisions which require approved pathology practitioners to retain specific records for 18 months and to make these records available to the Health Insurance Commission upon request.

The existing provisions apply specifically to approved pathology practitioners but do not apply to the APAs. Where the practitioners are employed by an approved pathology authority the terms of employment are such that the records relating to work performed under the contract of employment are legally the property of the employer and are not at the disposal of the employee. This creates a conflict of interest and makes it impractical to require the approved pathology practitioner to continue to retain these records.

As a consequence, the amendments to section 23DK contained in this bill place the responsibility on the approved pathology authority if the approved pathology practitioner ceases working for the authority. The authority would then retain these documents and make them available to the Health Insurance Commission officers when required. I commend this bill to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will spend a bit of time replying to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). Before doing so, I thank the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), the honourable member for Moncrieff, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) for their contributions. It has been a constructive debate. A number of very important issues have been covered, as is the case with omnibus bills of this kind which amend a number of acts. The Commonwealth wants to ensure that its legislation is kept up to date and that problems are detected in its implementation. It also wants to ensure that its policies are refined and relevant to its general social justice principles.

PARA.TAB: In the area of health and community services, we, as legislators, have an obligation to ensure that there is delivery of the service in the most efficient manner, which costs the taxpayers as little as possible and which provides the best service. That is not always easily achievable, especially in times of monetary restraints. It is in this context that a number of these amendments have had to be implemented.

I thank honourable members for their support of the legislation and for their comments. The areas of the department which are covered in this legislation indicate the wide spectrum of legislation that is under this portfolio.The honourable member for Kennedy is a bit confused about the role of parliamentary secretaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell me you aren't.

—No, I am not. He seemed a bit confused with the previous exercise, when I was handling a bill which was not directly in my portfolio, and this exercise which is in my portfolio. I am kept in touch with, and consult very widely about, the legislation that goes before this parliament. He asked why the minister is not here. It is a bit difficult for the minister to be here when he is in the Senate.
—There is a minister representing him here.
—There is a minister representing him here but the parliamentary secretary has a direct relationship. The honourable member might be interested to know how the system works.
—I was a parliamentary secretary in this place years ago, so perhaps you should do some homework for a change.

—If that is the case, the honourable member will know what I am saying. He and others may be interested to know that the parliamentary secretary has a direct link with the minister in the Senate on these matters—especially in the case of my portfolio—with his office and with the officers of the department. The statement by the honourable member for Kennedy that somehow parliamentary secretaries are not knowledgeable in the areas in which they have responsibility is quite mistaken. I am sure that all the parliamentary secretaries—they are an excellent team of people who have been appointed by this government—are on top of their legislative responsibilities and are very much in touch with their ministers.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with some of the specific comments made by the honourable member for Moncrieff. Before I do that, it might be worth dealing with the matter raised by the honourable member for Kennedy, who seems to think that the Therapeutic Goods Act is too broad and too wide in its application. The problem is that people want to have it both ways. On the one hand they want to say that they have a special health product that is good for their health and has a health benefit. They want to be able to advertise that product as having a therapeutic or health claim. On the other hand they say, `We do not want the government to have any control on these claims'.

They cannot have it both ways. There has to be a situation where the people making these sorts of claims about vitamins, minerals, et cetera, come under the Therapeutic Goods Act, in which case they are able to make legitimate claims that can be tested, or there has to be a situation where anybody can produce anything and claim that it has health and therapeutic consequences and we will have no controls whatever. We are not in the second exercise and it is for this reason that the Therapeutic Goods Act applies in this way.

In Australia, we have taken the view that if nutritional supplements are of assistance to health then it is better to regulate the goods as therapeutic goods and control the claims being made about them. That is the fundamental approach that we have had. I am not sure whether the honourable member for Kennedy would want to challenge that. He made the point that there is a problem with beche-de-mer, which is a form of sea slug. I presume he means other fish oil products as well. He did not mention that we receive many complaints about extravagant and misleading claims being made on supplements of products such as fish oil and beche-de-mer. Extravagant claims are being made and it is necessary therefore to have some controls.

He seemed to think that because these controls are present there is some massive increase in the price. That is not true. In fact, the costs levied on such products are not excessive. Furthermore, manufacturers are eligible for reductions in evaluation fees if the goods are in the public interest. The controls are not commercially viable if a company can show that the full fees have been paid or if it can show that it is in the public interest for the fees to be waived.

Furthermore, annual charges for registration are not payable where the turnover of the goods is of low volume or of low value. I understand that the honourable member is a bit concerned about overregulation. The reality is that we do not have overregulation here. We would have people making extravagant claims for a whole range of nutritional supplements if we did not have some regulation under the Therapeutic Goods Act. I hope the honourable member accepts those comments in good faith.

The honourable member for Moncrieff, speaking on behalf of the opposition, said that she was concerned about the amendments to section 14J and that, unless she received some sensible replies to her concerns about that section, the opposition would vote against it during the committee stage, which is its right in the democratic process. Section 14J of the Disability Services Act 1986 is only a recent provision. Although until now there has been no litigation or threatened litigation in relation to this particular provision, as the honourable member for Moncrieff said, nevertheless there are situations in which there have been legal challenges. Therefore, to ensure that such a situation does not happen in a way that would make it difficult for the operation of the act, the government has decided to insert this provision.

The honourable member asked what were the precedents. She said that, in her opinion, there were no precedents. The advice I have is that there are a number of precedents which provide immunity from certain types of legal action for statements made. Two examples of this are, firstly, sections 91 and 92 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982, which provides for immunity in relation to the publication of material which may be defamatory. This is very important. Secondly, section 89A of the Public Service Act 1922 provides specific protection from defamation action in relation to referee reports and work assessments. The honourable member may be interested to know that it has been argued that these reports would be protected by qualified privilege, yet specific protection has still been given by a specific provision.

It is true that the clause in this bill is pre-emptive because some concern has been experienced with other programs where reports relating to compliance with standards have led to threats of defamation action, and this matter has to be dealt with. The publication of comments under section 14A, which is proposed to be protected, is limited to those published in good faith. I hope the honourable member takes on board the expression `in good faith'. This is made clear by the statement in proposed subsection 14J(2)(b), where the Minister for Health is specifically included in the category of persons who will obtain protection against legal action only if the minister publishes the material in good faith. I say this because the honourable member for Moncrieff asked about malice. The proposed subsection deals with the problem of malice.

It is not the intention of the government to use this proposed subsection to protect the minister from acting in a malicious way against any individual in respect of these issues. The fact that the subsection includes the words `in good faith' deals with the problems which the honourable member raised. I hope that is a satisfactory explanation for the honourable member. I believe that the bill should be passed without amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on the second reading I referred to the probability that the opposition would oppose this clause and vote against it. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) was good enough to get some information for me during the second reading debate in an attempt to obviate that. Amongst other things, I had said that the protection that this clause gives to the minister was unprecedented and unnecessary. I said we wanted certain questions answered and explanations given.

PARA.TAB: The parliamentary secretary obtained for me references to two other acts as examples of precedents: section 91 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and section 89A of the Public Service Act 1922. We have taken a quick look at those acts and are not satisfied that they are equivalent precedents. I am not learned counsel, and there are others who are better qualified to give an opinion on those examples. I will not make one up on the run, but I want to say a few words about it.

In the speech of the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford)—she spoke immediately after me—she said that taxpayers have a right to know whether things are not `quite right'. Certainly the coalition would support that view. Taxpayers have that right now. The minister is authorised under the act—in fact, he is required under the act—to make certain information available. He is charged to see that the objectives of the act are properly carried out—in other words, that things are quite right—and, if they are not, he is empowered to remove a grant or refuse further grants. So there is no quarrel with that principle at all.

We are taking exception, however, to this bill's proposal to blanket immunity being given to the minister. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, at present the minister enjoys a qualified privilege anyway. We have not been persuaded there is a need to go past that qualified privilege. I reiterate that the minister, if he is acting properly, is protected now. We are unmoved, unfortunately, by the parliamentary secretary's best attempts to persuade us otherwise.

The parliamentary secretary said that section 14J of the principal act could be amended by adding proposed subsection (2). He referred to the fact that there is reference there to `good faith'. I point out that there are paragraphs (a) and (b) in that proposed subsection. Paragraph (a) refers to the minister making the information available to the public. Paragraph (b) refers to a person, including the minister, publishing in good faith a copy of the information, or a fair extract from, or a fair abstract of, the information. The matter of making the information available in good faith is not covered in paragraph (a). So the coalition will pursue its intention to vote against this clause of the bill before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly comment on the assertion by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) that section 89A of the Public Service Act 1922 and section 91 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 constitute precedents for clause 4 which contains the provision to be added to section 14J of the principal act. If one looks first at the Public Service Act provision, it can be seen that this is a provision which protects a person in the preparation of a report in the course of employment where it is done in good faith. It is not a provision that relates to the publication of a report; it relates to the preparation. One might want to argue that, in that respect, it merely restates the common law. To that extent, it might be suggested validly that it constitutes a precedent, but it is not in any way relevant to a situation where, a report or statement having been prepared in the ordinary course of the work of a department, the minister then elects to make it public. It is that issue which is addressed in the proposed addition to section 14J of the principal act.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at section 91 of the Freedom of Information Act, one finds that this also does not relate to the publication of a document at all, except in a very narrow sense. It provides that no action for defamation or other specified forms of action lies against the Commonwealth, an agency, a minister or an officer by reason of the authorising or giving of the access to a document pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act.

That is not a general publication; that is almost tantamount to a private publication because it is made to one person: an applicant. It is not, in that sense, as it is under the proposed addition to section 14J, a general publication or the making of information or a statement available to the public. I respectfully suggest that neither provision constitutes a precedent for what is sought to be done here.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is concerned to take seriously the objections made by the opposition. In this situation, we are prepared to take further advice on the matter; but I do not think this is a reason for delaying the passage of the bill. The best course of action is for the matter to be further examined. There are obviously contrasting legal opinions in relation to this issue. Our advice is different. I am not suggesting that the information given by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) is incorrect; I am just saying that there is a difference in legal advice in relation to this matter. However, I will have the matter further investigated. In the meantime, the best way to proceed is for this clause to be proceeded with. If there is some reason why a change needs to be made, I will recommend to the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, that the change be looked at in the context of the bill proceeding to be dealt with in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: In making these comments, I am not saying that I accept all of the legal argument given by the opposition, but we need to take on board the legal arguments put and examine the matter further. If there is something in what the opposition says, then I am sure that Senator Richardson would be prepared to examine the matter. Perhaps the whole point could be taken care of. I am not sure whether the opposition would be prepared to accept the whole thing if the words `in good faith' were also added to paragraph (a) of the proposed subsection. That is a possible compromise. If not, I think all these suggestions need to be referred to further when the minister examines the issue and the Attorney-General's Department gives further advice. As I said, I will recommend to the Minister that the question be further considered in the Senate in relation to this particular clause. But at this time, it is our intention to proceed with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) for the trouble he has taken and the indication of good faith on his part in the debate. However, the coalition will vote against this clause on the grounds that we have not been provided with a precedent here today. We would welcome a precedent if it could be produced. We will certainly examine any further information the government wants to make available in the future on the subject. However, we shall proceed now on the assumption that there is no precedent. We consider the issue sufficiently serious that we ought to register our position clearly on it by voting against clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It will give effect to three changes announced in the 1993-94 budget. One change will provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company income tax in respect of the 1993-94 income year. Another will exempt from income tax income derived by non-profit organisations established for the purpose of promoting the development of tourism. The third change will provide sales tax exemption for goods used in various activities of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

PARA.TAB: The bill also proposes changes to the imputation system as a result of the reduction in the company tax rate, for 1993-94 and later years of income, from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. The bill makes a number of amendments to the method of calculating and apportioning certain deductions allowable to life assurance companies. It also amends the capital gains tax provisions so that they do not apply to capital gains and losses realised on the disposal of policies of life assurance, or rights under policies of life assurance, by complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts.

The bill will also amend the provisional tax provisions of the taxation law to maintain the current uplift factor of eight per cent for the calculation of provisional tax for the 1993-94 year of income. Other changes are proposed to the petroleum mining provisions, fringe benefits tax, superannuation guarantee charge and petroleum resource rent tax.The bill also includes several technical amendments to the taxation law. I now turn to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deferral of initial payment of company tax

PARA.TAB: The bill will give effect to the announcement in the 1993-94 budget of relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company income tax in respect of the 1993-94 year of income. The companies affected are those with a tax liability of $1,000 or more but less than $300,000, and which pay their tax in two instalments. The due date for the initial payment will be deferred by nine weeks from the 28th day of the month following the balance date to the 28th day of the third month following the balance date.

As for previous deferrals in the 1990-91 and 1991-92 income years, the amendments will ensure that franking deficit tax and franking credits and debits will be determined as if there had been no deferral of the initial tax payment. The measure will defer revenue of $10 million from the 1993-94 year of income.

With effect from 1 July 1993, income derived by non-profit organisations established for the purpose of promoting the development of tourism will be exempt from income tax. Consistent with that change, special fringe benefits tax arrangements, which provide some organisations with a tax rebate of 48 per cent of their fringe benefits tax liability, will be extended to non-profit, non-government tourism industry organisations. This rebate will apply to relevant organisations from 1 April 1994. The amendments will have no effect on revenue.

As part of the 1993-94 budget, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced a change to the sales tax legislation to provide exemption for goods used in various activities of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The change will provide an exemption from sales tax on goods used by the various state, territory and national bodies that comprise the group of organisations known as the RSPCA, mainly in carrying out their inspectorial functions and the operation of animal shelters.The exemption will not extend to goods used mainly in their commercial activities such as boarding kennels. The amendments, which apply from 13 March 1993, will cost revenue approximately $500,000 in 1993-94 and later years. In addition there will be refunds of tax paid from 13 March 1993 to 30 June 1993.

The bill contains changes to the imputation system as a result of the reduction in the company tax rate, for 1993-94 and later years of income, from 39 per cent to 33 per cent as announced in the Investing in the Nation statement. At the time of the reduction, companies may have unused imputation credits arising from tax paid at the higher rate. In order to allow companies to pass on to their shareholders the full value of any imputation credits for tax paid at the 39 per cent rate, the imputation system will now operate using dual franking accounts instead of the existing single account.

Broadly, there will be one account for tax paid at the 39 per cent rate and another for tax paid at the 33 per cent rate. The 39 per cent account will operate in respect of the following: any surplus 39 per cent credits at the time of the rate reduction; any franked dividends received that have 39 per cent credits attached to them; and any further payments of tax that may be made at the 39 per cent rate as a result of, say, amended assessments for years when that rate applied.

In the absence of this change, under the present single account, the value of these 39 per cent imputation credits when passed on to individual shareholders would be reduced. The dual franking accounts will operate quite separately from but in the same manner as the existing single account. They will operate from the commencement of a company's 1994-95 franking year.

The bill also contains transitional measures to prevent franked dividends paid by early balancing companies with imputation credits calculated on the basis of the 33 per cent rate from being channelled through later balancing companies which effectively pass those dividends on to individual shareholders with higher imputation credits based on the 39 per cent rate. The overall cost of the reduction of the company tax rate, with which these measures are associated, is $440 million in 1993-94, $1,830 million in 1994-95, $1,620 million in 1995-96 and $1,700 million in 1996-97.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Income tax deductions for life assurance companies

PARA.TAB: The bill will give effect to the measures announced in the Treasurer's press release of 31 May 1993. These measures concern amendments to certain formulas in the tax law which enable the tax payable by a life assurance company to be determined. The formulas provide for the calculation of the amount of specific deductions to be allowed to a life assurance company and the apportionment of those and other deductions against the differently taxed classes of income of a life assurance company.

The formulas are based on income derived by a life assurance company. One amount of income presently included in the formulas arises as a result of a life assurance company agreeing to pay the tax liability of a superannuation fund.This is a facility instituted for the ease of administration of superannuation funds. It operates by a life assurance company agreeing to include in its assessable income an amount which otherwise would be taxable income of a superannuation fund. The inclusion of these transferred amounts in the formulas has an adverse effect on the tax payable by a life assurance company. This was never intended to be the case and will now be corrected by an amendment to exclude these transferred amounts from the formulas.

Other amounts will be included in the formula which apportion deductions to the differently taxed classes of income of a life assurance company. These other amounts represent the premiums received by a company which are treated as assessable income of the company for the purpose of calculating its allowable deductions. Because the inclusion of these other amounts increases allowable deductions they should also be taken into account in apportioning those deductions to the differently taxed classes of income. The inclusion of these premiums in the apportionment formula will provide a fairer allocation of deductions to the respective classes. The revenue impact of these measures, which will operate from 1 June 1993, cannot be quantified.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Life assurance policies and capital gains

PARA.TAB: Generally capital gains realised on the disposal of assets are included in assessable income and subject to income tax. A specific exemption is provided for capital gains made on the disposal of an interest in a policy of life assurance, or rights under a policy of life assurance. However this exemption is only available where the person making the disposal is the `original beneficial owner' of the policy or rights under the policy, or a person who did not acquire the rights or interest for money or other consideration.

This bill will amend the capital gains tax provisions so that they do not apply to capital gains and losses realised on the disposal of policies of life assurance, or rights under policies of life assurance, by complying superannuation funds, approved deposit funds or pooled superannuation trusts, whether or not the fund or trust is the `original beneficial owner' of the policy. This amendment will ensure that the taxation treatment of capital gains from life assurance policies realised by superannuation funds and similar bodies is consistent with their general concessional taxation treatment.

The proposed exemption will apply to disposals of policies of life assurance taking place during or after the year of income in which 1 July 1988 occurred. It will therefore apply with effect from the income year in which the current provisions relating to the taxation of superannuation and related business contained in part IX of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 took effect. The impact to revenue is not expected to be substantial.

The bill makes the necessary amendments to retain the current provisional uplift factor of eight per cent as announced by the Treasurer in June 1993. The uplift factor of eight per cent will be applied to the 1992-93 incomes for the purposes of calculating 1993-94 provisional tax. The amendments will have no effect on revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the petroleum mining provisions

PARA.TAB: This bill gives effect to my announcement on 4 August 1993 that the petroleum mining provisions would be amended to ensure that deductions are not available for expenditure incurred in carrying out activities overseas that do not generate assessable income in Australia. Income earned by Australian companies from carrying on a business in certain overseas locations is presently exempt from tax in Australia. However, a technical defect in the petroleum mining provisions could allow Australian petroleum mining companies to claim deductions for expenditure incurred in exploration and mining activities in these locations.

This was clearly never intended to be the case. It is a basic principle of tax law that deductions are not allowable for expenditure incurred for the purpose of producing exempt income. The cost to the revenue of the defect could exceed $1 billion. The government believes that it would not be appropriate to allow a small number of taxpayers to benefit from this defect at the expense of the general community. Taxpayers could not reasonably have expected to gain, given that the parliament's intention was absolutely clear. Accordingly, the amendments are to apply to expenditure incurred after 7.30 p.m., by standard time in the ACT, on 21 August 1990, the commencement time of the amendments that gave rise to the defect.

Under the existing fringe benefits tax law, an airline transport fringe benefit arises where an airline operator or travel agent provides transport to an employee. The taxable value of the benefit is the `stand-by value' of the transport provided, less any contribution made by the employee.

Under that part of the definition of `stand-by value' which covers travel over a domestic route, `stand-by value' is calculated by reference to the `economy air fare' of either the provider of the service or Australian Airlines, depending on whether the transport provided is on a scheduled flight or not. The definition of `stand-by value' will be amended so that no particular airline will be referred to for valuation purposes. Reference to a particular airline is no longer appropriate in a deregulated airline industry. Also, where an airline has a published economy air fare which differs in value from a non-published economy air fare, only the published economy air fare will be used.

The bill will also amend the fringe benefits law by removing the requirement for certain employers to disclose the sources of information used in compiling their fringe benefits tax return. The amendments, which apply from the date of royal assent, are not expected to have any significant impact on the revenue.

This bill will amend the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to allow the superannuation guarantee shortfall component to be paid into a complying approved deposit fund. The bill will also amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to ensure that any shortfall component received by a complying approved deposit fund is a taxable contribution. The amendments will apply from the date of royal assent.

The bill will amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 and the Superannuation Industry Supervision bill 1993 to allow approved deposit funds to accept the superannuation guarantee shortfall component. The proposed amendments will increase the number of funds that can accept a superannuation guarantee shortfall component, particularly if that shortfall component consists of a small amount. The proposed amendments will have no effect on revenue.

Last November a report to parliament on the operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987 was tabled by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths), then the Minister for Resources. The government committed itself at that time to further consider some issues raised in submissions to the report, and to further consult with petroleum industry representatives. This consultation has extended to confidential discussion of draft legislation.

As a result of this process, it was announced in the budget that amendments would be made to the petroleum resource rent tax law to help ensure that it does not delay exploration following changes in interests in projects or otherwise distort commercial decision making, and to ease compliance by resource rent taxpayers. This bill will make four amendments, applying generally from 1 July 1993. The amendments will:

SPEECH.PARA: treat transfers of part of a taxpayer's interest in a petroleum project in the same way as transfers of a taxpayer's whole interest;

enable exploration expenditure incurred in the financial year a person farms into a project to be set off against his assessable receipts from other projects, or to be set off against the assessable receipts derived by another company in the same wholly owned company group, from other projects;
enable exploration expenditure incurred in the financial year a person abandons a petroleum project to be set off against receipts from other projects; and
double the time for lodgment of expenditure transfer notices and annual petroleum resource rent tax returns.
These amendments will have a small but unquantifiable cost to the revenue.

PARA.TAB: The bill also includes several technical amendments to the taxation laws. These technical amendments include changes to `tidy up' aspects of the legislation which simplified the prescribed payments system, simplified the gift provisions, removed the commissioner's priority for debts in relation to certain unremitted amounts and implemented the Australia-Vietnam comprehensive double tax agreement. These amendments will have no impact on revenue. I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the bill. I commend the bill to the House.
