PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will amend the tax law that formally imposes franking deficit tax. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993, which I have just introduced, includes amendments to the imputation system of the income tax law. As part of these amendments, the provisions determining liability for franking deficit tax are to be changed. This bill reimposes franking deficit tax with effect from the time of those changes. The provisions of this bill are also explained in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated. I commend the bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK (QUOTAS) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming from a very large, beef producing rural electorate in Queensland—and Queensland has in excess of 50 per cent of the nation's beef herd pastured—it is a great pleasure to speak on the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Amendment Bill 1993. The bill will simply extend the operations of the Australian Meat and Livestock Quotas Act 1990 for a further three years—until 28 December 1996. The background is that meat quotas, or other restrictions, imposed on Australia by importing countries are necessary to control the amount of beef exported from Australia. This proposed act provides the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation with powers to establish quota schemes on the export of meat and live sheep from Australia, in particular circumstances.

PARA.TAB: As a result of what can only be described as United States blackmail for the past three years, Australia—very reluctantly—has agreed to restrain exports of meat to the US to avoid the imposition of quotas under the United States meat import law, commonly known by the meat industry as the MIL. To ensure that we comply with the so-called voluntary restraint agreement, the corporation currently imposes quotas on beef, mutton and goat meats to the US. Given that our beef trade to the US is worth in excess of $1.1 billion annually, it is very important—I commend the government for what it is trying to do—to have the meat import law eliminated as part of the Uruguay Round, or the GATT trade talks. The GATT quite often is referred to in the bush as the general agreement for talk and talk, because there has been an awful lot of that in this Uruguay Round of the GATT talks.

Having said that—it is extremely important—we can only hope that the December deadline and the current Blair House agreement will stand up to the deadlines and commitments from the countries involved in the negotiations. It is absolutely imperative—whilst we might joke about it being a general agreement on talk and talk—that there be an outcome by December this year. The talks have gone on too long, but it is much better to be continuing with dialogue than to have cut them off.

Cutting the talks off would have a devastating effect on our agricultural products and would certainly open up the world for a food trade war. Australia can only be the loser in any trade war because our Treasury—as we know—does not have much money at the moment. We have only to look at the budget to see that there is no money here in Australia. Our Treasury is much smaller than are those in the European community and the United States—the major players and obstacles to an outcome on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in the Uruguay arrangements.

If we do get an agreement by December this year, and as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) said in his second reading speech, the government will seek to have the American meat import law, MIL, linked to those talks with GATT. If it gets that law amended, in terms of the arrangements we have with America, it will certainly be good news for regional Australia and meat exporters and producers, because it will lead to a great deal more predictability in arrangements for access to these markets and it will certainly lead to investor confidence in those who wish to invest in the beef industry in Australia.

The beef industry, in agricultural terms, is another industry which over the last 10 years has moved down the process line of adding value to the product. No longer does the beef that comes to the table or is exported from Australia rely solely on seasons to be put into a form that can be processed to its maximum value. The beef industry has largely gone down the line of producing more feedlot beef. That creates a lot more stability in the meat industry, with beef of consistent quality coming onto the market. That is very important.

But all that costs money, and to invest in the beef industry today requires substantial capital. If people are to invest in the meat industry, particularly at any stage of the feedlot industry, they need stability and predictability in the markets. Only then will beef producers get on with the job of expanding our beef exports and our beef industry in Australia. So the GATT talks and the December deadline are extremely important to the meat industry. Whilst we live under the current arrangements there will be doubt in the minds of potential and would-be investors and in the value-adding section of the meat industry.

I will touch on the goat meat industry because arrangements for goat meat accessing the American market is a case of like not being considered with like. Recently in Broken Hill I was talking with the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), the local member, and Senator Brownhill. We met with people from the Desert Oak Goat Abattoir at Broken Hill. That abattoir has reformed its operations and is seeking markets overseas for its goat meat. Unfortunately, for the goat meat industry to gain access to the United States, it has to buy a quota. This quota comes out of the beef industry quota which is a general quota. The people were saying that goat meat is not like beef; it has a specific market which is quite different from that of the beef and mutton industries.

They complained—and rightly so—about the cost of that quota. This is one of the problems under the quota arrangements. The 45c a pound makes their products less competitive and often not worth seeking markets for, because of the way they have to buy their quota. They would like access for their goat meat to the American market with it being treated separately, not lumped in with other meats. I firmly agreed with them, as did the honourable member for Parkes, that we would then see the goat meat industry in Australia expanding.

It is very important to have that industry expand. Most of the goats that are being processed at the Desert Oak Abattoir are feral and come from some of the drier regions. They are virtually out of control and are causing enormous problems in these very fragile environments. While they go uncontrolled, and if they are not harvested because of market problems, they can only damage that very fragile environment. I just hope that when the department is talking to the authorities it will consider the Desert Oak Abattoir and the goat meat industry and its potential here in Australia.

The European Community allows imports of only 16,500 tonnes of sheepmeat, 6,032 tonnes of beef, and 2,250 tonnes of buffalo meat. However, the market is high-priced and this small amount earns $150 million per year. These strict limits to access the European market mean that the AMLC must issue quotas. In the instance of these quotas to the Europeans, these are issued without charge.

The AMLC also has the power to restrict the export of live sheep and it can allocate these quotas free, by auction, by sale by tender, or by private sale. None of these powers has yet been used. It could be that if we resumed trade with Saudi Arabia, we could well see that these powers may be used. I think eight or nine years ago the live sheep trade was an extremely important trade for Australia, and unfortunately we lost that. I think we lost it for a number of reasons. I believe that the live sheep trade was being used really in Australia as a by-product of the wool industry. In other words, the stock that we were sending to the Middle East in many instances was not what the customer wanted. In many ways we have ourselves to blame, hence the regulation that is now in place. I think it is extremely sad that we lost this market. It is now building again with very strict controls; but we must never again use the live sheep trade with the Middle East as just an avenue to get rid of our surplus sheep—in other words, the by-product of our Australian wool industry. I believe it was largely used as that for a number of years.

The other thing the live sheep trade with the Middle East did, and it certainly did this in the mid-1980s, was to take a great deal of sheep—seven or eight million sheep per annum, if my memory serves me correctly. It was only male sheep that were allowed to be exported to the Middle East, and it took these merino sheep out of the wool factories in Australia. This was a factor in keeping production down. If we look at the time when we started to lose access to this market, we also notice that it is about the time production in Australia started to rise. Obviously there are other factors involved, but the live sheep trade and its demise certainly coincided with the increase in production in Australia. That led to overproduction, and we all know the history of that which I will not go into tonight.

It is extremely important that when we re-establish this live sheep trade with the Middle East, particularly Saudi Arabia—it is extremely important that we gain access there once again—that we do it on the basis that we are suppling what the customer needs. That certainly means that we need legislation, such as we have here, which will ensure that these licenses to export to the Middle East are strictly controlled whilst we manage our way back into that market. In this area of the live sheep trade with the Middle East we do not hear a great deal from the government. I have not once heard the minister mention the live sheep trade with the Middle East. His performance on this issue in terms of gaining access to the live sheep trade with the Middle East has been one of silence. What we have to do is a great deal more in this area.

To that end, I am part of a parliamentary delegation that is going to the Middle East in November. That delegation is led by the former Minister for Land Transport, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). I am very happy to be part of that delegation. One of the things that I have requested is that whilst we are in the Middle East we touch base with the live sheep trade and the prospects for the future development of that trade and our contacts with the Middle East. I am certainly looking forward to my trip to Lebanon, Syria, Tunisia and Morocco because all those countries hold potential for us in the area of trade. In terms of the live sheep trade and how this bill impacts on the live sheep industry, it is extremely important as we rebuild those links with the Middle East that we do it on a sustainable basis and one where we are supplying what our customers want.

Another point that I would like to make concerns the introduction of new genetic material into Australia. We might say: what does genetic material have to do with the Australian Meat and Livestock (Quotas) Amendment Bill? It has a great deal to do with it. Unless we have genetic material coming into the country to improve the strains of beef or sheep, we are not going to be able to mix it with the best in the world. As genetic strains around the world improve, we have to be part of that improvement process in Australia.

I want to touch on the sheepmeat area, the recent release of the texel sheep in Australia and the proposal to release fat-tailed sheep in Australia. Let me advise those who are not familiar with the texel sheep. It is a European breed of sheep which originates from the isle of Texel, just off Holland. Being someone who is familiar with the beef industry, I know that the texel sheep will do to the sheep industry in Australia what the European breeds have done for some of our more traditional beef breeds in Australia. They are an extremely robust animal. They are a larger animal than we have in Australia. I believe this new genetic material will come at a time when our lamb industry is certainly showing signs of much better prices. An investment in this new genetic material, in terms of the lamb industry, is extremely well timed.

Texel sheep are much leaner and larger in their carcass. The product that they will produce is going to meet the consumer demands both on the Australian and overseas markets. The release of those texels, whilst they have been a long time coming to Australia and going through our very rigid quarantine process, will, I believe, have a dramatic impact on the lamb industry in Australia. Anyone associated with the lamb industry in Australia knows that it certainly has a good future with the infusion of this new genetic material in Australia.

The other breed that I mentioned is the fat-tailed sheep. These sheep came originally from the Middle East. They are sheep that carry their store of fat in their tails, hence their name. The fat is not deposited over the carcass. These are sheep that have been brought under a government program into Western Australia. I caution the release of these sheep into the Australian flocks. I do so for very good reasons. Whilst these fat-tailed sheep are certainly very much desired in the Middle East—they do not have this fat deposited over their entire bodies, and that is one of their traits and what the customer wants and pays a great deal more for than the traditional type of sheep in the Middle East—they have a gene in them which carries kemp fibres in their fleece. For almost a century the merino wool industry in Australia has tried to remove the kemp fibres out of our Australian merinos, and it has been largely successful. To release these sheep that have the potential to mix in with our merino sheep in Australia—and they will; it does not matter how we think we could control them, they will—will reintroduce a gene that carries this kemp fibre; in other words, a very coarse hair fibre.

Australia is noted for its very fine, soft handling wool. I certainly caution the minister—I understand that ultimately it is going to be his decision as to whether these sheep are released—and advise him against allowing the release of these fat-tailed sheep into the general flocks of the nation. I believe the market for such animals—a live sheep trade or, indeed, a carcass trade with the Middle East—is a very small one when we consider the potential damage that these sheep could have on the genetic structure of our Australian merino sheep industry.

Whilst the fortunes of the wool industry are not good at the moment, only five or six years ago the industry produced one in every $10 of export income for Australia. So I think we have to look at the priorities in this area and I certainly urge the minister to think long and hard. If I had the responsibility, I would be very reluctant to release these fat-tail sheep from quarantine. In fact, I would not do it.

I notice the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has just come into the House. I think these sheep may be in his electorate and I guess he has had representations about them. I hope what I have said accords with what he thinks about these animals.

This side of the House agrees to the Australian Meat and Livestock (Quotas) Amendment Bill. As the minister said, there are aspects of it with which the government does not agree totally, but it is working on it. That is certainly good to see. We support those efforts. We can only hope that the GATT talks result in an outcome by December and that the very important matter of the US meat import law and access to US markets is resolved in those talks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the support that the shadow minister for rural and regional development, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), gives to the Australian Meat and Livestock (Quotas) Amendment Bill. I do not know about fat-tail sheep, but I notice a few of them on the other side from time to time. I agree with the shadow minister that we need to take care with genetic material coming into Australia and we need to produce a product that is seen throughout the world as clean, green and acceptable. I think that is all part of the argument.

PARA.TAB: I can assure the shadow minister that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) takes a great interest in the resumption of the live sheep trade to the Middle East. I am sure that the leader of the parliamentary delegation, the former Minister for Land Transport, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), will be consulting with the minister and taking up that issue when the delegation visits the Middle East.

I rise to support the Australian Meat and Livestock (Quotas) Amendment Bill 1993. The bill proposes to extend the sunset clause of the Australian Meat and Livestock (Quotas) Act 1990. In that respect, it could be seen as something like a daylight saving bill—just delaying the sunset. I certainly hope that is true because we are forced to have these sorts of regulations because of laws and regulations overseas, and we would rather not be applying quotas at all.

This minor amendment to the 1990 act has important implications for the meat and livestock industry, and it should gain the full support of the House. The 1990 act was introduced to allow the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to set quotas for the export of meat and live sheep to countries where import restrictions applied, or were considered likely to be applied, on Australian meat and live sheep exports. Generally these restrictions were applied—and continue to be applied—by the United States, the European Community and Saudi Arabia. Because the reasons for the introduction of the original legislation continue to apply, it is appropriate that the sunset clause in the legislation be put back.

The United States has traditionally been our largest export market for beef, currently taking about a third of our exports, and the Japanese market is now nearly as valuable. Australian exports of beef to the US in 1992 were worth $1.1 billion. The quota to the United States is allocated on the basis of the exporter's global shipments for the previous year, and there is provision by the AMLC for new entrants to be allocated a quota. Access to the US market for fresh, chilled and frozen beef and veal, mutton, goat meat and some processed beef and veal is governed by the US meat import law.

The MIL was enacted in 1964, with amendments made in 1979, which introduced the counter-cyclical formula, and in 1988, which implemented the Canada-United States free trade agreement. The MIL contains a formula which determines the permitted level of imports, known as the trigger level, for each calendar year. This formula allows imports to grow in line with the overall increase in beef production, but it also winds back access when there is a cyclical increase in cow beef production, the product with which most imports compete.

Import controls must be imposed if the Secretary of Agriculture estimates that the imports will reach the trigger level. The US prefers to negotiate voluntary restraints with supplier countries rather than impose import quotas. The gain for supplier countries, including Australia, is that quotas must be applied at a level 10 per cent below the trigger level whenever it appears that the trigger level is likely to be exceeded. Restraint agreements have applied in 17 of the years since 1965.
Earlier this year, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics completed a study for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which, in summary, concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent times the efficacy of the price stabilisation capacity of the MIL has been eroded by the sharp increase in the (Canada-US Free Trade Agreement); the recent growth in US beef exports, particularly to North Asia; and aspects of the MIL formula itself.
Australia is negotiating in the Uruguay Round to have the MIL replaced by tariff-only protection and more predictable access conditions.

PARA.TAB: The House should be aware that Australia reluctantly, but voluntarily, restricts the amount of beef it exports to the United States. This is done through the AMLC applying the 1990 quotas act. The voluntary restriction comes through the United States' application of the MIL. Without complying with this voluntary restriction, it would be likely that Australia would lose 10 per cent, or about $110 million worth, of exports to the US. That is why it is important legislation.

A similar situation applies with the EC. Access of high quality beef to the EC is based on an allocation system derived from undertakings given at the time of the GATT Tokyo Round. Each year Australia receives a 5,000 tonne share of the so-called `Hilton' or high quality beef export quota at 20 per cent duty. In addition, we are allocated, by unilateral EC decision, a share of the so-called beef balance sheet by which a notional amount of manufacturing beef is converted to a proportionally lower amount of high quality beef with a 20 per cent levy.

Since 1991 we have retained our traditional 11.3 per cent of the beef balance sheet, which has amounted to 1,032 tonnes. Last year we exported 7,544 tonnes of high quality beef to the EC, with a value of $59 million. Access of sheepmeat exports to the EC is limited by a voluntary restraint agreement. Current arrangements to 31 December 1993 are for a quota of 17,500 tonnes of mutton, lamb and goat meat, including a chilled lamb subquota of 3,500 tonnes at zero duty. Any imports above this quota would be subject to a 20 per cent levy.

In 1992 we exported close to 15,000 tonnes of sheepmeat to the EC, with a value of close to $56 million. Quota to the EC is allocated on the basis of the exporter's shipments to the EC in the previous year, 80 per cent, and exports to other markets, 20 per cent.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 also empowered the AMLC to restrict the export of live sheep, principally to Saudi Arabia. These powers have not been used because Australia voluntarily withdrew its exports of live sheep to Saudi Arabia two years ago following a series of rejections, supposedly for quarantine reasons. The government, in close consultation with the live sheep industry, is actively working towards the resumption of the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia on a mutually satisfactory basis, taking into account appropriate animal health and welfare considerations. If and when these exports resume the AMLC may have an important role to play in determining the most appropriate levels of live sheep export to Saudi Arabia. The powers contained in this bill are necessary to manage the re-establishment of the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia if and when the opportunity arrives. There is a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal regarding AMLC decisions about the validity of quotas and the changes to quotas which are granted.

I see this amendment as a necessary evil. It is designed to give the Australian meat and livestock producer the best possible export earnings by not jeopardising our export markets. We have seen over the past three years that the corporation has been successful in its aims. In a perfect world, where countries traded freely, this legislation would not be necessary but, as the French and others have demonstrated recently, it is far from a perfect trading world.

Honourable members would be aware that US President Bill Clinton is to report to the US Congress in mid-December on the progress of the GATT Round. Hopefully he will be able to report that it is to be successfully completed. That would reduce the need for this type of legislation because it would provide us with better access to the US and the EC, two of our most important markets. But currently the need exists for this legislation to be passed so that the AMLC can continue to apply export restrictions on our meat and livestock exports in the best interests of the industry.

In summary, this bill allows the AMLC to operate quota mechanisms on meat and live sheep. The act will cease to be in force on 28 December 1993. It does not involve government expenditure, and there are no staffing implications for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

The continuation of the act is necessary to enable the AMLC to manage the restrictions which are forced upon us by the US in regard to Australian beef, mutton and goat meat exports and by the EC on beef, sheepmeat and buffalo. The lack of quota powers would result in disruption in the industry and the likelihood of a drop in revenue.

The necessity for this bill reflects the enormous problems for our primary producers brought about by the trade policies, particularly of the US and the EC. We live in hope that the leadership that Australia has taken through the Cairns Group and the strong stance taken by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) recently in the US, Ireland, England and France on farm subsidies will have a positive impact on the outcome of the Uruguay Round of GATT. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) made some interesting comments in his closing remarks, probably one of the more notable referring to `the strong stance taken by the Prime Minister' on these particular issues. I had a look at the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) on this Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Amendment Bill. He told us that in each of the last three years Australia has reluctantly agreed to restrain export of meats to the United States to avoid the imposition of quotas under the US meat import law, MIL.

PARA.TAB: To be honest, I do not think that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) raised that issue with President Clinton at all. I saw nothing to that effect; they were too busy patting each other on the back to get around to such serious issues as the fact that the United States still imposes these particular quotas on us, whilst demanding, of course, that it has the right to send all its American-made advertisements, soap operas and everything else here to Australia at great cost to Australian television stations, et cetera.

Of course, the fundamental issue that is being fought in the GATT at the moment is the demands made by technologically advanced countries such as the US and some European countries. They want access to our markets without a non-tariff barrier. Let me say that the entertainment industry has one of the most efficient non-tariff barriers I have ever seen. An overseas entertainer cannot be brought here to do anything without their being accompanied by Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the best clown in Australia, Wilson.

—I just heard you read your speech. I am making mine without that sort of help. You might tell us if the minister wrote it for you. I do not think you are intelligent enough to make a speech like that. When you learn to make a speech without reading it, with your head buried in your notes—because you do not know how to make a speech—then you can criticise me.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The honourable member will direct his comments through the chair.
Mr Brereton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Laurie, Laurie, Laurie; do not start me on you. Your history does not warrant it. If that is an invitation from the minister to talk about his past, I would welcome it.
—Order! We will have a little bit of silence. The honourable member for O'Connor will get back to the—

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. An aspersion has been cast on the intelligence of the honourable member for Page. It was claimed that he did not have the intelligence to write his own speech. I can assure the honourable member for O'Connor that that is wrong.
—What is the point of order?
—The point of order is that the honourable member for O'Connor is casting an aspersion on the previous speaker.
—Order! There is no point of order. We will not have any interjections. The honourable member for O'Connor will come to the—

—I would be delighted to, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was rereading, for the benefit of the parliament, the comments of the minister. There was an inane interjection from the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), who thinks he can get away with it. Honourable members on the other side of the chamber are very unwise. All they have to do is listen, because I am here to help them on this issue, which is significant to all parts of Australia. I like to think that I can assist them.

PARA.TAB: I happen to have another advantage. I have to admit that I do not frequently run a book on things, but I do run some cattle. In fact, the last of my grain-fed beef proceeds came through to me the other day. That is a declaration of interest. But, as the only member of this House with an electorate where farmers outnumber any other interest group, I think I have some good thoughts to bring to this debate, and I am here to do that in a constructive fashion.

This can be treated as a criticism or a comment, but the simple fact is that this is a very debilitating action by the Americans. It has to be condemned in the context of the size of their economy. I note that President Clinton is starting to get the message that something like 10 or 15 per cent, maybe 20 per cent of the exports of his nation are in the agricultural arena, and that about 80 per cent are in the manufacturing arena. US governments have been ignoring any assistance to the manufacturing arena which, of course, has had to provide the money to subsidise the inefficient agricultural sectors of America and Europe. Here we are, the country that can provide those sorts of products to those countries and to their consumers at the right price, but those countries are too silly to want to take them.

It is not that many years ago that the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), when he was a minister, got involved in trade. There were actually 1,500 copies of a brochure put out in Germany suggesting to consumers that they were getting done by these common agricultural policies and other things. I thought that was a good idea, but that it was woefully underdone. I have forgotten whether it was 1,500 or 15,000 brochures—probably 15,000—but honourable members can imagine how far 15,000 brochures would go in Berlin.

The issue has been kept at the diplomatic level when, in fact, the whole agricultural supply issue is clearly an issue that Australia and its Cairns partners should take to the people of Berlin, to the people of major American cities and to the people of Japan, notwithstanding that the Japanese now have a much more liberal approach to beef imports. The simple story is that an Australian eats the best part of a pound of steak for a few dollars, the freight on that meat being infinitesimal. Those people overseas are being slugged by their own politicians: their living costs have grossly increased through this stupid policy of protecting farmers who are trying to run farms on 20 and 30 acres.

It is time that we said to those people, `We just want to do you and your family a favour. Meet the Smith family of Australia carving up a nice big roast of beef that they bought for $20'—it might be a little more expensive—`for which a Japanese family would pay $1,000'. Why do we not go to those people? I know of no law against it. To the credit of the government, it organised the prawn on the barbie television advertisements; we said to people, `Come and visit Australia'. But we have never taken the debate on agricultural quotas and all the foolish agricultural policies of the world to people to tell them, through media advertising and particularly television, what those quotas and policies are costing them and how silly that is. We should tell them, `Ring your own member of parliament'.

The funny thing about it is that we send people off in delegations to America, for instance—and I have seen it happen from both sides of politics—to complain about these things to another group of politicians. We are saying to those politicians over there, `Now listen, mate, we want you to put your political career at risk to make ours a little more comfortable'. Imagine people visiting us with the same message. We talk to the wrong people. We do not go and talk to their constituents. As politicians we all know who we listen to, and we go and talk to politicians!

The story is true—we sent one delegation over there and the now Republican senate leader, I think he is, Mr Dole, was the only politician who agreed to meet it. Our people were very excited until they got in there and they put their case. Mr Dole stood up with all of these television cameras around them and he vilified them—`Do you think I would take this message back to the good farmers of my area?', he said. He had set the delegation up for the purpose of getting publicity back in his own electorate.

So why do we keep going and talking to the politicians? We should be talking to the people. But we do not have too much to worry about because the Prime Minister did not bother. The Prime Minister was too busy telling Mr Clinton what a good bloke he was. This was on television cameras that never played outside Australia—there was not one bit of coverage. The Prime Minister came back to Australia and said, `I had this wonderful trip to America'. One would have thought that American television actually took any notice of him. Of course not.

The only pictures that ever hit the silver screen were here in Australia. It was all for local consumption. No doubt the deal was worked out—`You say some good things about me, Bill, and I'll say some good things about you'. Bill's problem was that he did not get value for his money because nobody in America heard what our good Prime Minister had to say about Mr Clinton and, what is more, nobody cared. We need to get these things in their proper context.

As the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) told the House, the opposition recognises the need for this legislation and, therefore, supports it. But the simple fact is that we are still subject to these quotas because we have failed to change the attitudes of the major importing countries where we need to sell our product, where we are efficient. We are not efficient in manufacturing areas to the degree necessary to be competitive and generate the sorts of subsidies for our farmers that other nations have managed to do. Therefore, it is necessary that we get down to the issue of convincing the people of those countries.

Someone might tell me that the advertising costs of doing that would be huge, and that may be the case. But when we add up the cost of all our different agricultural schemes, all the running backwards and forwards to GATT meetings and Cairns Group meetings around the world, it might be that an advertising campaign of that nature would work. We have proved the point in the tourist area; by using our well-known sports people and others, we have proved that Australia can get a message to the consumers of America and the consumers of other countries.

It is time we went and told the people of those countries that we just want to do them another favour. We do not want to take anything off them. We just want the working people, who have millions of votes in those countries, to recognise that if their politicians changed their ways, they could live cheaper. And I think that is the way this should be done. I hope that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, considering his influence with the Prime Minister, might put some of those views to him because they are worthy of great consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the area of industrial relations in Australia?
—The other point I was just about to make, and I am prompted by my colleague—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The honourable member's colleague should cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am sure the honourable member for O'Connor can make his point without the interjections of the honourable member for Maranoa and the honourable member for Paterson.

—The point that I wanted to make—and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be aware of this—is that this legislation is all about quotas. It is all about a government entity, the AMLC, being given power under the laws created by this parliament to restrict exports of meat to certain markets because of the attitudes of those countries.

PARA.TAB: But as of yesterday we have a new mechanism. We could actually put this bill aside, because the veterinarians of AQIS are going to do it for us. They have decided to go on strike. They believe that their jobs are more valuable than the jobs of thousands of Australian farmers. The farmers are not the bloodsuckers in the industry; they actually produce something, and farmers in many parts of Australia are currently in desperate need. Many private enterprise veterinarians out there are consequently in desperate need and would fill the jobs that are being vacated tomorrow. They would do a better job for half the money.

Quotas are being put on our exports, anyway. I know that the minister for primary industries would be as concerned as I am about this, because only yesterday he announced in this place what is at least some attempt—it does not go nearly as far as I would like it to go for people in farming—to achieve proper cost structures for inspections and other things. At least he announced the measures whereby he is going to try to make the industry more efficient.

I will stand corrected on these figures, but my recollection is that a meat inspector is charged out at close to $70,000 a year against the industry. His take-home pay is more like $25,000. He is probably one of the people who will not get a tax cut. The simple fact is that he, with that sort of take-home pay, is charged out to the industry at close to $70,000 a year. The industry simply cannot afford it. It is another quota mechanism. People do their sums.

I heard the comments made by the honourable member for Maranoa about the export of sheepmeat. I live in an area where you can grow sheepmeat; I run a farm there. Last week I told my manager to shoot the Dorset Horn lambs because I am fed up with losing money trying to breed lambs. The cost of turning them into meat is such that the net value to me is not worth the effort. Yet this is in an area where, when I was a kid, one producer alone used to send a full train load of lambs away every year. That was the means of transport in those days. There was always a photograph in the West Australian newspaper of a fellow called Stacey filling up a whole train with lambs.

The industry today has just about had it. It cannot produce sheep at a competitive price which the meat industry can turn into competitively priced meat. One of the contributing factors is AQIS. We know that and we know that there are better solutions. A better solution is to let the abattoirs make their own arrangements. They can hire meat inspectors who have been fully licensed by the government. They can meet the export requirements.

I take honourable members back through Hansard to the days of the Fraser government when I had to bully one of our own ministers. Under the constraints of honesty that used to apply in this House, he had to answer me in an entirely different way from the way his department had answered me in writing. He said that there was no obligation upon his government to provide the services of meat inspectors according to the requirements of import competing countries. The only requirement is that we supervise meat inspection.

I gave evidence to the royal commission into the last meat inspection scandal. The people who are making these remarks at present say that, if the primary industries minister is to reduce the number of people involved and reduce the cost, we risk having another substitution scam. What a load of rubbish. Who was in charge of meat inspection when the last scandal occurred? It was these same people.

TALK.START.PARA: —More of them.

—Yes. They did it and they were up to here in it, as the royal commission told us. They had a QC flying around Australia wherever anyone gave evidence. He cross-examined me and my evidence was simply that meat inspectors should be employees of the works, as should these veterinarians; they should be answerable to the works. If it is a big works, there is one Commonwealth inspector there to perceive that things are going properly; if it is a smaller works, we have a roving fellow.

PARA.TAB: The QC said to me, `Don't you understand what would happen when all of these private enterprise inspectors were around the place?'. I said to him, `Well, how did you get to Perth?'. He said, `I flew in TAA', as it was named in those days. I said, `Well, who do you think certified your aeroplane as safe to fly in? Do you think it was a government inspector? If you did, you are wrong'. The answer is that it was an LAME, a licensed aircraft maintenance engineer, licensed by the government but employed by the airline. We have one of the safest airline industries in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a government airline.

—It does not matter. Both Qantas and Ansett employ their own inspectors. If I had the choice when comparing meat with flying an aeroplane, I would rather have a tummy ache than have a wing drop off at 40,000 feet. We have a situation where we demand that our meat be inspected by the government but we allow our planes to be inspected by private enterprise. Which is the safest? There are no major scandals in the airline industry as in the meat substitution racket.

PARA.TAB: What are these blokes fighting for? They are not fighting for me, the consumer, or all the farmers I represent. No, they are fighting for their own greedy selves. It is an outrage. I am here defending the minister, whom they are fighting against. I hope he has the courage to take them on. He should ring up those country veterinarians and give them the protection of the law to go in and let us at least get back to the quotas that we legislate for in this parliament, not quotas imposed by veterinarians and others who are just trying to protect their own greedy living when there is not one ounce of logic in doing it. It is a disgrace and it is time it stopped, because it is costing housewives money and it is costing others money.

Until recently there was a works in my electorate which was administered by local government. The qualifications of all the meat inspectors are exactly the same as those employed by the Commonwealth. There was a time when they had both. But the local government, by law of Western Australia, is told how much it can charge for each animal for meat inspection services. It is about a quarter of the cost applicable for federal government inspection charges, yet the local authority that provides these inspectors makes a profit. They make a profit of about a quarter, yet that was the system that people tried to close down.

I know so much about it because in that local authority those inspectors fought to the death to give a service that they could give so well. In Victoria, of course, they learnt their lesson. They took the Commonwealth inspectors and saw their costs blow through the ceiling. In my electorate, I have had cases where one Commonwealth inspector resident in Geraldton has driven to Perth to do his job and another in Perth has driven up to Geraldton to do his job and they passed on the way. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise to support the Australian Meat and Livestock (Quotas) Amendment Bill. For the past 20 minutes I have been wondering what we have been debating. It is very interesting to note that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) during his speech took on the Americans, who he claimed were too stupid to want to take our beef, and the meat inspectors. I am not sure whether he took on aircraft inspectors or not. I thought it was only the government that he objected to, but it would appear that he objects to everyone.

PARA.TAB: Some of the things that have been said tonight are very interesting, but I am pleased that the opposition is supporting this bill because it represents a positive but a non-aggressive marketing tool for very valuable and increasing export goods. There is no doubt that Australia has the potential to increase productivity of red meat. We could do it to a stage where we could swamp the world markets with beef, lamb and mutton and reduce the price alarmingly—certainly to a stage where many of our producers would experience great difficulty in continuing their operations.

The history of meat prices, undersupply, oversupply and quotas, both self-imposed and externally imposed, has made the grazing and feedlotting industries a lottery and certainly without security. As a primary producer and a member of a government which represents as many rural electorates as does the National Party, it certainly gives me a great deal of pride that the bill introduced in 1990 has had the effect of bringing a great deal of security to members of the grazing industry.

I think it speaks well for Australia that much of our restraint has been self-imposed. Since 1990 we have seen a levelling out of the peaks and troughs. That has been beneficial to producers. They can have a certain expectation of their prices so they can plan their operation. Similarly, the buyers of the meat we export know that Australia is a consistent producer of a quality product and that we demand a fair price.

Every producer—it does not matter what the product—would like to be able to sell 100 per cent of his production. Unfortunately, that is a very rare situation. The honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) said that in an ideal trading world we would be able to do that, but when we are opening up new export markets, when we are exporting to countries that have a long history of domestic production, obviously we have to treat them carefully.

There are attitudes of resistance to our produce by the domestic suppliers in countries we export to. From time to time they will lobby their governments and they will lobby them strongly enough to gain support so that quotas will be imposed to prevent access by our product into their market. The confrontationist approach that existed in the pre-1990s could hardly be described as successful and it is not one that I would recommend for our industry today. Actually, our meat export figures indicate a market that we cannot jeopardise by changing our policies. So we are grateful that the opposition is supportive of this particular bill.

Not only are we retaining our traditional markets in the world such as the United States, Canada and Europe, but markets such as Japan, Korea and Taiwan are expanding. I am confident that as the standard of living in South-East Asia escalates in the next decade so too will the demand for beef. Once again, these new markets will need to be treated with sensitivity.

In relation to live sheep exports, I was interested to hear the comments of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), particularly his acceptance that this market was generally lost as a result of the way we attacked it because we thought those people would accept any sheep that we were prepared to put on a ship.

Some grazing friends of mine that keep sheep often speak of the quality of sheep that they really did not think they would be able to sell on a local market and which they happened to get on a ship to send off to the Arabian countries. That is very unfortunate. Obviously, we are repenting at leisure now. That is the sort of thing that must not creep back into any trading practices that we develop in the future. I believe this bill will prevent that type of thing happening.

Having visited the Fletcher slaughtering facility at Dubbo, which is one of the largest sleep slaughtering facilities in Australia and which employs in the order of 500 people, I understand that particular facility can slaughter sheep that are accepted by members of the Muslim race. That is because the slaughter is done in accordance with their religious principles. I believe that we should be encouraging representatives from countries that want live sheep exports to come to Australia and inspect our slaughter facilities because they are going to get a better product and we are going to get the employment. I have no doubt about that. I sincerely hope that over the next few years in negotiations for live sheep markets that suggestion is made. In that way, we are in the driving seat; we can guarantee the quality.

I strongly support the bill before the House this evening. Despite the imminent entry of Argentina into the world market for beef, I believe that the future augurs well for Australian beef producers. But I mention a matter that concerns me in relation to our beef industry, in particular; that is, the vertical integration by offshore investors into our beef industry. I am talking about the fact that breeding, fattening, slaughtering and export facilities are owned by the one company. This places people in the grazing industry at a tremendous disadvantage because such vertically integrated companies do not have to make a profit up to the point of export. Their profit is made from the export stage onwards, particularly if they are the selling company in their own country.

I did not think I would ever get to the stage where I would agree with the honourable member for O'Connor, but he identified that point as well. I am sure that an enormous profit is being made on our produce outside this country. The poor old Australian grazier has to be able to compete up to that point where very little profit is taken by these organisations, so he is at a distinct disadvantage.

As a beef producer, I know that when the cattle are right, they have to be sold. If they are sold on a day when such an organisation is selling a large yardage of cattle, then that is tough; the grower does not make much money that day. I can assure the House that, as long as I am a member, I will oppose the increased participation in our industry by companies such as ConAgra, the Itoman Corporation, Nippon Meat Packers and Mitsubishi, because I believe it is companies such as these that are not necessarily acting in the interest of real prices to the Australian producer.

We produce a world-class product, we are proud of that product and I believe Australians have the right to benefit from it. The only way we are going to do that is by being in the driving seat; by being in control. I have only taken up 10 minutes but, just as the opposition is supporting this bill, I also have great pleasure in supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very disappointing that we have to pass this legislation extending meat quota powers to the AMLC for a further three years in relation to the United States and other markets. One would have hoped that perhaps the Uruguay Round could have been over by now and that we could be further advanced with regard to a better access system than we are required by the United States and the Europeans to have—particularly, in relation to beef, by the United States.

PARA.TAB: It does raise very sharply the double standards of the United States in its trade practices. The meat import law was passed by the United States in 1964 and it has had the nice euphemism of voluntary restraints ever since. It has not only used it for beef but also for Japanese cars from time to time. For the last three years those voluntary restraints, which reluctantly are imposed at this end to prevent more restrictive restraints at the United States end, have been in place.

When I say the United States has a terrible double standard with regard to trade, and in particular the beef industry, I am not saying that it is worse than the European Community, but the European Community does not try to put any moral gloss on what it does. For example, at the same time as we were being forced to have these voluntary restraints on quotas, the United States took Korea and Japan to the GATT to force them to drop quotas and to tariffy—to put tariffs in place—for access for beef to those markets. That was successful and Australia has gained its competitive share of those tariffied markets. But at the same time as the United States was being holier than thou with Japan and Korea, it was adopting this beautiful double standard by continuing to impose tariffs against Australia.

When one looks at some of the other restraints of the United States on our trade one sees that with sugar the United States is worse than the European Community. In relation to the export enhancement program for grain the United States certainly is tougher than the European Community at present because it has an October deadline by which to spend its budget. Its dairy export program is not as significant as the Europeans' because it does not have the same surplus.

What is very ironic is that for years the United States railed against Australia because we had a quota on tobacco in Australia. But in the last farm bills of the United States—I think it is even in the budget that went through earlier this year—the United States itself has now imposed a quota on tobacco. That additional protective measure is coming at a time when the United States is supposedly going full steam ahead for a more open trade regime with the Uruguay Round. One could go on to cotton and other items.

I would also like to look at how the United States and, for that matter, the Europeans, adopt dumping practices. All of us follow the GATT code, but that GATT code is a very broad criterion. Both the United States and the Europeans use that criterion far more aggressively and protectively than does Australia. To a certain extent I agree with the Europeans, and particularly the Americans, that we should adopt those same policies ourselves with regard to what constitutes dumping.

I will just give an example with regard to how both the Europeans and the Americans have a different stance on dumping from ours. I use the example of canned fruit. For years, even though a tariff had to be paid for any Australian canned fruit going into Europe, the Australian exporters in the canned fruit industry would have to go to Europe each year and negotiate a voluntary restraint agreement additional to the formal restrictions.

In 1972, over 20 years ago, the United States International Trade Commission, the ITC, with only one out of the three commissioners voting, not two out of three, determined that Australia was dumping canned pears in the United States. Under the United States dumping code, every five years its people have to ask people in the industry whether anybody would suffer potential material injury if canned pears could be imported from Australia. Logically, there is always somebody who puts up a hand and says, `Yes, I would, or could, materially suffer'. So it means that we have this absurd situation that for more than 20 years no Australian canned pears have been allowed into the United States.

I would hope that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) and other ministers are aggressively addressing in relation to the Uruguay Round that terrible injustice with regard to US dumping procedures. I am concerned with our beef access to the United States, even if there is a successful Uruguay Round. From my information, our access could actually be worse than it is now. The United States has put up its proposal that there will still be a quota—no tariffication, but a quota. If that quota is applied on a global basis, Australia will actually be worse off. Instead of Australia having an agreed access into or quota with the United States, the seasonal nature of the beef industry in Australia—that is, from an export point of view, as my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) knows well—means its season starts well into the calendar year. Other countries, like New Zealand, whose slaughter program starts earlier in the year, would have the jump on us and therefore any change would be a retrograde step for us. But even if that is sorted out by having specific country quotas in the post-Uruguay situation—and my understanding is that it still has to be successfully negotiated—the United States will still want a 30 per cent tariff. There is only a certain price that can be obtained for hamburger beef in the United States because of the cost pressures of the white meat industry—that is, chicken and pork. Unless we have a disastrously low dollar, a 30 per cent tariff effectively means that we have no opportunity at a profitable level to increase our exports to the United States. That means that there is some hard negotiating to be carried out in the bilateral discussions in relation to the multilateral Uruguay Round if it is successful—and I certainly hope it is—to see that we gain something for our beef exports to the United States rather than lose ground.

The EC is referred to in this bill because it imposes even more restrictive quotas. It then has, to my knowledge, a common external tariff as well as the quotas which have to be paid. That is not enough for the EC, because it brings in some nice non-tariff barriers as well such as hormones—even natural hormones. Those who read any European agricultural magazines will know that far more hormones are being used in the European Community in the beef industry than in Australia and in some other countries. The EC officials were out here recently. They are imposing higher and higher standards on abattoirs in Australia which, by a non-tariff, cynical tactic, could make it too expensive for anybody in Australia to bother to service this very limited EC market. If anybody has been to abattoirs in the European Community or, for that matter, in the United States, the good old double standards appear again. There is a difference in the standard of their abattoirs compared with what is required for our abattoirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do as I say, not do as I do.

—That is right. I want to talk about the real problems that come with a quota system and the allocations of quotas for the beef industry, while acknowledging that it is the United States that forces these quotas on us, not we on ourselves. The first problem is that quotas restrict access. We cannot increase our exports to that market. Secondly, they redistribute profit within the industry and within Australia, because those who hold the quotas get more than their fair share, in my view, of the profit—it is not distributed fairly throughout the industry as a whole. The price to producers is reduced by as much as 30 per cent.

PARA.TAB: It is one thing to talk about a quota being free with regard to its allocation; it is another thing to talk about the traded price of it when a processor needs quota, and 55c a kilogram was a very common price paid for quota into the United States a few months ago, and it still could be the case. That is up to 30 per cent of the price for our chopper cows which form a very significant part of the United States market. The performance of trading in quotas is not unique to the meat industry and, until quotas were removed in the textile industry, that was another example.

The next problem that this quota system creates in the industry is that it freezes the industry processing sector. It works against the future interests of the industry, it delays rationalisation of the processing industry and it goes against desirable trends that are necessary for a future processing sector that is more productive.

We do have quite a contrast in Australia between what I call the old style dinosaur type abattoirs, large rambling single shift ones with a whole range of problems including industrial problems, and the more cost efficient, low capital, New Zealand style, or boutique style, or whatever you like to call them, high throughput abattoirs—and I happen to have one in my electorate—where the basis of their efficiency is multiple shifts and a far greater use of new technology, including hot boning. This is something that the industry should be encouraging because it provides the opportunity to dramatically reduce the cost of processing. As the honourable member for Maranoa mentioned, the cost of processing in a beef abattoir in this country is two to three times that of our competitors. That is a dramatic reduction in profitability to our producers. The final price in the export market must remain, so it is a reduced price to the producer.

That is typified by the fact that according to the reports—and there have been many of them, all confirming this most inefficient sector of the industry—the average abattoir in Australia works for 32 hours a week and the new style ones in New Zealand for 120 hours a week. So there is a dramatic difference in the efficient use of capital and, therefore, the efficiency of those abattoirs.

But under the current quota allocation system, new style abattoirs like the one in my electorate—there are one or two others around Australia and, if they were given a fair go, there would be far more—were granted only a 500-tonne quota to the United States and you cannot make a living, even with a low cost capital abattoir, on 500 tonnes. The rest has to be bought, and bought at 55c a kilogram or even higher.

The quota allocation to the United States is controlled too much by the existing exporters, and I guess they see it as being to their benefit to keep it that way. The Cattle Council has not been assertive or aggressive enough on what it knows is the essential future for the meat processing industry in this country and a fair go for different areas of Australia. There has to be, for next year, a far better allocation of quota to some of those new entrants.

The next point I want to make is that the quota system reduces competition. Two companies have the overwhelming amount of quota to the United States. It does not worry me who they are; it is the fact that there are only two. They have tremendous leverage to use that quota themselves. That also gives them the jump on the diversification to other markets that flows as part of the attempts of the AMLC to try to get our meat going to all the markets necessary and, of course, to sell quotas if they want to. It has got to the stage that in northern Queensland and right throughout northern Australia there is such a low opinion of the meat processing companies and the lack of competition that, wherever they can, they are selling those cattle live off-shore. I happened to be in Karumba not that long ago when there were cattle going out to the Philippines.

Selling live cattle is not necessarily to Australia's benefit because the importing countries make sure that any value adding takes place in their country by graduated tariffs, and the cattle that go out, go out young, and are finished off and, of course, processed in the other country. But it does indicate the frustrations of cattle producers in those areas with regard to lack of competition, lack of what they consider to be a fair go, the very high cost of processing and the cost of transport.

We support the legislation, recognising that it is essential. Hopefully, matters will be wound up before the three years but there are warnings that, if the Uruguay Round is successful, we will have to do better in our negotiations, and the AMLC, the Cattle Council and the meat exporters need to have a fairer and more positive form of quota allocation for the next calendar year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my two colleagues the honourable member for Page (Mr Woods) and the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) who have spoken before me in this debate on the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Amendment Bill. As they both indicated, this bill extends the operation of the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 for a further three years to 28 December 1996.

PARA.TAB: The legislation would allow the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, the AMLC, to operate quota mechanisms on exports of Australian meat and live sheep where restrictions are placed by importing countries or may be imposed. The legislation was a response to a series of rejections of live sheep shipments to the Middle East in 1989-90 and augmented quota mechanisms already operating in relation to exports to the United States and the European Community.

It is deemed necessary to continue the operation of the quota system to manage the current restrictions imposed by the United States government on imported beef, mutton and goat meat and on our exports of beef, sheepmeat and buffalo to the European Community. Without the operation of a voluntary restraint arrangement, it is likely that Australia's access to the US market would be reduced by 10 per cent—a significant amount when one considers that our beef exports to the US are worth $1.1 billion a year. The lack of a quota mechanism would result in significant uncertainty and disruption to the industry, particularly in Queensland, which is heavily orientated to the US export market.

The powers contained in the act will also be necessary to manage the re-establishment of the live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia, if and when the opportunity arises. As the honourable member for Page and other speakers have indicated, Australia has similar problems with its access to the European Community markets.

Australia's beef and veal exports are worth in excess of $2 billion. After the US, the main markets are: Japan, worth approximately $938 million in exports; Korea, worth $256 million; Canada, worth $126 million; and Taiwan, worth $133 million. Australia's sheepmeat exports are valued at approximately $504 million. Protection of our market share requires continual negotiation, given the trade barriers which apply. I believe that our government is being assiduous in its negotiations on our behalf.

Despite domestic pressure from Japanese producers, we anticipate that Japan will continue to honour the Australia-Japan agreement of 1988. Already, our trade has been boosted by a 50 per cent reduction in tariff. A new beef agreement with Korea was signed in July and it should significantly improve our market share.

Australia is presently in dispute with Canada following the recommendation of the Canadian International Trade Tribunal, the CITT, to the Canadian government that a tariff of 25 per cent be applied to all imports of boneless beef sourced from outside the US until the end of 1995. Following strong representations from the Australian government, Canada agreed to re-examine the restriction applying past the end of 1993. The AMLC has challenged the CITT findings in the Canadian Federal Court of Appeal.

Due to the operation of the US meat import law, the MIL, Australia reluctantly agreed to voluntarily restrict meat exports to 315,200 tonnes in 1993—17,000 tonnes below the 1992 limit—at a cost to the Australian industry of more than $50 million. However, this voluntary restraint avoided the activation of the trigger level which would have reduced access by 10 per cent at a cost of $100 million.

As other speakers have indicated, the MIL is a major barrier to fair trading between the US and Australia. The government is committed to working towards its elimination both through bilateral negotiations with the US Administration and through the Uruguay Round of GATT.

Consultations with cattle industry representatives in my electorate reveal trenchant opposition from producers to the MIL and consequent acceptance of the need for the continuation of the quota mechanism to provide stability and the 10 per cent increase in market share provided by the present system. The government is lobbying strenuously to have the MIL replaced as part of the Uruguay Round. To this end, Senator Peter Cook has scheduled a meeting of the Cairns Group for mid-October. This is why the focus of the meetings that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had with the US President was on developing creative solutions to international trade issues.

Once again, the Prime Minister's ability to demonstrate leadership on these matters will be in the long-term economic interests of this country. It was therefore interesting to note the paltry criticisms of his world trip made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in this House yesterday. The Leader of the Opposition suggested that the Prime Minister should have raised the problem of US farm subsidies, which of course he did. The fact is that raising such issues has not in the past resulted in immediate altruism from American agricultural lobbyists. It is naive to think it would. Presumably, the opposition leader would then have blamed the Prime Minister for his lack of success. Fortunately for the future prospects of this country, we have a Prime Minister who can think strategically.

The development of new trading relationships based on our mutual interests in the Asia-Pacific region is more likely to result in an effective trading quid pro quo than bleating about a trade barrier based on US domestic self-interest. Unlike the carping criticism of the Leader of the Opposition, the consensus in reports of the American visit was that it was an outstanding success. Just as it is possible for smaller countries to carve out niche markets by utilising skill, diplomacy and strategy, Australia can carve for itself a place of influence in regional trade negotiations.

I want to turn to some issues in relation to this bill that are of some importance to my electorate. As I have said, the bill aims to provide stability in a market affected by the imposition of trade barriers by our customer countries, all of which places more pressure on producers to be as efficient as possible. Our beef producers in central Queensland are part of this effort and have been wrestling with extremely difficult drought conditions. I was therefore pleased to note the announcement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) of additional funding to Queensland for drought affected farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not additional funding; it is a reallocation.

—Additional funding for exceptional circumstances via the rural adjustment scheme will provide an immediate increase of $3.1 million. From the start of the pilot drought scheme in September 1992—as I am sure the honourable member for Maranoa knows only too well—until 31 August this year, 1,847 Queensland farmers have received a total of $16 million in support through the exceptional circumstances provisions. I am aware, through my discussions with primary producers, local government representatives, Queensland government officials and political representatives that we have not been able to meet all the needs. This is particularly frustrating for those individuals and groups trying to assist families on the ground. It must be remembered, however, that ultimately the rural industry sector needs to become self-sufficient and able to manage the risks inherent in the industry. That is the thrust of federal government policy—assistance. I believe that the minister has the respect and credibility of primary industry representatives.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the beef export industry, which is the focus of this legislation, I want to mention a specific issue—it relates to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd)—in terms of efficiency in the processing end of the industry. I certainly consider his comments on the importance of the primary producers having more say in the ultimate negotiations on prices to be very important. I did not have a problem with that.

The Smorgon Group, following its acquisition of the Angliss Group, became the second largest processor for 1992, with a capacity of over 800,000 cattle through its five abattoirs. It exports 90 per cent of its production, it has over 2,000 employers and a turnover in excess of $500 million. It is disappointing, therefore, to report that the company's industrial relations orientation would appear to be back in the dark ages where employees are not valued as an integral part of the operation of value adding. This was demonstrated in the recent industrial dispute at its Lakes Creek meatworks in Rockhampton, a dispute which spread to its Townsville abattoir. What effectively became a lockout situation will not ultimately improve productivity, nor will an attempt to bludgeon people into accepting the stripping away of award conditions.

I am pleased to report that the coalmining unions in the Bowen basin provided effective support for the meatworkers in their dispute, and there was also a great deal of effective community support. I am glad to be able to say that there has been a return to work. I hope that the company will now sit down and negotiate effective work practices and productivity issues with the work force.

While there is no doubt that new technology, plant and equipment will assist this process, it will not help to bludgeon people into submission. For those people who have not worked at, or been to, a meatworks, it is a very tough end of the work force. It is not easy work; it is hard and difficult work. It is still true that workers front up for a line-up to see if they can get a few hours or a couple of days work on a casual basis. This is not easy when we are trying to bring up a family and pay our costs. It is very difficult work. It is very important to our export initiative that we have effective work practices and improve our productivity, but we will not do it with this kind of industrial relations policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you read the IC report on impediments to regional Australia?

—I have read the IC report, and in my view it is absolutely appalling. If we are going to develop this very important export market, we must remember that we have a number of players and stakeholders. We will require the collaboration of government, producers and the work force to achieve improvements to this vital export industry. This legislation is but one aspect of the government's commitment to further developing our commodity exports in a highly competitive world trade environment.

PARA.TAB: The news is not all bad. Before I conclude, I would like to mention that we are going to have the Rockhampton brahman week. Australia's biggest bull sale is to be held between 6 and 8 October. There will be 933 bulls for sale. Mr Deputy Speaker, you might say this is an enormous amount of bull, and it is certainly true that Rockhampton is the beef capital of Australia. Rockhampton has a number of amazing statues at both ends of the town. I might mention that they often lose a particular part of their appendage, which is creating some difficulties in the city.

In spite of very difficult circumstances in the industry—including the drought—it is important to note that there has obviously been an upturn recently with the rains that we have had, and there is a new air of optimism. In fact, it was reported that the sentiment was quite bullish in the market. This augurs well for the industry.

I would like to refer to another initiative. There was a very particular cattle sale at the CSIRO in Rockhampton recently, and that was the first auction of boran and tuli in utero embryos, which are the product of a long project by CSIRO in collaboration with primary producers in the cattle industry. This has been a remarkable story of how science and technology can assist our export effort. Over a long period of time genetic material was brought to Australia from Africa. It was very exciting to be at the sale of these wonderful new breeds of cattle which will be particularly adapted to our Australian conditions. I believe these cattle are going to make a huge difference to our exports in this area.

It reminds us—if we need to be reminded, and I think we do—of the importance of research and development, and allocating funds to the longer term development of new technology in this area. I commend all those involved in the boran and tuli venture and hope that this government will continue to support such innovations coming from organisations such as the CSIRO.

In conclusion, I am glad to say that this bill has the support of the opposition; it has the support of the industry, and I made sure of this by contacting cattle producers in my electorate before I rose to speak in this house. I commend the bill to the house.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the Australian Meat and Live-Stock (Quotas) Amendment Bill which is before the parliament. I was pleased to hear the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) speaking in the way that she did. As we all know, Capricornia is a very strong beef seat and it is very obvious that the honourable member has the interests of her electorate at heart.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the bill is to extend the power of the AMLC for a further three years so that it can establish quota schemes for the export of meat and live sheep from Australia in particular circumstances. Both the free trading United States and the protectionist EC impose import restrictions on our meat exports. Apparently, the EC thinks it is important to charge its less well off people a lot more than it needs to for food, including meat. This is based on the principle of `From him that hath not it shall be taken', because the French peasantry has many votes. I think they call this social equity in France, because socialist governments in France also endorse the policy. However, as we all know, the cost to the EC of not pursuing freer trade is absolutely immense and, if the French sabotage the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations, all Europe will suffer, particularly the French.

It has now been estimated that farm subsidisation by the rich industrial countries costs between $US270 billion and $US300 billion per year, if one takes consumer transfer into account. The United States and Australia worked well together to break down some of the wall of protection surrounding the Japanese beef market through the 1980s and protection is now only a 50 per cent tariff.

I will never forget the statement of a US official during those negotiations. He said that if the United States and Australia could not get access to the Japanese meat market, then Australia might try even harder to break down the meat import law, and he did not have his tongue in his cheek. Because of the vagaries of the US legislative system, the counter-cyclical meat import law was attached to legislation in the mid-1960s, removing an anomaly which required the payment of a tariff on racehorses returning from overseas which were owned by United States citizens while they were out of the country.

In terms of the type of meat we export to the United States, our product provides little, if any, threat to US producers. Recently, we had the ridiculous situation whereby Canada imposed import controls because Australian meat was allegedly flowing through Canada to meet the high demand and prices for meat in the US at a time when quotas were imposed on our meat going into the United States.
