We are also required to meet the export plant and inspection standards of the United States Department of Agriculture, and we are pleased to. But I think it helps to understand at times that our meat trade is a very controlled one and we have to fight for every bit of additional market we can get. Out of the goodness of its heart, we get a few tonnes of meat into the EC, within quota. It is ironic that we constantly have to deal with European business people wanting to import product from Australia who do not realise that they are prohibited by the EC's own protectionist policies.

The bill provides a reminder of the role that the AMLC plays in keeping the fiercely competing arms of the industry working together. If the AMLC did not perform tasks such as quota imposition, setting up systems to deal with such matters as contaminants, such as organochlorines, and dealing with questions associated with the live sheep trade and health issues, the government would have had to be more directly involved. Quite frankly, governments do not have the flexibility, and sometimes they do not have the trust.

Producers, saleyard operators, processors, workers, inspectors, wholesalers and retailers all interact competitively in this industry and it is very important that there be an organisation of the strength and ability of the AMLC where the key actors have some ownership. In order to unite the industry, facilitate trade and develop and promote the domestic market, it is important to have the identity of a government body to handle markets that are really government to government and to have the flexibility to meet promotional and marketing competition.

Some of the work of the statutory marketing authorities in general could be handled by Austrade. But it is the nature of the producing and processing industries to require a consultative levy paying mechanism, such as that of the AMLC. Some Darwinists in the processing industry, who believe in the survival of the fattest, are seeking to all but destroy the AMLC and make it a much leaner, supposedly more commercial, body. The AMLC is very commercial. It has been so under its former chairman, Mr Dick Austen, and continues to be so under Mr Cotton.

It is not possible for the private export industry to achieve all that the AMLC has been achieving on its own, no matter what a few greedy operators think—just because they resent paying a levy to part fund the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. All parts of the industry determined the present funding level. I do not believe that it should be destroyed on the basis of greed, ideology or perversity. If the industry wants to spend more on promotion or marketing, or less, or meet a particular demand or requirement, it can do this within its own arrangements. This gives all players within the industry the flexibility they need.

While it may be said that the AMLC does a bit too much for the export sector at times, this is a question only of judgment or balance. The levy paying industry, the board or the policy council are the best judges. The past decade has been one of significant growth for the Australian meat and livestock industries. The beef industry, in particular, has grown considerably over this period. Evidence of this growth can be seen in a number of industry statistics.

Total beef and veal production has grown from 1.41 million tonnes in 1984 to 1.84 million tonnes in 1992, while the farm-gate value of production has risen from about $2.1 billion to $3.7 billion over this period. To a large degree, this growth in output has occurred as a result of advanced export opportunities, particularly in Asia. In volume terms, beef and veal exports have almost doubled over the past decade, rising from 616,000 tonnes in 1984 to 1.191 million tonnes in 1992, while the value of exports has increased from $1.1 billion in 1983-84 to almost $2.8 billion in 1991-92.

Also of note is the strong growth in exports of high value products such as chilled and grain fed beef in recent years. For example, exports of chilled, grain fed beef to Japan have increased by over 1,300 per cent between 1988 and 1992. High value is the way to go with respect to value adding in the industry, because most people still like to buy meat raw. It is in the areas of finishing, chilling, packaging and getting dependable supplies of grains for finishing off cattle where higher value added products can be aimed for.

On the domestic market, beef consumption was stable at around 40 kilograms per head for much of the 1980s but it fell to about 37 kilograms per head in 1992 largely due to depressed economic conditions. In real terms, however, the value of domestic sales has been approximately stable since 1987-88. Trends in the sheepmeat industry have been less clear cut than those in the beef industry. Mutton production has been extremely high since 1990 as the result of problems with the wool industry. The industry has been successful in developing new export and domestic outlets for this increased volume of production.

Lamb production has been trending downwards since 1984, partly as a result of stagnant to declining consumption in the major outlet for lamb—the domestic market. But, recently, prices have been picking up. Despite this decline in production, the lamb industry has managed to increase exports, especially the higher value cuts. Particularly significant has been the growth in exports of chilled lamb to North America. Recently the industry has put in place a major campaign, the trim lamb campaign, aimed at arresting the declining domestic consumption and increasing sales of lean, boneless lamb cuts.

The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation has played an instrumental role in the development of the meat and livestock industries over the last decade. Since its inception in its current form in 1984, the corporation has implemented programs in three key areas: market access, market information and marketing systems, and marketing and promotion. Activities in all these areas will enable the industry to capitalise on new opportunities and to remain competitive with competing meats and foods, by changing consumer perceptions of red meat, implementing marketing systems that reduce selling costs and better matching production to consumer requirements.

In all these areas, the overriding philosophy of the corporation has been to work to improve the efficiency of operational markets rather than intervene directly in the operation of the market itself. This philosophy reflects the corporation's and, for that matter, the government's view that, with few exceptions, the normal unimpeded operation of markets will provide optimum outcomes. Consequently, the corporation has confined itself to activities that are of net benefit to the industry but which, because of their nature, would not be provided at optimal levels by the industry itself.

Market access is one such type of activity. I want to touch on the Andriessen assurances, which was gained in 1985. Those assurances, which effectively kept most of the Asian region free from massively subsidised EC beef, have been the foundation on which much of the growth of the Australian beef industry has been built. There is no way that I am going to downgrade in any sense the role played by government in securing the Andriessen assurances. But the truth is that the government, the AMLC and the industry worked very well in that enterprise as we did in many other areas. The then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, is to be congratulated, as are some of the key public servants of the time—Mr Duthie and Mr Teece.

The lead-up to the Andriessen assurances occurred at a time when the corporation was on the lookout for threats and was able to provide to government high quality analytical advice. We worked with those assurances, and we had our own advice at the time. Together, we examined the threat from the EC and the market opportunities in Asia. Of particular importance was the part the corporation played in analysing the policy mechanism that the EC used to provide export subsidies.

I well remember that the corporation's analysis highlighted the fact that subsidies for existing and new markets could be introduced or adjusted on an arbitrary basis by relatively junior EC commission officials on the beef management committee. Through this analysis, the corporation recognised the need to institute a procedure to ensure that export subsidies to Asia could be introduced only after review by EC officials at the highest level—that is, the EC commissioners—and only after notifying the Australian government that export subsidies to these markets were to be introduced.

It is fair to say that the corporation, through its status as an industry organisation and its close links with the industry as well as government, was able to stress to us the commercial implications of the EC gaining access to Asian markets. Today, the corporation continues to provide a bridge between industry and government on access issues. Invariably, the optimal targeting and progression of access issues requires both a detailed knowledge of the workings of the market and an in-depth understanding of government processes.

The corporation's market knowledge stems from its marketing activities and dealings with industry. Conversely, by reason of its statutory nature, which I have already touched upon, the corporation enjoys close connections with government. With the Andriessen assurances and from a knowledge of the market, the corporation was able to fully appreciate the potential for market growth in north Asia. From the knowledge of government, the corporation and industry all working together, we were able to marshall bureaucratic support, and that got us the final agreement.

At that time, the corporation also played an important role in alerting similar organisations in both importing and competing countries to risks of this massively subsidised EC competition. For example, the corporation worked closely with the LIPC in Japan, which is not an organisation that gave us much joy. But it provided information on the commercial implications of the entry of EC beef and, in addition, highlighted factors such as the differences in product quality and quality assurance systems between the EC and Australia.

Similarly, the AMLC worked closely with the New Zealand Meat Producers Board and US agencies, such as the US Meat Exporters Federation and the US special trade representative. This coordinated industry wide approach would not have been as effective if carried out by individual exporters. It ensured that the maximum international pressure was placed on the EC to agree to the assurance. Today, where appropriate, the corporation continues to liaise closely with overseas governments, statutory organisations and industry associations. Again, I reinforce the point that government does not always have the flexibility of the statutory marketing authority and that no single individual exporter could do this sort of job.

The Andriessen assurances would not have been nearly as valuable were it not for the liberalisation of the Japanese and Korean beef markets, which has occurred in recent years. Again, the corporation, in working with government, played a vital part in achieving liberalisation in these countries. We agreed that the concept of tariffication is the preferred process of liberalisation. The Japanese market was the way to go, and the Australian government then convinced the United States government of the merits of this approach.

A lot of detailed and analytical input on the quota arrangements to allow Australia to negotiate transitional quota arrangements—these applied for three years—stopped the slide in Australia's market share and strongly positioned the Australian industry for the tariffication of quotas in 1990. The corporation, through close consultation with industry, was able to ensure government officials were well advised of key commercial concerns, options and priorities, and developed strong industry consensus and support for negotiating objectives and strategies. Finally, corporation officers were directly involved with government officials in the negotiation of liberalisation of the Japanese beef market. I well remember when the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) and I signed that agreement.

Another important access achievement has been in the introduction of countervailing duties on EC beef from Canada. The corporation again played a significant part in ensuring that these countervailing duties were implemented. As well as mounting pressure on the Canadian government and industry to act, the corporation provided considerable assistance to the Canadian Cattlemen's Association in the preparation of its case. Appearing on behalf of the Australian industry, the corporation also presented a case to the Canadian International Trade Tribunal, which highlighted issues such as the impact on imported and domestic beef prices of EC imports, and the flow-on consequences in other markets of the diversion of significant quantities of Australian and New Zealand product away from the Canadian market. Of course, we can make that same point about the United States with respect to the meat import law.

I think it is fair to say that the corporation had three distinct advantages over other groups in presenting this case to the tribunal. First, an industry statutory body has more credibility and authority in presenting arguments to the tribunal. Secondly, the corporation was able to present a coordinated industry case which presented or reflected the views and interests of all in the industry rather than only particular sectoral views. Thirdly, having specialist trade policy skills available internally meant that the corporation was able to research this issue thoroughly and present a detailed and well-reasoned case to the tribunal.

Two of the corporation's most important achievements in the market information and marketing systems area have been the establishment of Aus-Meat and CALM. Both are examples of marketing infrastructure which, because of their nature, the industry is unlikely to have developed itself. Aus-Meat has developed a meat and livestock language system which enables both live animals and meat to be traded on the basis of objective descriptions. This has improved the flow of information back to the producer and led to improved carcass quality and a better matching of production to end market needs.

Supporting the language and product description system is Aus-Meat's quality assurance programs. This is effectively an industry-run quality assurance program which has received widespread acceptance by domestic and overseas purchasers. CALM is a computer-aided livestock marketing system, and its establishment has conferred several benefits on the industry. It is still slowly being adopted by the industry.

The final area of AMLC activities has been marketing and promotion. Here, the focus has been on changing consumer perception of red meat by advertising the generic qualities of meat, such as trade, nutrition and convenience and, in exports markets, the safety of meat of Australian origin. For example, the shorts cuts campaign emphasised the ease of preparation of meat while, more recently, the iron campaign has focused on meat's nutritional qualities.

In exports markets, generic promotion has focused on the messages I have just imparted but has also stressed the safety of Australian meat. The guarantees on food safety made in export markets are supported by a residue testing procedure, which was originally developed following the organochlorine residue problem in the US market in 1987. Again, the corporation worked closely with industry and government to implement a residue testing and trace-back system which ensured that Australia's reputation was preserved and that no lasting damage was inflicted on the industry. This provides another example of how the corporation's activities have enhanced the image of Australian meat and therefore led to expanded market opportunities.

I have spent quite a bit of time talking about the corporation because this bill refers to the extension of power for the corporation. I believe that, by and large, it has built up a great body of expertise. It is an organisation that is in the hands of the industry and its players.

Areas of constant dissension in this industry include the continuing problem with respect to the meatworks and also export inspection charging. I believe there will always need to be constant attention paid to the activities of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, but enormous progress has been made and there is a limit to how far one can push it just because there is an associated cost. Some people seem to think that through constant criticism the standards can be downgraded. I reject this approach.

There have been many inquiries into the meat processing industry, such as the so-called Harrison report. There have been other reports on the industry as a whole. It is an industry that is rationalising all the time. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Bilney) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 September, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Dr Wooldridge had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes:

PARA.TAB: (1)the likelihood of foreshadowed amendments to the Budget;
(2)the vacillations and confusion about the Budget;
(3)the pernicious impact on low income Australians;
(4)the failure to reduce unemployment; and
(5)the continuing abrogation of responsibilities towards the long-term unemployed".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1993-94 with a great deal of concern. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, I have been a member of this House for a number of years and I have faced a number of elections. But I cannot remember an election that was fought with as much deceit as the last election.

PARA.TAB: The coalition came up with a policy. We crossed the t's and we dotted the i's and took it to the Australian people. But the campaign that was fought against us was just unbelievable. I am sure you remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, how every scare tactic in the book was used to frighten pensioners, trade unions, housewives and the unemployed. Anyone who was at all vulnerable was under attack. Unfortunately—as the Australian people are finding out now—that attack was very successful.

We now have a government in power that did not expect to be there. It has rattled together a budget that nobody wants and nobody cares for. This budget probably has one of the lowest ratings of any budget that has ever been brought before the Australian people. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been overseas for some time. While he was overseas, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) said, `I do not want a bar of this. I have been left holding the baby. The Prime Minister is overseas strutting the world stage and here I am left with this mess'.

What do we find in this budget? I would have thought the main objective of any budget at this time in Australia's history would be to try to create some jobs and try to get some people back to work. The nearly one million unemployed—many of them long term unemployed—are concerned that they do not have jobs. Of course, this is no good for the national morale.

Who creates jobs? The people who create the real jobs are businesses. What do the business organisations have to say about this budget? The Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Ian Spicer, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In its pre-budget submissions, the business community sought reductions in government spending, reductions in the deficit and reductions in taxes on business inputs.
What did it get? It got rises in all of those things. That does not say much for trying to get jobs for those unfortunate people who do not have them.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is saying, `You promised, Mr Prime Minister, that there would not be any tax increases, but in your One Nation statement you said something about tax cuts'. We all know that the One Nation statement was shonky from the start, but now it has fallen apart completely. Who can blame the Australian people for taking notice of some of the Prime Minister's statements? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think the incidence of tax should rise. I do not think that we ought to be having surplus fetishes years from now and try to cover them with tax collections brought about by a higher incidence of taxation. I just do not think we need . . . it. What I'm promising is not to put up tax.
He then went on to say:
We will be following the policy we have been following—that is, to keep Australia a low tax country.

This government comes in and promises tax cuts and legislates for tax cuts—they are l-a-w—and then to pay for those tax cuts it brings in these insidious taxes. That is why the coalition is opposing those taxes. We are saying to the government, `You must provide those promised tax cuts to the people'.

PARA.TAB: Why are we insisting on that? I had a long, hard look at it because I was very concerned. I thought that we ought to forget about these tax cuts. I have received a lot of information lately from people in my electorate—the low to middle income earners and the unemployed. I have a letter from an unemployed person, which will give honourable members an idea of what the unemployed think about the situation today. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,
My purpose in writing to you is to express my profound concern for the problems facing ordinary people in this country.
Honourable members should note the words `ordinary people'. The Prime Minister says that most of us are out of touch with them. The letter continues:
I have never taken pen to paper to a politician or newspaper in my life but I am now so concerned I feel I must.

I am a 56 year old married man with 4 adult children and 7 grandchildren (my wife and I celebrated 35 years of marriage on the 30/8/93). I possess good trade qualifications and references (a copy of my resume is attached for your information) and until the last years have always found it possible to obtain sound employment. Everywhere I go the word is you are too old. What rubbish. My grandfather was still putting in a good days work at 82 years. My father died very young, I despair that I may never find employment again. That I feel is a waste of my experience and ability and a loss to the country.

What is happening to this country Mr Hicks? All the mature age people are being pushed out, the young cannot get work. There are no apprentices being taken on, in 10 to 15 years time all our skills will be lost forever and no new trades-people to take our place. What a waste.

Media reports in the last few days tell me the average wage in Australia is now $600.00 per week and the Government gives the impression that no person receives below $22000.00 P.A. Our sole income is now $260.30 per week or $13536.60 P.A. It is proposed to give low income earners a tax rebate of $150.00 per year that is taxpayers on $22000.00 P.A. On our income we won't pay tax so no rebate. We own an old car 1970 Model Kingswood in very good condition. Since the budget it will now cost an extra $70-100 per year to run.

We are paying off a home through the N.S.W. Homefund which we will never own and should anything happen to either of us the house would be lost to the other, with Rent, Rates, excess water, phone, Electricity & Gas, petrol etc. Some weeks we have less than $40 for food etc. I believe I and hundreds of thousands of Australians like myself are in the AVERAGE group and get nowhere near what is reported.
This letter is not to whinge but to draw your attention to the plight of ordinary people. All I and most people want is a job, to work and put a bit of dignity into our lives.

My only son turned 25 on 24/8/93. When he was born I was working as a Plant Fitter on $50.00 per week, paying rent on a Housing Commission home had 3 girls at school and an old car and could still afford a holiday on the Coast every other year. Now my wife and I cannot afford a good night out.

I do not have access to a copier but would be grateful if you could give copies of this letter to members of other parties to gauge their reaction. Mr Hicks I do not want charity, handouts, sympathy or benefits. I just want a job.

That gives honourable members the message of what some of the unemployed people in our community are concerned about. Today, in answer to a question, the Prime Minister said that we must get used to the idea that we are going to have a great number of long-term unemployed people and that we must do all we can to look after them because he does not want an underclass in this nation. There is an underclass in this nation: the people on low incomes who are finding it so very difficult to survive.

PARA.TAB: Over the last several months I have had a number of phone calls, from women mainly, who have been crying on the phone. Some have come into my office to see me and said, `Mr Hicks, we can no longer survive as a family. We would be far better off if we split up and went on to the benefits and welfare provided by the government if we are to survive at all'.

Just to give another example, a woman who had been working full time, as had her husband, until seven weeks ago came to my office recently. They have three dependent children. Her husband is still working. He earns between $350 and $385 net per week. They are in receipt of the family allowance payment of $62 a fortnight. They applied for sickness allowance but they are earning too much. They are paying off their home and are finding it impossible to survive on one salary. The only assistance they can get is the additional family payment. I have tried to get that for them, but the problem is that, as the lady said to me, she has $40 in the bank.

Another lady—I will not go into it in detail—actually brought in a list of what it costs her to live per fortnight and what she and her husband are earning. At the end of the fortnight they have got $21.50 left over. They have to keep the children and provide all the extras on that. There we have an underclass in Australia.

Over the past 10 years we seem to have got away from the situation of people just being able to live on a wage or a salary. It seems to me that most people in Australia can survive only if they are getting welfare payments in addition to wages. We have in effect over the past 10 years reduced ourselves almost to a welfare state. As an Australian, I am not very proud of that. This is one of the reasons why I am saying that we in the coalition really cannot oppose this reduction in taxation—because these people must get some tax relief.

Over the past few years the government has been bragging about this accord that it has with the trade union movement. The government has also been bragging that it has been able to keep wages down. I do not think it is a matter of keeping wages down; I think we have to try to get the wages up so that people do not have to depend on welfare payments. The only way we can do that is to have a deregulated industrial relations system. But while the government side is being dictated to by the ACTU and the union movement this will never happen. The ranks of the unemployed will continue to swell.

We do not want people to have lower wages; we want people to have higher wages. We want people to have all those benefits that we should be able to provide in Australia. We cannot do that until we deregulate the system. Of course, we intended to do that in our coalition policy. I might say a bit more about that later. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) is in all sorts of strife trying to do what he knows is right for this nation.

What are we opposing here? We are opposing the fuel tax increases. Let us have a look at those fuel tax increases. We have an immediate increase of 3c on leaded and unleaded petrol; in February 1994 there will be an increase of 2c on leaded petrol and 1c on unleaded petrol; and in August 1994 there will be an increase of 2c on leaded petrol and 1c on unleaded petrol. There was to be a 3c increase on leaded petrol in February 1995, but the Democrats will not allow the last 3c. That is very generous of them. We are all paying the increases now.What does that increase do? When a tax is put on fuel, it is worse than any GST because it increases everything. If we were setting up this chamber today, everything in this room would increase in price because of the fuel increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worse in the bush.

—In the bush, as the honourable member says, we have a particular problem because everything that comes in has to travel great distances and everything goes out the same way. It does not matter what it is. The coalition had a proposal to reduce the fuel excise in order to get business up and going and to help families to be able to survive. With those families that I was talking about earlier, imagine what happens when they have to go and pay their fuel bill. Of course, most of them have cars that use leaded fuel. They are in more strife than Ned Kelly. That is one of the reasons why we are opposing this tax.

PARA.TAB: Apart from the overall increase in costs, the costs incurred by trucking operators, for example, are increased. A few days ago in the parliament the question was asked: how many people's jobs will be lost in the trucking industry as a result of the increase in the fuel tax? The answer was none. The Treasurer gave that answer. I think that the Treasurer should study that answer again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with a lot of other things.

—Everything, I would say. An average trucking operator in Australia has five rigs. The increase in the cost of fuel, plus the cost of the sales taxes going up another one per cent, will cost that operator $35,000 a year. That is at least one job. A trucking operator in my electorate phoned me and said, `We've just been hanging on by the tips of our fingers. We're hoping to stay in business, and we will stay in business, but we have had to put two of our five employees off—one aged 45 and one aged 48'.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Treasurer said something today about Christmas and that we were holding up the tax cuts and were going to make it a bleak Christmas for a lot of people in Australia. Imagine the bleak Christmas those people will have. As I read earlier, once someone is over 40 or 45 the chances of getting a job are almost nil, so those people will not have too good a Christmas. I would like to bring that to the Treasurer's attention. One of the reasons why we, particularly in the National Party, are so opposed to this increase in fuel tax, is the effect it would have on our people in the bush.

TALK.START.PARA: —It adds $70 million to farmers' costs.

—Another $70 million, as the honourable member for Murray said, on farmers' costs, apart from anything else. I have not even touched on the diesel fuel administration fee and I doubt if I will have time. That is also an horrendous tax.

PARA.TAB: We thought the primary objective of the budget would be jobs. Let us look at some of the unemployment figures in my electorate. In Wagga Wagga in March there was 10.4 per cent unemployment; Coolamon 9.4 per cent; Junee 13 per cent; Narrandera 14.5 per cent; Griffith 10.5 per cent; and Hay 11.5 per cent. The only one showing any promise was Leeton which was down to 8.6 per cent—still an horrendous historical figure but good compared with the rest.

Since then, of course, we have had problems with the Letona Cannery in Leeton, and I hope to speak to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) at a later date to see what can be done to make sure that that cannery stays open so that the 8.6 per cent will stay there, because if that cannery closes, that figure will go up to probably more than the other figures and that would be an absolute disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those increased fuel taxes won't help Letona to survive.

—They certainly will not, as the honourable member says. Letona depends very much on transport to get those canned goods away from the cannery, and any increase in sales tax just puts an extra cost on the tinned food.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the wine industry and at the temerity of the Treasurer. It is all right to blame everyone else, but it is really the Treasurer and the Prime Minister who get the budget together; they are the ones who work out the revenue. Who in their right mind would attack the wine industry, one of the leading industries in Australia? I would say that in technical terms we are recognised as one of the best wine producers in the world, both in quality and in cost. Previously, wine was taxed at 20 per cent. The sales tax on wine has now jumped to 31 per cent, with a further rise to 32 per cent in July 1995. It is estimated that such an increase will mean that a $5 bottle of wine is likely to rise in price by $1, a $10 bottle by $2, a $20 bottle by $3 and an $8 four-litre cask could cost $10. The industry is expecting consumption to fall by 10 per cent or possibly more.

We could go on and on with the figures, but the thing that really concerns me is not only the effect it will have on the wine industry and the wineries but also on the wine grape growers in my electorate and in other electorates. Already suffering now, they will be suffering further because of these fuel imposts and other taxes and charges imposed on them. The wine industry is one of the few industries that is really showing the way and putting Australia on the map, and the government has come along and chopped it off at the knees. I was absolutely flabbergasted.

I remember when Mr Hawke and the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) who is here alongside me at the moment came to visit my electorate in 1983. They put forward the budget proposals, and they said, `There will not be a tax on wine'. Wouldn't you know it, in the next budget of course there was a tax on wine. The industry survived, not because of the government but despite the government, and now we find this new tax on wine. It is horrendous. I am pleased to see that the Greens and the Democrats will support the coalition in doing something about making sure that that tax does not come in.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was as at seven o'clock.

—That was at seven o'clock, as the honourable member said. The other thing that really concerns me is roads and road funding. There is a $608 million decrease in road funding, with further decreases next year. Australia just cannot face that. The federal government recently announced that the Newell and Sturt highways will be part of the national highway system. With a reduction of $608 million in road funding I do not know how it will do that. The road system in much of my electorate is already dangerous. Recently, the city engineer in Wagga Wagga sent me a resume of the needs in that one city of Wagga. It is actually frightening.

PARA.TAB: In an article in the Wagga Daily Advertiser, Councillor Osborne of the Wagga council was reported as follows:

Australia's children would inherit a disintegrated road system thanks to a `tyrannical' fuel taxes system . . . a graph . . . indicated that government income from fuel excise had grown from about $900 million in 1979 to about $7,300 million in 1993 and a projected $9,000 million in 1993.
Meanwhile, roads funding had risen from about $500 million in 1979 to just under $2,000 million in 1993 and a projected $800 million in 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what will happen to the infrastructure because once it falls apart it costs a fortune. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know this, because you have said here many times that we need a great deal of money for the Pacific Highway. I know how much work you have done on that and how important it is.

PARA.TAB: I could touch on many other things. I said I would speak about industrial relations. I have run out of time, but I implore the government not to give in to the ACTU on sections 45D and 45E. Now that we have the Olympic Games, imagine the fun and games that will be going on in Sydney when all of these massive structures start to be put into place. We have been fortunate in the last three years. Industrial relations has been on a level plane because jobs are scarce. Once that money starts flowing, I can just imagine what will happen up there. I implore the government to do something about that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now some six week since the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) handed down this year's budget. Therefore, it is perhaps appropriate to reflect not only on the budget but also on the events that have occurred since. There has been a wide range of criticism of the 1993-94 budget. I have to admit that I share some of those concerns. Pleasingly, some of them have already been addressed.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I want to speak primarily about two matters: the budget process and the issue of unemployment. In the period since the Treasurer delivered the budget, we have seen what is surely an unprecedented process of negotiation and division. Most of this has occurred as a result of the objections to aspects of the budget by people outside of the executive: from the caucus, the ACTU, the minor parties in the Senate and sections of the wider community. There has been criticism of this input, criticism of the role of the caucus and the ACTU, and a suggestion that this display of disunity has produced the government's dip in recent opinion polls.

I reject this criticism, because I was pleased to see the budget amended in the ways that it has been and because I believe that this input has been appropriate. For example, I believe the ACTU has every right to have a say about the nation's budget. The question is not whether it should have a say but at what stage it has that say. Unfortunately, this year, for the first time in a decade, the ACTU was not consulted during the formulation of the budget. If it is not given an opportunity to have a say beforehand, then it can hardly be criticised for having a say afterwards. It is not, as the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) has just indicated, a matter of the ACTU dictating to government; it is the ACTU, on behalf of its membership, having input along with other representative bodies that represent different sectors of the community. It is on a basis of policy making that involves a spirit of inclusion of the wider community in the decision making process.

The government must recapture the spirit in which the One Nation statement and last year's budget were developed. This was a process based on consultation. In my view, the reason that One Nation and last year's budget were so well received and seemed to be effective was that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer and other ministers were out and about in the community listening to the key players—to the unions, to the business sector and to other community organisations. What has been seen in the last few weeks is the necessary, indeed inevitable, consultation and finetuning that should and could have taken place before budget night.

I turn now to the decision regarding the removal of Medicare rebates for optometrical consultations for those other than health care card holders. This was a stupid decision. I was horrified to be informed that, in a fashion, it was borrowed from the textbook of Margaret Thatcher. Mrs Thatcher removed eye care from the National Health Service in 1985, but even she had the good sense to exempt children under the age of 16 and families in receipt of supplementary benefit, the family income supplement or on low incomes.

Through this initiative, the British government saved a paltry #17 million in 1985. The measure that was originally included in the budget was also intended to save a paltry amount. However, I would not want the opposition to take comfort from my comments on this issue; indeed, it cannot. It went to the last election with a plan to smash Medicare and were rejected.

The community reaction to the proposal to delete eye tests underscores the community support for Medicare. The community wants Medicare; they want its universality protected and they are prepared to challenge anyone who threatens this. In fact, I believe that we should be mature enough to be looking not only at the present coverage under Medicare of medicine and optometry, but also at other allied health professions that might be included under the umbrella.

I believe that the dropping of the eye test rebate would never have been considered seriously had it been widely canvassed. The whole consultative process of decision making can be used to refine ideas and to prevent bad decisions being taken. I would now hope that the importance of getting this process right has been realised.

The last election was not about the level of taxation; it was about the nature of taxation. The electorate rejected unfair regressive taxes such as the GST. Perhaps in the run-up to the budget, had the government entered into a wider form of consultation, it would have understood that there was a wide opinion abroad that indicated a willingness to forgo the One Nation personal tax cuts rather than accept indirect taxes. Whilst I understand that the tax cuts to middle income earners are designed to be stimulatory, I reject any shift from progressive to regressive taxation. Whilst I also understand that there are constraints on the ability for wide consultation on specific tax measures, the generalities should be explored and discussed.

One of the progressive features of the present wholesale sales tax is the classification of goods. Whilst this is an imprecise tool, at least it is an element that exists in the present scheme. For instance, we have a higher rate of taxation on so-called and so-classified luxury items. But in the changes that we see there is a one per cent increase on the 10 per cent rate, which is far higher proportionately than a one per cent increase on the 30 per cent rate. The relativities which the differing rates of wholesale sales tax provide have not been protected by this flat rate of increase.

I share the concerns of organisations such as the Australian Council of Social Service about indirect regressive taxation. Before the budget ACOSS put to the government a number of taxation proposals, such as an inheritance tax, restriction of capital gains tax exemptions, negative gearing and taxing of luxury services. Many of these suggestions were also issues that were specifically raised in the FitzGerald report on national savings. Many of these proposals would have raised substantial revenue whilst taking into account the equity concerns that are so important.

Unfortunately, media coverage of the problems of the budget have tended to take attention away from the main question—that is, the question of growth in employment. As has been pointed out by a number of speakers in this debate, this budget has failed in a way to address the question of structural unemployment. The budget should be part of an ongoing countercyclical strategy to tackle unemployment through growth. However, as the Prime Minister himself said in question time today, the days when growth alone would solve unemployment problems are well and truly gone. Recent research shows that we need to sustain an annual growth rate of something like 6 1/2 per cent in order to return to full employment. A growth rate of roughly 3 1/2 per cent will allow us to stand still. This is obviously a chilling assessment.

On the weekend, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission launched a document entitled A moral accord with people who are long-term unemployed. This is a worthwhile document for people who have an interest in trying to solve Australia's major problem of the time, unemployment, to peruse. In the background to the present situation, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission points out that in 1990 long-term unemployment was 44 per cent above 1982 levels, despite strong annual job growth for which this government was responsible between 1984 and 1990. The shift of the mass employment base, manufacturing offshore, rapid and ongoing advances in technology and increasing productivity and efficiency all add up to an employment disaster for a whole generation. The jobs that have been lost are gone forever.

Jobs that are created do not tend to go to the most disadvantaged job seekers. In earlier contributions to this budget debate it has been pointed out that of the 1.6 million jobs created between 1983 and 1990, only 70,000 went to long-term unemployed people. The skills of those displaced in the labour market through the economic adjustment of the 1980s are no longer suitable for the new jobs that are created.

In its publication, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission refers to an occurrence known as job mismatch. This is a phenomenon where vacancies cannot be filled, although there are large numbers of unemployed people willing and able to work, because of the loss of everyday work skills or the inappropriateness of their work skills to the jobs available. As the document said, structural change has also created a `sectoral mismatch' and the existing skills of many people who are unemployed are no longer appropriate for the positions that become available.

Without intervention by the government, this situation will become increasingly worse. People who have been put out of the labour market for a long period of time require assistance by the government to enable them to re-enter. The Catholic Social Welfare Commission states:

SPEECH.PARA: Without positive intervention, and even with modest economic growth, the worst case scenario suggests more than 500,000 long-term unemployed by the end of 1994, and the best about 360,000.

I find it difficult to comprehend how any organisation could argue for a reduced role for government when the facts are so compelling. In my electorate, as in other members' electorates—I acknowledge the cases that the honourable member for Riverina put before us in his contribution—there are many who genuinely fear they will never work again. We must all give these people hope.

PARA.TAB: The opposition argues for a reduction in the deficit at the same time as providing tax cuts and introducing no new taxes. In between all of the crocodile tears for the poor, let there be no doubt that this is its policy. The Australian people need to know that this adds up to large spending cuts—in fact, massive cuts in outlays. These cuts would affect every area of government expenditure and every facet of life in Australia. The effect of massive cuts in social programs would be that many Australians would simply fall through the safety net. The cuts to government expenditure would mean that the unemployed would miss the springboard to employment that can be created through the active role of the public sector in the economy.

The policies of the opposition, even without the GST, remain a pernicious threat to the fabric of Australian society. We saw that from the opposition's wholehearted endorsement last week of the Industry Commission's draft report—Impediments to regional industry adjustment. This report has been slammed by a wide range of community organisations and economic commentators as being totally out of touch with reality. Few of the issues raised by the Industry Commission report dealt specifically with regional unemployment. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) earlier this week in question time said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . some of the recommendations—
that is, of the Industry Commission—
are guided by a philosophy that is alien to this side of the House and certainly will not guide our responses to those issues.

I was pleased to see the minister, and a cabinet minister at that, was willing to put that type of comment on record because there is grave concern about the type of advice that comes out of some of the Industry Commission's reports. When one looks at the terms of reference of the particular inquiry those comments were made about, one notes that in giving the reference the government specifies that the commission is to have regard to the established economic, social and environmental objectives of governments. I hope that in undertaking its inquires the commission will perhaps have a greater regard to that because historically its record has not been good. In reports on the provision of public housing, disability aids and the like, the commission's interpretation of what is within the bounds of social objectives of government is quite amiss. I believe that it should address those issues within the parameters that most people who work within social policy would find plausible.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission has propagated its hardline economic rationalism. It is now common to hear talk of award flexibility as if it were some magic cure to the nation's problem. The question that should be asked is just what exactly this term means? How flexible are these awards if the terms refer specifically to lower award conditions, as it invariably does? Terms such as `award flexibility' should be treated with extreme caution because they usually require one party to be flexible rather than the other.

As Tim Colebatch, the economic editor of the Age, outlines in his article of 21 September about the Industry Commission's report, the experience in other countries of removing awards has not solved the problems of regional unemployment; the removal of awards can be said to have further exacerbated it. Colebatch points out that areas of New Zealand with high unemployment in 1991, such as the Bay of Plenty, have even higher unemployment since the removal of awards. He gives the example of the United States, where there is not only enterprise bargaining but also `weak unions and a six-month limit to unemployment benefits—just what the commission wants'. Colebatch states:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983, when unemployment in the US peaked, the four states with the highest unemployment rates were West Virginia, Michigan, Alabama and Mississippi. Eight years later, the four states with the highest unemployment rates were West Virginia, Michigan, Massachusetts and Mississippi.

As Colebatch says, `It didn't work there either'. Clearly this attack on award wages from the Industry Commission will do nothing for unemployment; world experience indicates that. But what if we look at other definitions of award flexibility and perhaps turn to the question of the developing nature of work? I refer honourable members again to the Catholic Social Welfare Commission's report where it describes the move towards part-time work. It states:

Over the last decade there has been a marked decline in the number of full-time jobs. This decline has also seen an increase in the amount of part-time work available in the labour market . . . In the future, it is more likely that people will have several part-time jobs. Some people may only find employment through one part-time job and require a supplemented income.
It then goes on to say:
The increased demand for part-time work means that there is a need to develop more flexible workplace practices so that people can job-share or move in and out of the labour market without penalty.

If we are talking about that type of flexibility, we really have to consider the wider issues that are involved. Why should the Australian people accept simplistic recommendations from the Industry Commission which are based on a narrow ideological view of the world? As Bishop Michael Challen, the executive director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, said last week at the launch of the book Understanding Social Justice, written by the honourable member for Calwell, (Dr Theophanous):
The new right agenda . . . does not achieve it—
that is, social justice—
as it is based on the premise that inequality is a precondition for growth. While the social democratic tradition has most chance of achieving it, full employment is a critical precondition of this.
Later, Bishop Challen made this remark:
If governments are serious about social justice they must take action in two key areas, employment and taxation.

That remark is important in the context of my next point. New approaches and new strategies must be considered if we are to address the problem of structural unemployment. The government's white paper process provides the opportunity to do so. There has been wide discussion of the potential for an employment levy on higher income earners as a means of raising revenue directly for measures to fight unemployment. Perhaps at some later stage I will be able to develop those ideas in more detail.

PARA.TAB: It is important that this white paper process provides an opportunity for consultation and for inclusive decision making—unfortunately, the types of things that were sadly lacking in the preparation of the original budget. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Bilney) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this evening 50 years ago—29 September 1943—the then Prime Minister of Australia, at a little after 8.30 p.m, rose in this place and said:

SPEECH.PARA: We who have sat in this chamber tonight have participated in one of the historic episodes of our Commonwealth Parliament.

The episode to which Mr Curtin referred was, of course, the maiden speech of Dame Enid Lyons, the first woman to be elected to the House of Representatives. The historical importance of that occasion was not lost on Dame Enid, whose husband, Joseph, had been Prime Minister of Australia from 1932 until his death in 1939. She said:

It would be strange indeed were I not tonight deeply conscious of the fact, if not a little awed by the knowledge, that on my shoulders rests a great weight of responsibility; because this is the first occasion upon which a woman has addressed this House.

In fact, two women were returned to parliament at the general election in 1943: Enid Lyons as the member for Darwin, an electorate in Tasmania; and Dorothy Tangney as a Labor senator for Western Australia. Both women were aware of the task ahead of them. Dame Enid said:

I believe, very sincerely, that any woman entering the public arena must be prepared to work as men work; she must justify herself not as a woman, but as a citizen; she must attack the same problems, and be prepared to shoulder the same burdens.
This was a sentiment shared by Dorothy Tangney, who had remarked in her maiden speech to parliament five days earlier:

It is not as a woman that I have been elected to this chamber. It is as a citizen of the Commonwealth; and I take my place here with the full privileges and rights of all honourable senators, and, what is still more important with the full responsibilities which such a high office entails.

Enid Lyons and Dorothy Tangney were two remarkable women. They were not the first women members of parliament in Australia—that honour rests with Edith Cowan, who was elected to the Western Australian parliament in 1921—but they contributed greatly to the life of this nation: Dame Enid as the member for Darwin from her election in 1943 until 1951, including her appointment to the federal cabinet in 1949, and Dame Dorothy, as she was to become, as a senator for Western Australia for 25 years until 1968.

PARA.TAB: Some of their comments remain as valid today as they were in 1943. Both were concerned about social justice in the midst of war and within a decade of the Great Depression. Dorothy Tangney said:

SPEECH.PARA: Preference to any section of the community implies a return to the old order of things, in which there was not sufficient for everybody, and only some people were privileged to work. If these conditions were allowed to return, they will be a negation of what we are fighting for. Under this new order there must be justice for all and not reference to any one section.
It is a pity that the Labor government does not heed these words today. Dame Enid said:
I hope that I shall never forget that everything that takes place in this chamber goes out somewhere to strike a human heart, to influence the life of some fellow being . . .

Whether that purpose in life is expressed in religious terms, as Dame Enid expressed it then, or in a humane concern for the dignity and well-being of our fellow human beings, her words echo a vision absent from much of national life today. Despite—some might say because of—the deprivations of the Great Depression and the Second World War, we then had governments which inspired Australians in unity and in hope.

PARA.TAB: It is pleasing to note that the Senate has marked this occasion with the publication of the book Trust the Women, which details the contributions to national life of 59 women who have served as senators and members since 1943, and with an occasional lecture delivered under the auspices of the Senate last week by my colleague the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). It is appropriate, though, that this anniversary be recorded in this chamber this week.

It was hope that Enid Lyons and Dorothy Tangney shared and inspired in all Australians. It is the same hope that we must rekindle if we are to contribute to the peace, welfare and happiness of the people of Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Monday and Tuesday, 20 and 21 September, the Newcastle Workers Club was the venue of a world-wide conference on ship safety initiated by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and sponsored and organised in a highly competent manner by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The conference was entitled `Ships of shame—what can be done?'.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Australian Maritime Safety Authority for the professional manner in which it hosted the conference and for the way in which the conference was conducted. I would like to thank my committee colleagues: the deputy chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur); the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who is here on my right; and the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), all of whom attended the conference and some of whom participated in it. I think they share my views as to the success of the conference. The honourable member for Throsby participated in the forum in the latter stages of the conference. More than 200 delegates participated in that conference over the two days. I also want to thank formally in this place those international speakers—people of the highest ranking in the world on particular subjects—who came to Australia to participate in the conference.

Safety in sea transport, like safety in road, rail or air transport, will always involve a trade-off between the level of safety and the level of cost—a trade-off between a sensible level of safety and realistic levels of cost. The Ships of shame inquiry found that, with a minority of ships, the scales were tilted against safe working practices in favour of ruthless cost cutting and profiteering, regardless of the dangers involved for seafarers and the marine environment. It found that, in the vast majority of marine casualties, the human element was the prime causal factor. By human element, we mean all those decision makers involved—from the owner of the vessel who makes the decision to buy the vessel, to the ship manager, to the ship charterer, right through to the people who actually use the vessel, who are either the exporters or the importers.

Last week's conference was about people—people who live and work and die in ships; people who design, build and repair ships; people who register ships purporting to meet international maritime standards; people who inspect ships to ensure that they meet the required international standards; and, lastly and importantly, people who utilise the services of substandard ships. It is their decision to use substandard ships and to use ships that employ substandard practices that unleash the risks and dangers generated by substandard ship practices, the risks and dangers to the seamen who work on those vessels and to the ports and marine environments of the nations they visit.

I mentioned earlier today, as did the honourable member for Throsby in the last week of sitting, the case of the Greek vessel Angelic Faith which was held up in Dalrymple Bay a few weeks ago. The payment of $200,000 was arranged for 11 Burmese seafarers on that vessel. Those seafarers were flown home by Qantas via Singapore on the way to Bangkok. They were effectively hijacked in Singapore and went on to Rangoon some days later. We have been unable to ascertain the whereabouts of or what has happened to those seafarers. But information was provided to us in evidence in the course of our inquiry about Myanmar or Burma, the contracts that people are forced to sign, the double pay books and the contracts that require them to pay to the government any additional wages they earn while they are abroad—remembering that when one gets a Burmese crew that crew is provided by the government and the government collects a return for the crew and remits some of that money to the seafarers. The money is not paid to the sailors; it is paid to the government. The government hires out a group of people.

The companies, the coal vendors, the coal buyers, the coal charterers and the Star Corporation Shipping Co., which owns that vessel, need to stand up now and identify themselves as the people benefiting from the exploitation, the intimidation and the blood and pain that those sailors are now suffering as a result of the use of that vessel and the actions that have followed in the days since this happened a few weeks ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment to honour the 50th anniversary of the first address in this house by a woman. It is 50 years today since Dame Enid Lyons delivered her maiden speech in this House. In that speech she said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am well aware that, as I acquit myself in the work that I have undertaken for the next three years, so shall I either prejudice or enhance the prospects of those women who may wish to follow me in public service in the years to come.

As one who follows Dame Enid in public service, I would want to thank her and assure her that she did indeed enhance our prospects. Dame Enid was not only the first woman elected to this house but also the first woman to serve in a federal cabinet. Senator Dorothy Tangney was elected to the Senate at the same time. There have been a number of commemorations of the anniversary, including a special stamp issue and the launch of the excellent book Trust the Women by Ann Millar.

PARA.TAB: I also want to record my appreciation of the men and women who worked for decades to ensure that Australia had access to the political wisdom of the other half of its population. In particular, I mention the work of Catherine Helen Spence, who was a resident in what is now my electorate. Catherine Spence was Australia's first female political candidate. Despite being regarded as one of the great Australian women of the 19th century, she came 22nd out of a field of 23.

Of the 21 elections since the election of Dame Enid Lyons, 10 elections have not returned one woman; only one of those elections, the 1972 election of the Whitlam Labor government, did not return any woman for either house. Recent progress has been more steady. Since 1980 the number of women elected to this house has been three, six, eight, nine, 10 and now 13. At the rate of an increase of 10 every 10 years, we would reach gender balance well after the centenary of Dame Enid's election.

Let me assure the House that we women are here for the long haul. It took 100 years from Mary Wollstonecraft's Rights of Women until women won the right to vote and stand for parliament. It took another 50 years before the first women were elected to parliament.

What of the next 50 years? What is the most important goal for the next 50 years? Should we aim for a female Prime Minister, a majority of members in the Senate or majorities in both Houses? I would suggest a more subtle goal: that women's contributions to the political life of this nation will be accepted on their merits and not be devalued as women's views.
In a speech last Monday, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) outlined her frustration at the impact of preconceptions on her parliamentary contribution. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: It appeared that women MPs could state their views however they liked—tactfully or aggressively, sweetly or stridently, obliquely or bluntly—but if they were expressing views about women, too often a majority of the men in their parliamentary audience automatically closed their ears, believing that they were about to hear fringe feminist rhetoric.

Women do not seek to have women in parliament as a feminist goal in and of itself. Women care about their community and how it is governed, and are entitled to have their views on the breadth of their concerns respected and listened to. Dame Enid's maiden speech is a case in point. She spoke only briefly about women in parliament and then ranged across a number of topics—social services, population, decentralisation, family policy, the war, housing, employment policy and international relations. I conclude by encouraging women to take up the challenge of the future. The problems besetting our nation are great; we need the best people to resolve them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said in recent weeks about petrol pricing. In its usual destructive role, the opposition—the Uriah Heep of politics—has taken the opportunity to spread doom and gloom. I want to look at a real situation, namely, the unique opportunity that exists in Australia for alternative fuels.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I want to talk about LP gas. LP gas is a naturally occurring gaseous hydrocarbon that exists in Australia in great quantities. It does not need a lead additive. In fact, the lubricant used in it is propylene, another hydrocarbon, so that it burns completely to produce carbon dioxide and water vapour. The cost of converting a pre-1985 six-cylinder car to run on LP gas is approximately $1,650; a new Holden or Falcon, about $1,900. Opposition members will probably say, `More money, another slug', but we should be considering the benefits.

LP gas is a low polluter. LP gas deposits are largely owned by Australian companies. LP gas tanks are safer than petrol tanks in cars. LP gas is tax free and has been guaranteed to remain so for the next five years. In fact, any decision to introduce tax at the end of that period needs to have been notified 12 months in advance.

Motorists also enjoy many benefits. The fuel is cleaner with less harmful by-products, which means that motors will cost less to maintain and their life is extended. Motorists travelling 30,000 kilometres per year will more than recoup the cost of conversion over a two-year period. In other words, the further they travel, the greater the saving.

I represent a rural electorate and I am pleased to advise the House that specialist gas converters are working overtime to convert cars to LP gas. There is an obvious bonus there for rural residents and I would urge them all to use it.

Secondly, I want to talk about ethanol. Honourable members may have noticed that the ACTION buses in Canberra are currently boldly advertising that they are trialing diesohol, an 85 per cent diesel and 15 per cent ethanol mix, the brainchild of one of my constituents, Dr Russell Reeves. Dr Reeves and his partners hold the worldwide patent for the catalyst that allows the production of diesohol. That represents Australian technology, under the leadership of this government to the fore again. Honourable members would be very interested to know that the public transport system in Sweden now runs on diesohol, cutting costs, reducing pollution and using our technology.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has recently approved a $50,000 feasibility study that is currently being carried out in the Dungog-Gloucester area. It will look into the feasibility of producing ethanol from forest waste. At the conclusion of this study a trial plant will be constructed at the chosen site to produce ethanol from renewable resources. This plant will be constructed courtesy of a $2 million grant that was announced last December by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths). This is exciting news in many ways. Ethanol will reduce our dependence on imported diesel fuel but it will, more importantly, place Australia as a leader in the world of renewable fuel technology. I urge all honourable members to watch the development of this industry that has had strong government support.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate this week on superannuation I developed the argument that there is no fairness or justice in superannuation as it is being presented to the Australian workers by the current government. Since that debate, it has come to my attention that a number of businesses in my electorate have workers who are seriously disadvantaged. They are casual, part-time workers; some are migrants and some are women. They are people who are trying to keep the household together, often when the principal income earner has become redundant or unemployed.

PARA.TAB: For example, at the Hills District Evening College there are a number of casual teachers. Teacher No. 1 earned $450 for only one calendar month last financial year and became eligible for a superannuation payout—calculated at three per cent of $450—of $13.50. Most superannuation funds have an administrative charge of at least $52 per annum and the union funds are higher than that. The payment of $13.50 was deducted from $52, leaving a debit balance of $38.50. That will be carried against that teacher's name indefinitely if that teacher should go back to employment at any of the evening colleges. The funds would then pick up that debit and further write off any money paid in by the employer against the remaining charge of $38.50.

A second example is teacher No. 33 who became eligible for a superannuation payout of three per cent of $1,790, which is $51.33. Thus for the first year, there was a credit of $51.33 with a fund charge of $52, leaving a debit balance in this instance for this individual of 79c.

Teacher No. 49 became eligible for a superannuation benefit of $113.14. Thus, for year one, the fund statement would show a payment of $113.14, a charge of $52, leaving a credit balance of $61.14. That is the benefit that worker would have at the end of the period. If that person were not to work for the following two years, there would be a continuing $52 a year charge against their contribution, reducing their contribution, which was originally $113.14, to a debt of $42.86 at the end of a three-year period.

There is no justice or fairness in this process. Another business that has brought to my attention the situation of its employees is Elf Mushrooms Pty Ltd. I will not use the names of the employees, but I have them here. The premium paid by employee No. 1 was $132.17. There is an administrative charge of $58.27, a tax of 15 per cent on contribution of $13.19 and a dividend paid of $6.82, leaving the employee with $67.53 at the end of the period. Instead of $132, this person had only $67 in the account. There is no fairness or justice in that. There are no changes in the legislation to rectify that. I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Mrs Crosio), who is at the table, may be unaware of these processes, but workers are being seriously damaged by the accord of Martin Ferguson and the government which says that superannuation is good for everybody. That is bunkum and rubbish.

Employee No. 2 in the same organisation contributed a total of $264.86. At the end of the period all those two people have in their accounts is $170-odd. Roughly half of the funds are lost either through a mystery charge or through tax paid to the government. The problem with these schemes is that the workers who need them most miss out. They are on a treadmill and they do not get anywhere. The funds do not get enough to cover their costs. The employer pays extra and the worker gets nothing. It is a crazy system.

Employers are milked of their funds for no benefit and they just lay off employees rather than continue to lose money in this process. The funds are pushed and pulled by continuing changes in government policy, which means that the workers never know where they stand. I can tell them that this government does not care, because it has done nothing to lift the basic charge from $450 to at least $600. An exemption level of $600 is an absolute minimum. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, 29 September, is World Maritime Day. As such, it is an appropriate day to consider the role of shipping and to pay tribute to the seafarers of the world. Seafaring has a long and distinguished history and we in Australia, as an island continent, are more dependent than most on ships to bring produce to, and take produce from, this country. It is also an appropriate time to consider human and financial tragedies that can result from unsafe practices in regard to shipping and the potential for any vessel to cause major damage to a nation's maritime environment, ecosystems and trade.

PARA.TAB: The loss of ships and lives in recent times has been appalling. Between 1988 and 1991 some 47 loaded merchant vessels were lost worldwide, along with the lives of at least 380 crew. Australia was not immune from the impact of the effects of this unnecessary waste of life and property. Over a similar period, six bulk carriers were lost in the Indian Ocean, having sailed from Australian ports.

Last week, in Newcastle, all sectors of the shipping industry in Australia gathered to discuss the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Ships of shame. Also, last week a shameful document was released from the Industry Commission purporting to outline impediments to regional industry adjustment in Australia. One of the recommendations was for the termination of the policy of cabotage for coastal shipping.

At a time when the world's ocean transport industry faces an unprecedented crisis, the international fleet has become critically over-aged and suffers from a deteriorating safety record, the implications for the removal of cabotage to Australia would be devastating. What far-ranging and far-sighted preparations have been made in Australia against the day when there is a shortage in world shipping—bearing in mind that any such shortage would impact on Australia much more than most other countries?

Very little has been done in Australia and, indeed, those opposite continue to push for our Australian coast to be opened to the ageing rust buckets of the world. The argument of those opposite is that if other countries are foolish enough to use taxpayer funds to subsidise shipping and shipowners and crews are prepared to run huge risks in running cheap, untaxed, unsafe ships, then Australia should participate in this free lunch and not bother about developing its own shipping capability, as the free market will take care of it for us.

This is not good enough for a nation with the fifth largest transportation task in the world. The removal of cabotage would lead to the immediate disappearance of the Australian flag fleet and its input to the economy. The fleet would have to flag out to tax havens to survive. Australian ships pay tax, their crews pay tax, and they carry the costs of complying fully with all the international safety conventions. We are thus uncompetitive with the untaxed, unregulated and unsafe ships that the removal of cabotage would allow in.

Australia now has one of the most modern merchant fleets, if not the best, and one of the best trained seafaring work forces in the world. For this we can largely thank a tripartite 10-year effort between government, industry and unions. Reform of Australian shipping has been one of the major achievements of the government's microeconomic reform process. It has resulted in a major reform of this traditionally difficult industry which has gone almost totally unremarked by either the press or the public.

In the calling for the introduction of foreign flag ships to Australia, the Industry Commission is following in the footsteps of the American shipowners in 1917 and of every tax avoiding, regulation evading international shipowner since. Disguise it how they may—they are advocating tax avoidance. The huge advantage these owners have over Australian shipowners is that they pay little or no tax. They are not smarter or better. They just do not have the tax burden.

Foreign flags are cheaper because they do not pay tax, but that is no reason to import them into our domestic economy. The argument that this would lead to a competitive balance between Australian flag ships and foreign flags is nonsense. The Australian ships would flag out immediately in order to gain the tax advantages of their competitors and we would finish up with no Australian fleet at all.

If this is what the opposition is proposing, it is proposing that we in Australia exchange safe, well maintained and well manned ships for the foreign ships. Additionally, it would put several thousand seafarers onto the dole and significantly increase our balance of payments problem by the profits and wages repatriated out of Australia.

The government must strongly reject this nonsense report from the Industry Commission. On this World Maritime Day we must commit ourselves to maintaining cabotage around the Australian coast. We should also pay tribute to those seafarers who go down to the sea in ships. Long may they continue to do so in Australian flagged ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I made a speech commemorating the 50th anniversary of the first woman to enter the House of Representatives and the Senate. I referred to the fact that, on my election to the House of Representatives, some of my male colleagues—well intentioned, I am sure—told me that I was not to be like the Labor women in this House, who only ever talked about women. I went on in my speech to point out that that was not my experience of the speeches of the Labor women and, subsequently, I had drawn some conclusions about that matter. Tonight all that the Liberal women are talking about is women, in contrast to the ALP men. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) also spoke about women, and it was very welcome to hear a Liberal man speak on the subject for a change. In view of the event whose anniversary this evening is—namely, the 50th anniversary of the maiden speech in the House of Representatives of Dame Enid Lyons, the first woman ever elected to this chamber—I wish to speak very briefly.
