PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, Dame Enid had to retire early because of ill health. Her biography tells us that, as she grew older, after leaving this place, her health improved. I met her at a function in Canberra in 1976 when, as I recall, she was past 80 years of age. I had never dreamt that I would ever meet her and was thrilled to have the opportunity and the privilege. Her speech that day was challenging and sharp—a clear indication of the vigour of her intellect and the strength of her personality. When I was introduced to her that day she urged—even instructed—me to stay in parliament for a long time. I suspect her own premature retirement from the House of Representatives was a matter of enduring and continuing regret to her, but I did not have the nerve to broach the subject with her then.

I remain grateful to this day that I had the honour of meeting and having a conversation with her, even if it was for only a few minutes and with a number of other people present. The circumstances were not conducive to a swapping of personal experiences or inquiries as to how she had managed the incredible loneliness she must have experienced here in those days.

I do not wish to impose on the chamber tonight because I know others wish to speak. However, I do wish to say that, whilst it is 50 years since Dame Enid came in here, without doubt her impact has lasted over the years—although there would have been times subsequently when she would have wondered about it. Her courage in taking that great step into the Commonwealth parliament is something that we should acknowledge and that all Australian women should be grateful for. She was the pioneer and the icebreaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the 1980s it seems to have become almost mandatory that whoever runs government organisations should preferably be ignorant of the organisation's workings and public purpose. The itinerant chief executive generally changes the organisation's name and telephone numbers. The organisation is usually relocated physically, extolling the virtues of either all under one roof or decentralisation.

PARA.TAB: There is an invariable need to shed production staff and increase the number and salaries of executives. There is also a need to contract out, call in consultants and form partnerships with a range of private organisations. Often a new and expensive headquarters is built largely as a monument to the chief executive. New logo designs are prepared; seminars and overseas trips dramatically increase.

The chief executive generally moves on before the music stops, and the organisation inexorably declines. It is marginalised or sold off, and clearly loses all sense of public purpose. We seem to have overdosed on the Harvard business school of management with the price of everything and the value of nothing syndrome. Even many long term Dr Jekylls in the Public Service seem to have a Mr Hyde, Mr Bond or a Mr Skase inside and they gleefully adopt the syndrome when free.

Public institutions such as the Federal Airports Corporation, the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority, Telecom, Qantas, and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation are all more or less examples of this syndrome. The ABC is now a particularly well advanced case. The thrust towards pay TV, together with advertising on the Asian service and SBS, the spread of overt and covert sponsorship, coproductions, reduction of program makers and advertising thinly disguised as documentary on programs such as Everybody, Consuming Passions and the Home Show, certainly indicates the beginning of the end. The Channel Ten recent blatant running of a new car launch of Nissan Bluebird for its sponsor Nissan as a main news item simply indicates where the ABC is heading.

In spite of the previous denials, the Asian satellite service is already siphoning off funds from free to air television. The cost of this service so far is $2.5 million and has a shortfall of $2.3 million. The latest can do man, Mr Ben Hawke, General Manager of Australian Television International, whose job it is to make the service pay, blithely says that if a further injection of funds from free to air television is required then he makes no apologies.

The ABC's involvement in pay TV threatens to be the trojan horse that will ultimately prove fatal to the organisation. It will prove fatal to its role as an independent broadcaster and possibly the most important cultural institution in this country. It is inevitable that pay TV will bleed the free to air services of resources and program materials. No amount of `black is white' jargon statements about pay TV `boosting' the free to air service by `pumping in' revenue or by commissioning and buying programs or ideas that we will `lose the plot' will alter that fact.

The ABC's management claims that pay TV will show news, fine drama and children's drama. That shows how far the ABC has departed from its original charter. In other words, access to independent and high quality information for both adults and children is now subject to the capacity to pay and ultimately the censorship of the sponsor. New Zealand has shown that, after three years of Sky television, only seven per cent of households use the service. So much for providing an injection of funds for free to air television! Why would people in New Zealand watch pay TV when the three channels present esoteric and mostly boring minor sport, CNN news consisting largely of male and female versions of Bronwyn Bishop hairstyles interviewing each other, and endless old movies?

Given a likely charge of $480 per annum and a plethora of other pay TV—both satellite and microwave—and at least 12 free to air channels from Star Television in Hong Kong, together with a number of other possible channels from Indonesia, New Zealand and USA within a few years, what chance does pay TV on ABC ever have of providing any funds? The ABC pay TV is commercially, and in quality programming terms, a dead duck. All that it will do is lead to a transfer of resources from the ABC radio and free to air television which are already stretched. The Fraser government began the squeeze in the 1970s, but since 1983 Labor governments have steadily eroded the role of the ABC. In recent years we have seen an acceleration towards its ultimate demise.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: Is the Coal and Minerals Division of his Department involved in activities in regard to Maralinga; if so, (a) what activities, (b) what expenditures have arisen from those activities since 1 January 1993 and (c) what was the reason for each expenditure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Yes. The Division is responsible for the management of the 3200 square kilometre test site area at Maralinga and prevention of exposure of

ANSWER.PARA: members of the public to residual radiological and other hazards at the test site. The Division is also responsible for implementing the clean-up of the former test sites.

PARA.TAB: (b) Expenditures that have arisen during the period 1 January 1993 to 31 August 1993 are as follows:
Australian Protective Service Guarding (APS)—payments cover the period 1 January 1993 to 30 June 1994—$392,480
Maintenance of Maralinga APS post—$174,366
Site visit for planning rehabilitation works—$2,137

(c) The Maralinga APS post is permanently manned to prevent unauthorised access to sites contaminated by the British nuclear weapons test program at Maralinga (1955-1963). A site visit was undertaken in relation to the rehabilitation program to reduce the considerable radiological hazards at the test sites.
